title: Thames Water sparks fury after plans to reduce pollution in River Evenlode thrown into doubt
lead: A campaign group working with Thames Water say they have been ‘betrayed’ by the company and will no longer accept funding from them
author: Lucie Heath

body.text: Thames Water has been accused of betrayal after it appeared to reverse on a commitment to help clean up a popular river in the Cotswolds.

The water company had agreed to what campaigners described as “critical” work to rid the River Evenlode, a tributary of the Thames, of pollution but it was missing from Thames Waters’ latest business plan.

A charity focused on improving the water quality of the River Evenlode has broken ties with Thames Water, saying the water company “betrayed” them by failing to commit to upgrading a number of sewage treatment plants they say is essential to improving the river’s quality.

Thames Water said its investment plans for the next five years are still subject to change, but acknowledged it was “not what our partners had expected”, adding that the business was facing a “challenging time” amid financial pressure.

Rising near Moreton-in-Marsh in Gloucestershire, the River Evenlode encompasses a number of popular swimming spots on its journey through the Cotswolds towards Cassington in Oxfordshire, where it joins the Thames.
But the water has become so polluted with sewage that locals have been warned against taking a dip for their own safety.

In 2021, Thames Water provided funding to a group called the Evenlode Catchment Partnership (ECP) as part of a 10-year initiative to improve water quality and restore the river to ‘good’ ecological status.

As part of the project, the ECP has been collecting and analysing data on the water quality in the area. A key finding is that the Evenlode contains high levels of phosphorus pollution from sewage. This causes algae growth that restricts oxygen levels, killing fish and other aquatic life.
The ECP recommended that Thames Water carried out phosphorus stripping upgrades at its sewage treatment works in the catchment area as part of its 2025-30 business plan.

The ECP said Thames Water had originally agreed to carry out this work, but the project is missing from the latest draft version of its business plan, which was published in October and has been submitted to regulators for approval.
As a result, the ECP has made the decision to stop taking any funding from the water company after 2025 when its current project ends.

Ann Berkeley, the ECP’s project manager, said: “Thames Water has repeatedly assured us that the required improvements will be made, but these are not present in the business plan. This is a betrayal of our trust and we no longer have faith in Thames Water’s assurances.

“In light of this, ECP has made the difficult decision to end our relationship with Thames Water at the conclusion of our project in 2025, symbolising our collective dismay at Thames Water’s lack of meaningful commitment to repairing the damage already done to our rivers.”

A Thames Water spokesperson said: “We greatly value the close partnerships we have with our local communities and the Smarter Water Catchment partnership for the River Evenlode. However, we recognise the proposals within our draft PR24 business plan submission, which has yet to be discussed with our regulators and is subject to change, are not what our partners had expected and we’re sorry for the concern this has caused.

“The last year has been an extremely challenging year for the business. As we set out in our full year results, our performance was impacted by inflation, which significantly increased costs for energy, chemicals and capital items, and the penalties we received as severe weather events impacted operational performance.

“While we are still spending the same amount in real terms, the purchasing power of this amount has been impacted. Given this we continue to take a rigorous approach to financial discipline throughout the company in order to operate within budget and to prioritise improving the core performance of our business.”
Earlier this year Thames Water was forced into emergency talks with the water regulator Ofwat after it was revealed it was facing a £10bn black hole in its budget.

The group raised £750m from shareholders in July, but remains one of four water companies – alongside Southern Water, South East Water and SES Water – that Ofwat has raised the flag over for financial health.

title: How climate change is affecting the way we have babies
lead: We look at the science and find climate change is affecting every stage of the reproductive process, from sex to birth
author: Tom Bawden

body.text: Climate change is not only threatening our way of life – for some of us it is risking the creation of life itself – from our sex lives and fertility, to the birth of our children.
In some cases, climate change is putting people off having children and in others it could prevent those who do want them from doing so, studies suggest.

Research into how climate change is affecting how and whether we have babies is still thin on the ground but there are growing signs that it is already starting to make a difference – a trend that will only accelerate as temperatures continue to warm.
As Professor Alan Barreca, of the University of California at Los Angeles (UCLA), told : “Hot weather impacts all stages of reproductive health from conception to delivery.”
These are some of the ways in which climate change is starting to impact on sex and how we have babies.
It remains unclear whether high temperatures damage eggs but there is clear evidence that they can severely damage sperm.
A 2022 study involving 356 men from Italy, Iran, Thailand, China and Egypt looked at the potential of high temperatures due to global warming or the workplace.

It concluded that “high ambient temperature negatively affects sperm quality, including decreased semen volume, sperm count, sperm concentration, motility [movement] and normal morphology [size and shape].”
And this could ultimately mean that in some cases people are unable to have children, especially if they are older, argues Professor Barreca.

“Men are impacted when it comes to producing healthy sperm. Given more men and women are conceiving at older ages, my worry is that climate change will rob them of the chance to have the family size that is right for them.
“There are likely to be couples who are in their forties who want to have children. They may have dwindling chances to have a child because aging affects both the male’s sperm or female’s eggs.
“And so if the male in the equation is exposed to extreme heat, then that will just mean fewer chances where they might conceive because of the somewhat lasting harm to sperm production.
“Conceiving is already a low probability event so removing a couple chances means some people won’t be successful,” he said.

The peer-reviewed 2022 study, by Hue University in Vietnam and the University of Hawaii, builds on earlier research by the Glickman Urological and Kidney Institute in Cleveland, Ohio which found that each 1°C increase in testicular temperature leads to a 14 per cent decrease in spermatogenesis (sperm development).
The world has warmed by about 1.2°C, on average since pre-industrial times.

A number of other studies in animals have had similar results. Research by the University of East Anglia on red flour beetles showed “clear evidence” of lower “sperm number and viability” as temperatures increased.
The beetles were subjected to control conditions and a five-day “heatwave”.
“Heatwave conditions -9°C to 13°C above the typical high temperature for five days – damaged male — but not female — reproduction,” according to the study, published in the peer-reviewed journal.

A study in the BMJ Open journal notes that “the effects of climate change and associated extreme weather events…hold the potential to harm sexual health through pathways including elevated exposure to HIV and other sexually transmitted infections (STIs)…and increased sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV)”.

A follow-up study, led by the same academic – Professor Carmen Logie, of the University of Toronto – is currently being edited for publication in a peer-reviewed journal, so the findings cannot be disclosed.

However, Professor Logie was able to share with  the ‘high level’ finding that: “Our review of 83 peer-reviewed articles on all climate change-related weather events, multiple sexual health domains, and all global regions points to the importance of a multi-level approach that looks at the various ways that extreme weather events can directly and indirectly effect sexual health.”

Among other things, this approach should look at “interpersonal impacts – for example increased household stress can lead to increased intimate partner violence – and “intrapersonal impacts,” for example substance use-related coping can disrupt engagement in sexual health care and reduce safer sex efficacy,” she said.

“Pregnant women risk delivering one to two weeks early when it’s hot. That means if your child’s due date is in July, August, or September, climate change will put your child at risk,” according to Professor Barreca, in a stark warning.
A UCLA study he led on suggests that climate change is causing many women to have shorter pregnancies than they would normally, which could pose risks for infant health and child development.
According to research, published in , birth rates were 5 per cent higher on days when the temperature exceeded 32°C (90 degrees Fahrenheit).
And, perhaps more concerning still, births on those days occurred up to two weeks earlier — and 6.1 days earlier on average — than they would have otherwise.
“That’s enough to take somebody from what’s considered to be a pretty healthy pregnancy into a ‘we are somewhat worried’ pregnancy,” said Dr Barreca.
The research, carried out in US, estimated that about one in 400 pregnancies are already being affected as 32°C-plus temperatures accelerate deliveries and shorten pregnancies.
By the year 2100, the study estimates this will have risen to about one out of every 100 births.
The exact link between higher temperatures and shorter pregnancies isn’t totally clear, Dr Barreca said.

One possibility is that the phenomenon is tied to the fact that the level of oxytocin, a hormone involved in the onset of labour and delivery, increases in the body when it’s hot. Another is that heat could be causing pregnant women to experience added stress on their hearts.

Early delivery could cause long-term harm to the affected infants. Previous research has shown that early deliveries are linked to cognitive differences later in childhood, though it’s unclear whether this applies to heat-related early deliveries specifically.

Another study found a direct link between mothers experiencing extreme heat during their third trimester of pregnancy and reduced income for their offspring once they reach adulthood. That might be due in part to earlier deliveries, too.
The effect of climate change on our sex drive is unclear. It may be, for example, that warmer temperatures in winter increase sexual appetite while extreme summer heatwaves reduce it.
Heatwaves have been linked to lethargy and reduced productivity both of which may, in theory, lead to lower sexual activity.

Meanwhile, a study of Norwegian men living in the city of Tromsø, a population exposed to a wide seasonal variation in temperature, found that the “lowest testosterone levels occurred in months with the highest temperatures and longest hours of daylight”.
Testosterone plays a key role in our libido – with less testosterone, you might be less likely to be in the mood.

“The variations in hormone levels were large, with a 31 per cent difference between the lowest and highest monthly mean level of free testosterone,” said the study by the University Hospital of North Norway.
However, the study doesn’t determine whether testosterone levels can fluctuate on a daily basis, potentially as a result of an extreme heatwave.

Meanwhile, a study looking directly at the effect of ambient, or outside – as opposed to indoor – temperature, found that “hot temperatures do not have a significant effect on sexual activity on a given day”.
“We found that temperature does not influence sexual activity on subsequent days either,” according to the research, by the Hungarian Academy of Sciences.

A University of Copenhagen study published in the journal in May found that people are losing about 44 hours of sleep per year due to hotter-than-optimal ambient temperatures, which are also contributing to approximately 11 nights of “short sleep” – meaning less than seven hours per person per year.
There have been a number of studies showing that, perhaps not surprisingly, being tired reduces appetite for sex.

One study, by the University of Michigan, found that “obtaining sufficient sleep is important to the promotion of healthy sexual desire and genital response, as well as the likelihood of engaging in partnered sexual activity”.
There is a growing body of research showing that many people are reconsidering whether they want to have children on environmental grounds.

In some cases this is due to concerns about the associated carbon footprint they would bring to the world – which is far higher than any other single activity, such as driving a car or eating large amounts of red meat.
And in others it is because people don’t want to bring children into a world they worry is in a perilous environmental state.
Choosing not to have children for environmental reasons is something that most people would never consider but the evidence is that it is occupying the population at large far more than it used to.

One study, in the journal Climactic Change, found that 27 to 45 year olds are factoring climate concerns into their reproductive choices. They found 96 per cent were very or extremely concerned about the wellbeing of their potential future children in a climate-changed world.
Meanwhile, 60 per cent were very concerned about their potential offspring’s carbon footprint.
Another study, published in , found that four in 10 young people around the world, including the UK, are hesitant to have children as a result of the climate crisis.

title: England’s wettest week for decade brings hours of sewage discharge and ‘cocktail of pollutants’ in rivers
lead: Campaigners are raising the alarm about the impact this week’s weather is having on rivers, as data show a huge increase in sewage discharges
author: Lucie Heath

body.text: England has endured the joint wettest week for at least a decade, bringing hundreds of hours of sewage discharges and a “cocktail of pollutants” to the country’s rivers
New data released by the Government on Thursday showed that the week leading up to 24 October had the joint highest amount of rainfall in England for at least 10 years as Storm Babet hit the UK.

Central England recorded the most amount of rain during the period (79mm), followed by the East of England (78mm). With a week left of the month, the East of England has already had the third wettest October on record since 1891 and has recorded more than two and a half times the average amount of rain for the region during this period.

Communities in Scotland, the Isle of Wight and the Midlands were among those worst-hit by the storm last week and heavy rain has continued to batter parts of the UK since, with more forecast in the coming days.

Environmental campaigners have raised the alarm about the impact the weather has had on Britain’s rivers, which they say have been hit with a lethal combination of sewage discharges and runoff pollution from roads and farms.
The sheer volume of rain has led to a dramatic increase in the amount of sewage being discharged into rivers,  has learned.

Water companies are permitted to discharge untreated sewage into rivers at times of exceptional rainfall if their pipe networks are overwhelmed. Thames Water is currently the only water company that publishes real time data on when it is discharging sewage.

Data analysed by the Rivers Trust, and shared with , showed that average weekly hours of sewage spills across the Thames Water region were up 60 per cent over the last two weeks compared to the average figure for the year so far.

Data collected by River Mole River Watch showed the local area, which is covered by Thames Water, had seen 424 hours of sewage spills between 18 and 24 October, accounting for more than 10 per cent of the total hours for this year so far.
It is understood Thames Water’s real time data only indicates discharges, rather than confirming them and can therefore sometimes include inaccuracies.
A Thames Water spokesperson said improving the health of rivers was a “key focus” of the company and that they had plans to upgrade more than 250 sewage treatment works and sewers.
It is possible that the sewage discharge figures could be even higher for water companies based in areas such as the Midlands that were worse affected by the storm.
Rebecca Duncan, spokeswoman for conservation charity the Rivers Trust, said flooding was having a “catastrophic effect on river ecosystems”.

Alongside an increase in sewage discharges, she said water running across land “brings pollutants such as agricultural and road runoff with it, accumulating in rivers which are already in an extremely delicate state”.

The River Wye is one of the areas that was subject to pollution from farm run-off this week. Campaigners took to social media to share videos that appeared to show top soil being washed down towards the river bed.

Charles Watson, chairman and founder of River Action UK, who recorded one of the videos, said the soil is “laden with nutrients” that lead to a “cycle of destruction” in rivers such as the Wye, as algae growth restricts oxygen for invertebrates and wildlife.

He accused the Government of failing to enforce rules that are in place for farmers to mitigate the impact of heavy rain on river pollution, particularly as Britain continues to see more extreme weather due to climate change.

“We are now seeing seven or eight storms a year when we might have been seeing one every two or three years. The whole system that has been underinvested, underregulated and underenforced is now coming under intolerable stresses and strain,” he said.

Jo Bradley, director of operations at Stormwater Shepherds, warned rivers in urban areas have also been damaged this week due to the “cocktail of organic pollutants, toxic metals, sediments and tyre wear particles” that are washed off motorways into rivers during periods of rainfall.

A new online map published by the charity Thames21, partly funded by the mayor of London, shows the parts of the city that are worst affected by contaminated rainwater being washed into rivers, with Barking and Dagenham and Barnet being highlighted as the two worst areas.

Ms Bradley said these pollutants are washed into rivers and settle somewhere downstream, having a devastating impact on wildlife, for example by causing creatures to mutate or making them unable to reproduce.

Appalling scenes coming in today from River Wye catchment 😥Topsoil from fields left bare to autumn/winter storms – laden with nutrients from dumped manure by valley’s massive intensive 🐓 industry – just freely running off into the river system. How to destroy an ecosystem 😖 pic.twitter.com/fibowTOmCI
It comes as scientists warn that the UK is likely to see an increase in events such as Storm Babet as a result of climate change.

Climate scientist Dr Friederike Otto told  earlier this week that extreme storms have become twice as likely in the UK since the pre-industrial era and have become 10 to 20 per cent more intense in terms of rainfall.

Ms Duncan said: “We are already seeing an increase in extreme weather events as a result of climate change and our infrastructure – engineered and nature-based – is not set to be able to cope with these pressures. As a sector and a country, we must address this problem so we are more resilient to increasing flood risk and minimise the impacts on people and wildlife alike.”

A Defra spokesperson said: “The recent heavy rain and the resulting run off highlights the importance of Our Plan for Water, which sets out more investment, stronger regulation and tougher enforcement to tackle pollution and clean up our waters.

“We are also committed to tackling agricultural pollution. We have set a new legally binding target to reduce nitrogen, phosphorus, and sediment from agriculture entering our waterways, while also funding 4000 water quality farm inspections a year and doubling the funding to our Catchment Sensitive Farming scheme to ensure farmers can receive free advice on reducing water pollution.”

An Environment Agency spokesperson said because the world is “already seeing the impacts of climate change, including flooding”, urgent action is needed to adapt to the “impacts” of it “at the same time as reducing emissions”.

They added: “When we experience heavy rainfall, this can cause pollution by washing contaminants from agricultural land and causing sewers to overflow into our rivers. We are working closely with the agricultural sector and water industry to put measures in place to minimise the impact of these events on our rivers to ensure nature can flourish.

The spokesperson also claimed the organisations flood defences have meant 374,000 homes are better protected since 2015 – and is also planning a record £5.2bn investment to “better protect hundreds of thousands of more properties”.

A Defra Spokesperson said “the recent heavy rain” and the “resulting run off highlights the importance of its ‘Plan for Water’ which sets out more investment, stronger regulation and tougher enforcement to tackle pollution and clean up our waters.

They said: “We are also committed to tackling agricultural pollution. We have set a new legally binding target to reduce nitrogen, phosphorus, and sediment from agriculture entering our waterways, while also funding 4000 water quality farm inspections a year and doubling the funding to our Catchment Sensitive Farming scheme to ensure farmers can receive free advice on reducing water pollution.”

title: Cumbria and Cornwall to miss out on clean river bathing spaces following new Defra rules
lead: Some local river groups are having to withdraw applications for official bathing status after Defra introduced new rules on the number of bathers
author: Lucie Heath

body.text: Hopes of cleaning up polluted rivers by making them official bathing spaces have been abandoned in several locations across England, with campaigners blaming a Government rule change.

Rivers in Cornwall and Cumbria no longer meet the criteria to apply for the status after the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) introduced a requirement for a minimum number of swimmers to visit the waterway. It means the rivers will miss out on additional checks to rid them of pollution.
Campaigners in Cumbria said the Government change made it “probably impossible for any upland river to achieve bathing status”.
Environmental groups across the country have been applying to Defra to have their local river recognised as an official bathing space as part of efforts to monitor water quality and reduce pollution.

While people can still swim in unofficial bathing spaces, the designation forces the Environment Agency to carry out additional tests on bacteria levels and will investigate when the water quality does not meet regulatory standards.

Achieving bathing status does not automatically mean the water will be cleaned up, however campaigners hope achieving the status will bring attention to the plight of their river and allow swimmers to make informed decisions over when to enter the water.
The UK has more than 600 designated bathing water sites, however most of these are coastal and only three are located within rivers.
Last year, at least nine sites on English rivers were known to have submitted applications to Defra, but just one site, on the River Deben in Suffolk, was accepted. The rest were rejected.

Next Tuesday is the annual deadline for applications for new sites but Defra’s updated rules, introduced in July, mean several campaigners have been left unable to submit applications for their river.

The rules say applicants must record 100 bathers using the space on at least two days within the bathing season, which runs from May to September and that all sites must have a toilet facility within 500m.

Campaigners have criticised the Government for introducing the new rules in July, in the middle of the bathing season, meaning they had to scramble to carry out new surveys on visitors in the second half of the summer.
Kirsty Davies from Surfers Against Sewage, which is supporting local groups in submitting applications, said eight communities have been forced to stop their application due to the new criteria.
She said: “We believe that a minimum of 100 bathers a day is far too many, as it doesn’t recognise the diversity of sites, how they’re used, or the ecological impact of this scale of water use.

“These harsh criteria will mean many well-loved waterways are not able to progress through Defra’s bathing water designation process, losing the opportunity for crucial monitoring, essential to improve water quality and provide transparency to water users.”
One of the groups that has withdrawn their application is the Clean River Kent Campaign, which was hoping to gain bathing water status for a site in Staveley, Cumbria.

Group co-founder Isobel Stoddart said: “When we applied in 2022, there was nothing in the guidelines that said that a bathing site had to attract at least 100 people for a minimum of two days during the bathing season.”

She said the new guidelines did not recognise the different ways rivers are used to lakes and coastal areas, making it “very challenging and probably impossible for any upland river to achieve bathing status”.

“People will dip, paddle, swim at different times of the day, at lots of locations along the length of a river. And there will be other recreational users such as canoeists, kayakers, anglers that also encounter the water that are not being taken into account,” she said.
A campaign group based in Calstock, on the River Tamar in Cornwall, has also decided not to apply for status this year.

Local Parish Councillor Richard Newton-Chance said the new rules around bathing numbers have “pretty much shut it down” as he said there “aren’t going to be that many beaches in Cornwall that can meet that, let alone rivers”.

While the new rules are a setback for Surfers Against Sewage’s campaign to see 200 sites on rivers achieve bathing status by 2030, Ms Davies said around 20 sites have been able to submit applications this year, including in Lancashire and Oxfordshire

Some, like the River Dee, which flows from Bala to Chester, are applying despite failing to meet the 100 bather criteria, while others were able to record the numbers with the help of the September heatwave.
Defra has been approached for comment.

A Defra spokesperson said: “We encourage applications and provide guidance to help people understand the criteria that must be met, including the need to show that the site is regularly used by sufficient numbers of bathers.

“The recently updated guidance makes applying for our bathing water designations clearer and more streamlined for applicants. Groups have until the end of October to submit their applications this year.”

title: Avoiding alcohol and staying indoors: The miserable future of 40°C summers
lead: With the Met Office warning of more heatwaves in the future, new research sets out what experts call the ‘many and varied ways that extreme heat harms our physical and mental health’
author: Tom Bawden

body.text: Last year’s 40°C heatwave has given people in the UK a glimpse into the future – suggesting that, for many, summers will often mean avoiding alcohol and staying indoors.

A study of people’s behaviour in July 2022, when temperatures exceeded 40°C in the UK for the first time, revealed widespread changes in everything from clothing, diet and lifestyle to attending church or going to the supermarket during that time.

The period could go down in history as the time the UK saw the start of a widespread shift in attitude to hot weather, researchers say – in which many people stopped automatically seeing heat as a “good thing” and started to ask whether it may be a “bad thing”.

“We can see a shift in how people are thinking about hot weather as their experience of extreme heat grows – perceptions are shifting,” Louise King, of the Centre for Climate Change and Social Transformations at Bath University, told.
“Hot weather has typically been viewed positively in the UK but people are starting to experience the negative impacts of extreme heat on their everyday lives.

“We found that the 2022 heatwave, for many, was the first time they had experienced extreme heat in the UK for a prolonged period. There was a shift, for some, from it being merely an inconvenience to having more significant impacts on their lives – for example, on their sleep, work and caring for relatives and pets.”
“They also reported feeling lethargic and finding it hard to do normal activities, difficulty concentrating and being productive in their working lives,” Dr King added.

Working with University of Bath colleague Christina Demski, her findings are drawn from a nationally-representative survey of 1,500 people – carried out with the University of East London – along with interviews conducted with 40 others and four workshops involving 25 people.

Their findings are being used as part of an inquiry on how well-prepared UK homes are for rising temperatures by the Environmental Audit Committee, a cross-party group of MPs looking at the effectiveness of the government’s green policies.
The study reveals that during the heatwave of 2022, the nation ate, drank and dressed quite differently – stayed indoors a lot more and did far fewer activities.
77 per cent wore different clothing (light coloured and fabric e.g. linen, cotton)
46 per cent avoided alcohol
21 per cent left home to visit air-conditioned buildings, such as supermarkets, shopping malls and churches
76 per cent stuck to cold food and cold fluids
23 per cent put out an outdoor paddling pool or cool hot tub
When outside, 63 per cent stayed in the shade
62 per cent kept curtains, blinds and windows open at night. And 58 per cent kept them closed during the day.
51 per cent took a shower or bath more often
47 per cent stayed indoors during the day
47 per cent avoided physical activity
19 per cent left home to visit cooler coastal and rural areas
43 per cent moved to a cool room in the home.
“I was sat behind a laptop struggling to get through work, I couldn’t think in the heat, counting down the hours until I finished. It felt like suffering in a way.”
“I felt hot, sweaty, uncomfortable, irritated, stressed, unable to concentrate, tired. It was hard to work from home because I was working from home at that time and I was very frustrated.”
“It was just so hot. And there was just no air, and you just feel like you can’t cool yourself down. And it kind of made me feel like claustrophobic.”
“It was isolating, I couldn’t really go out like normal. Just stuck in the house with all the curtains shut. Pretty depressing really.”
“It was just unbearable. You just couldn’t sleep, so therefore you’re tired. You’re just in a circle, and you can’t get out of it.”
The research also shows that many people experienced both physical and mental health impacts related to the summer 2022 heatwave.

Some 55 per cent of those surveyed reported some experience of heat-related health conditions, such as heat stroke, dehydration, or exacerbation of existing health issues including cardiovascular or pulmonary conditions, diabetes and renal disease.

Some people described collapsing during the heatwave, suffering from heat stress and heat stroke, which is of particular concern within vulnerable groups – over-65s, young children and those with underlying health conditions.
The research also found that the heatwave affected people’s mental health.
People reported a decline in cognitive function – attention and memory – which reduced productivity as well as increased anxiety and stress.
Low mood, loss of social networks and poor quality sleep were other common issues.
Meanwhile, low motivation and lethargy were reported across diverse age groups with a decrease in physical and social activities due to low energy or inhospitable outdoor settings.

Attempts to cope with extreme heat, such as closing windows and curtains, may have helped keep the temperature down but they were also found to increase feelings of isolation and loneliness in some participants.
Experts from climate change organisations said the findings gave an unpleasant insight into the future.

“Worryingly, I think we are going to see a lot more of the problems this research highlights as heatwaves become more frequent thanks to climate change,” said Roger Harding, director of climate change charity Round Our Way.

“It is those of us who are stuck in smaller cramped flats or houses, or who are getting on a bit, who are the most at risk of overheating. We all deserve to be able to live and work in reasonable temperatures, but with increasing heatwaves like we saw last year that simply isn’t possible for growing numbers of people.
“We urgently need politicians better to protect us from the effects of climate change and do more to tackle it in the first place.”

Gareth Redmond-King, of the research group Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit, said: “The intense heat of summer of 2022 was an unwelcome glimpse into our future, with the Met Office warning that 40°C will become commonplace in future decades if we continue as we are. This research shows the many and varied ways that extreme heat harms our physical and mental health.”

title: Avian flu might not be as bad for British birds this year – here’s why
lead: A fall in cases, increased immunity, changes in the virus and scientific breakthroughs all give cause for hope – but scientists have warned against complacency
author: Tom Bawden

body.text: This winter’s avian flu season is showing signs of being less severe than it was last year, although there is no room for complacency, scientists have said.
While there were 58 confirmed outbreaks of avian flu in poultry in the UK in the first twenty days of October last year, there have been none in the same period this year.
October is a crucial time in the bird flu season, being when cases typically start to rise as many migratory birds come to the UK.

Scientists have also found the first evidence that sea birds are starting to develop immunity to flu. Thirty per cent of Northern gannets and 50 per cent of Shags analysed by researchers have antibodies from previous infections that could help protect them against the virus in the future.

The fact that wild birds are starting to build immunity is not hugely surprising but this is the most comprehensive evidence so far that this is happening. And it is the first time it has been demonstrated in sea birds specifically, according to the research consortium lead by the Animal Plant Health Agency.
There is considerable cross-infection between wild and farm birds and so any immunity in one group would help reduce cases among both.

In addition, there are signs that the main bird flu virus, HN51, is mutating to become less severe. However, scientists said more research is need to be sure and that it remained unclear how much this would affect infections and deaths this year.
“The virus seems to have changed again,” said Professor Paul Digard, of Edinburgh University’s Roslin Institute.
“It seems to have gone back back to being more like the precursor, H5N8 virus, which wasn’t such a problem. So it’s a question of waiting and seeing.
“Is that the virus that we’re going to have kicking around in the winter? Or are we going to see more of the original H5N1 strains coming back?”

Any reduction in bird flu cases is also good for humans. Although it has been extremely rare for a person to be infected by avian flu, lower numbers of cases in birds the lower the risk that the virus can mutate into one that can infect and pass between people.
The UK’s Chief Veterinary Officer, Christine Middlemiss, said the UK was actively considering vaccinations for some poultry, although no decision has been made yet.
“We have set up a joint government industry task force on vaccination – inside, outside, turkeys, chickens, ducks, geese, many different species,” she said.

“France are vaccinating ducks, particularly around their foie gras industry. We are not at a decision yet, if we would vaccinate and what sector vaccination would be most appropriate for. But we are very much exploring it” she added.
Although it’s unclear which, if any, birds would be vaccinated, the fact that jabs are being discussed raises hopes that the immunity of poultry could be boosted.
There have also been developments in gene editing that show promise in making chickens resistant to bird flu.
Earlier this month, UK scientists successfully gene edited a group of birds to fully withstand the virus with no notable side effects.
This the first time gene editing has been shown to reduce the risk of a flu infection, with chickens given complete resistance to avian flu when three of their genes were edited.

The success of the technique, known as CRISPR/Cas9, in chickens paves the way to significantly reduce the spread of avian flu from the wild into farmed poultry. This, in turn, would reduce infections in all kinds of birds, which help perpetuate the virus by passing it between different groups.
Experts said the various developments raised hopes that bird flu could be less bad this year although they remained cautious at this stage.

Professor James Wood, infectious disease epidemiologist at the University of Cambridge, said there “is really good news in relation to how the risks may be playing out but it is too early to be sure about anything”.
Professor Ian Brown, Head of Virology at the Animal and Plant Health Agency (APHA), said: “At the moment, there are encouraging signs but we can’t drop our guard.

“We’re not raising the flags. We’re in a very uncertain window at the moment. And we certainly wouldn’t be advocating any dropping of biosecurity standards, far from it. Because this is a very unpredictable virus.”
The last two years have been particularly bad for bird flu.

An estimated 2.8 million farmed birds – including chickens, ducks, turkeys, geese, pigeon, partridge, quail, guinea fowl and pheasants – were culled in the UK last year. More than 50,000 wild birds are estimated to have died in the UK between October 2021 and April 2023.

title: Smart water meters set to be delayed as water companies fail to spend green funding
lead: Water companies were given permission to invest £793m on green projects after the pandemic, but are currently behind the spending target
author: Lucie Heath

body.text: Major water infrastructure projects, including the rollout of hundreds of thousands of smart meters, are facing delays as water companies struggle to spend funding they were allocated to help with the UK’s “green recovery” from the pandemic.

Water companies are falling behind on schemes including the replacement of lead pipes and the installation of smart meters, with one company yet to install a single smart meter out of a target of 204,700 by 2025.

In 2021, the water regulator Ofwat gave five water companies permission to invest a collective £793m by 2025 on projects to support the country’s green economic recovery following the Covid-19 pandemic.
However, in an update published late last month, the regulator confirmed that water companies had spent just 10 per cent of this funding by March 2023.
While Ofwat said it expects spend to increase significantly in the final two years of the programme, it noted that all five water companies have currently spent less than their original forecasts.
This includes Thames Water, which by the end of 2022-23 had spent only £1m out of the £72m it has been allocated to install 204,700 smart meters in customers’ homes.
According to Ofwat, the water companies had spent the following amounts by the end of March 2023 (the deadline for spend is March 2025):

In its latest annual report, the struggling water company admitted it had failed to install a single smart meter by March 2023. It’s understood the firm has installed more than 15,000 meter boxes as part of its preparatory work.

A spokesperson for Thames Water told  its ability to recover the full £72m from Ofwat was dependent on its ability to deliver at least 98% of its leakage performance commitment, which it failed to do last year due to “the impact of drought and freeze-thaw events”.

They said: “We asked Ofwat to review the Green Economic Recovery funding conditions in response to these challenges, but our request was recently declined. We are carefully reviewing our next steps and remain committed to driving down leakage and encouraging our customers to use water wisely.”
The firm said it has installed almost one million smart meters in customers’ homes as part of a wider rollout of the technology.

South West Water has also faced delays as part of its plan to install 76,000 smart meters by 2025, having installed just 930 to date. However, the firm insists the project is still on track to be completed by 2025.
A separate project to upgrade the Knapp Mill water treatment works in Christchurch, which was first built in 1897, is currently facing delays due to a planning challenge from Natural England.
Other projects, including schemes to improve river water quality and investigate sewage discharges, are currently on schedule.
With an allocation of £565m, Severn Trent has received the majority of the green funding from Ofwat and has currently spent £67m (12 per cent).

While a number of its projects are currently delivering on target, the company has reduced the scope of a £75m project to replace a maximum of 26,000 lead pipes in Coventry and Bomere Heath, and is now forecasting it will deliver 13,000 by the 2025 deadline.

Chris Wand, Severn Trent Green Recovery programme director said: “We’re on track, and in some cases accelerating work that will bring benefits and improvements to the communities we serve as we deliver what is the biggest green economic recovery programme in the sector.”
A spokesperson for United Utilities said it was currently on track to deliver all of its Green Recovery projects despite having spent less than 5 per cent of its allocated £64m by March 2023.
However, in its latest annual report the firm admitted it was unlikely to meet targets on projects to restore peatland and improve river water quality before 2025.
Meanwhile, South Staff Water, which has received the smallest allocation from Ofwat to deliver upgrades to a water treatment plant appears to be on track to deliver by 2025.

The delays to the green programmes raise fresh questions over water companies’ ability to carry out large infrastructure projects as they pledge to invest £96bn by 2030 to improve Britain’s water and sewage network.
It comes after Ofwat found that water companies spent just 73 per cent of the approximately £7bn in funding they were allocated to invest in infrastructure between 2020 to 2023.

At the end of September seven water companies, including Thames Water and Southern Water, were ordered to cut a collective £114m from customers’ bills after failing to meet key targets on tackling pollution, leakage and supply interruptions.

title: Revealed: World’s CO2 emissions set to rise by about 1 per cent to new record in 2023
lead: Scientists are dismayed by the figures as CO₂ emissions need to fall rapidly and sharply to avoid runaway climate change
author: Tom Bawden

body.text: The world’s CO₂ emissions are forecast to rise by about 1 per cent to a new record this year, according to a key analysis.

The estimate has alarmed scientists because the amount of carbon dioxide pumped into the atmosphere needs to fall quickly and sharply if the planet is to have any hope of avoiding runaway climate change, they say.

After dipping early in the pandemic for the first time in decades, the world’s total carbon dioxide emissions – generated by everything from cars, planes and other forms of transport to electricity and heating, manufacturing and food – are clearly rising again.
This has dismayed, if not surprised, the scientist behind the analysis.

“It is more disappointing that fossil CO₂ emissions continue to grow rather than surprising,” said Glenn Peters, of the Global Carbon Project and Centre for International Climate Research (CICERO) in Norway, who made the forecast.

“To be consistent with ambiguous climate targets laid out in the Paris Agreement, global fossil CO₂ emissions would need to decline in excess of 5 per cent per year. This is just not happening. Each year, that emissions keep rising makes it even harder to reach the Paris targets and locks the world into even more climate impacts,” he told .

The Paris Agreement saw 196 countries signing up to a legally binding treaty to hold “the increase in the global average temperature to well below 2°C above pre-industrial levels” and pursue efforts “to limit the temperature increase to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels.”

Any temperature increase above 2°C would result in devastating consequences around much of the world as extreme weather such as ferocious storms, intense heatwaves and prolonged droughts became increasingly common, scientists warn.
The Global Carbon Projects is led by Exeter University and involves more than 100 scientists from 18 countries. Its assessments carry considerable weight among scientists and policymakers.
The group will present its latest emissions estimate for the year to the COP28 climate change summit in Dubai in December.

Dr Peters said the estimate given at the summit may change slightly from his current 1 per cent estimate as the group assesses the latest data – although it is unlikely to be altered greatly, if at all.
It will probably be between 0.5 per cent and 1.5 per cent and almost certainly between 0 and 2 per cent, Dr Peters said.
“There is little evidence emissions will go down, little evidence it will grow remarkably high,” he said.

Tom Crowther, Professor of Ecology at ETH Zürich University in Switzerland, who was not involved in the research, said: “I am surprised, and devastated by this forecast. I had hoped that the growth of renewable energy might have begun to slow the rate of fossil fuel emissions, but this suggests that dream is entirely wrong.”

“It is painful to think that we have failed to slow our fossil fuel emissions, but it is unthinkable to imagine that they could even be increasing. Given the amount of suffering we know this will cause around the world, it is hard to imagine how we could knowingly let this happen.

“If we want to protect life on this planet, this devastation just has to stop,” added Professor Crowther, who is co-chair of the advisory board for the United Nations Decade on Ecosystem Restoration, which aims to reverse the degradation of ecosystems around the world.

Professor Myles Allen, the Oxford University scientist who founded the Climate Prediction project, the world’s largest climate modelling experiment, said: “It has become clear that the world won’t stop using fossil fuels in time”.

“One day, we will stop using fossil fuels. I don’t know when that day will be, but I’m sure if we carry on dumping all the CO₂ generated by the fossil fuels we still use into the atmosphere, it will be too late, certainly to meet Paris Agreement goals,” he said.

The Global Carbon Budget did not estimate UK emissions for 2023. Separate research shows that UK CO₂ emissions have come down significantly in recent years – although nowhere near enough to meet the country’s legally-binding target of becoming net zero by 2050, experts say.
CO₂ emissions in the UK are estimated to have decreased by 2.4 per cent in 2022, according to government figures – with no 2023 estimate yet available.

Last week, the government’s climate change advisor, the Climate Change Committee, warned that Rishi Sunak’s recent reversals on key climate policies to phase out gas boilers and petrol and diesel vehicles have damaged the UK’s ability to meet its carbon-cutting goals.
Dr Peters based his calculations on data that the International Energy Agency (IEA) has published publicly, which gives estimates for the growth in coal, oil, and gas for 2023.
He then used Global Carbon Budget figures for CO₂ emissions by fossil fuel type to project forward coal, oil, gas, and cement emissions to 2023.

title: The evidence that shows climate change is already impacting our bills, homes, health and businesses
lead: i canvassed leading researchers’ opinions and looked at key reports into the impacts climate change is having – this is what we found
author: Tom Bawden

body.text: Climate change is already affecting the everyday lives of British people in profound ways – from food and the weather to our health and leisure activities, an analysis has found.

We canvassed the opinions of leading researchers and institutions and combed through key reports on the effects of global warming – and they have painted a picture of nation that is already going about things differently in all sorts of ways.

“The UK’s first 40°C day, in summer 2022, was the clearest indication that climate change has arrived in this country,” said Richard Millar, head of adaptation at the Climate Change Committee, the Government’s official climate change adviser.
“Last year’s record-breaking temperatures brought unprecedented numbers of heat-related deaths, wildfire incidents and significant infrastructure disruption.

“These, and impacts from other events, highlight the UK’s critical exposure and vulnerability to extreme weather even today. Climate change means many weather extremes driving these impacts will continue to get worse for several decades at least,” he said.
Mark Maslin, a professor at University College London, with a keen interest in how people’s lives are affected by global warming, has also noticed significant changes.
“I have observed lots and lots of adaptations everywhere. People are becoming much more focused on hydration, for example, and you increasingly see people taking water with them on the Tube.

“A lot of people are changing their work pattern to make sure that during the hottest part of the year they are either working from home,  if it’s cool enough, or they’re working at work because of the air conditioning. And people try to go in earlier to make sure don’t have extreme heat on their journey,” added Professor Maslin, a member of the Climate Crisis Advisory Group (CCAG).
Meanwhile, 23 per cent of people in the UK say “climate change has already had an impact on me personally”, according to a survey of 2,064 conducted in May for the National Trust.
Here are some of the ways in which life in the UK is already being affected.

Climate change is clearly affecting the nation’s mental health. A 2021 paper by Imperial College London concluded that there “is clear evidence of a relationship between higher temperatures and increased suicides” and “clear evidence for severe distress following extreme weather events”.

It said: “The available evidence suggests that climate change has a significant and multi-faceted impact on mental health and emotional wellbeing. Data show that there is a clear relationship between experiencing the effects of climate change – such as rising temperatures or more frequent and severe extreme weather events – and worsening mental health, even resulting in more suicides,” according to the paper.
It goes on to give examples of how climate change can impact our mental health.

“Experiencing the effects of climate change first-hand, for example by a flooding event, directly raises the risk of experiencing post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), depression or low mood, and extreme distress.

“People with mental illness are also more vulnerable to impacts of the changing climate, such as high temperatures, which worsen their physical as well as mental health. Damage to infrastructure and supply chains arising from climate change impacts also risk disrupting the provision of mental healthcare,” it adds.
There is good evidence that high temperatures can increase the risk of injury, particularly in children.

A review of existing scientific studies,  published in the British Medical Journal found that the increased injury risk varied between 0.4 per cent and 5.3 per cent for every 1°C increase from a moderate temperature.

“Our review confirms that hot weather can increase the risk of unintentional injuries and accidents,” wrote report author Eveline Otte Im kampe, of London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, in the study.
-Heat typically leads to a reduction in work intensity or an increase in breaks, according to a report prepared for the Climate Change Committee.

– A study focused on the US, by the National Bureau of Economic Research in Boston of found that average productivity in the US on individual days declines roughly 1.7 per cent for each 1°C  increase in daily average temperature above 15°C.

-Meanwhile, another study by the Grantham Research Institute suggests of the UK suggests that 2°C warming trajectory (which the world is currently surpassing) could cost around 0.4 per cent of economic output for London in a warm year due to a reduction in productivity.

Exposure to heat also slows the development of cognitive skill development in students, according to research which has shown that hotter school days prior to tests have resulted in lower test outcomes.
Another study by the National Bereau of Economic Research found that without air conditioning, each 0.6°C increase in school year temperature reduces the amount learned that year by one percent.
And another found that taking an exam on a 32°C day leads to around an 10 per cent lower likelihood of passing compared to a 22°C day.
More than 4,500 people died in England in 2022 due to high temperatures, the largest figure on record, with the number of heat-related deaths increasing over recent years, the ONS said last month.
Between 1988 and 2022, nearly 52,000 deaths associated with the hottest days were recorded in England, with a third of them occurring since 2016, data from the Office for National Statistics shows.
More than 2,000 people died in Wales due to the warm temperatures over the same period.
While heat-related deaths in the UK hit a record last year, the ONS pointed out that they have been at significantly elevated levels for some years.

It noted that from 2016 to 2021, deaths were above average in every hot spell – defined as days when the average temperature is greater than 20°C in central England – and 9.3 per cent higher on average.
“Across the 2016 to 2021 ‘heat-periods’, excess deaths ranged from 3.0 per cent (2 to 9 August 2018) to 27.7 per cent (6 to 9 September 2021)” above average,” the ONS said.

A government study found that overheating was found to reduce good sleep by one or two hours – or cause an equivalent reduction in sleep quality – although considerable variation across the population is expected.

Another government study estimated that relative to sleeping seven to nine hours, “productivity loss” was estimated to be 3.7 working days per year if sleeping six to seven hours and six working days if sleeping  less than six hours.
UK homes are starting to change, with more people buying fans, installing air conditioning and shutters and painting external walls white, scientists say.
But most households are still very unprepared for the new era of high temperatures, studies have shown.

Some 4.6 million English bedrooms – one in five households – and 3.6 million living rooms (15 per cent) overheat in the hot weather, according to a study by Loughborough University last year in partnership with the BRE (Building Research Establishment).
Meanwhile, a study by London South Bank University in 2018 found maximum internal temperatures of almost 50°C in a London office building converted to apartments, when they had no shading.

Furthermore, research by the University of Bath, presented to the Environment Audit Committee in August as part of a review into UK household preparedness for climate change, concludes: “Many of the coping solutions reported by respondents in our research would likely prove insufficient in the face of sustained heatwaves”.
Overheating is also regularly recorded in other building types such as hospitals, care homes and schools occupied by some of the most vulnerable people to heat-health impacts.
Overheating is defined as occurring where the daily maximum temperature exceeded 26˚C in a ward or clinical area.

The number of overheating incidents in clinical areas reported by NHS trusts has almost doubled over the past five years, with directors saying ageing estates make them vulnerable to extreme weather events.
And in , a survey of teachers found that 90 per cent reported taking additional measures to reduce classroom temperature, including purchasing portable air conditioners.

Schools in London have also reported that concentration levels of children had been affected due to high temperatures in recent years, with the annual period for public examinations being one of the hottest parts of the year.
There is also increasing evidence of overheating in  and other care settings.

Meanwhile, A HM Inspectorate of Prisons’ report included concerns from during inspections which included difficulty of breathing, the heating in cells being continuously on, high ambient temperatures in cells and limited oxygen.

A report on food prices in 2022 by the Energy & Climate Intelligence Unit research group found that extra costs relating to climate change added £170 a year to the average UK household food bill – representing 37 per cent of food inflation.
One example of how this is translating into increased meal prices is with Britain’s favourite curry.

The cost of making a chicken tikka masala has rocketed by 17 per cent in a year – and it’s largely the fault of climate change, according to a separate new analysis, by ECIU for the climate change charity Round Our Way.

This finds that the cost to an average family of four of producing ‘the nation’s favourite dish’ has shot up by £3.67 in the past year as prices of key ingredients have jumped. Supermarket canned tomato prices has risen by 32 per cent over the period, while onions are up 26 per cent and cooking oil by 38 per cent.

British people barbecued 86 million times last summer about 7 per cent more times than they did before the pandemic and continuing “a new normal” level of elevated bbq consumption, according to the latest figures from the Agriculture and Horticulture Development Board (AHDB).
The board puts a large part of this down to changes in our lifestyles as a result of the pandemic – but it comes against a backdrop of warming temperatures that make barbecueing a more viable option.
“Despite living without restrictions, we continue to work differently than before, which keeps us in the home more and cuts back on out-of-home occasions,” a spokesperson for the board said.
However, part of the reason could be rising temperatures, experts said – although extreme temperatures may be considered too hot.

As the board spokesperson noted: “The latter part of summer saw a rise in temperatures which was matched by a spike in BBQ occasions in August, however the same did not happen for the record temperatures in July”

A report from the government’s climate change advisor, Committee on Climate Change, finds that, according to UK businesses, “extreme weather is already a significant source of supply chain disruption”
The study gave UK wheat yields as an example.

Wheat yields in 2020 (9.7 million tonnes) were the lowest since 1981, with the value of wheat output falling by £526m or 25 per cent compared to the average for 2016 to 2019. This was due to unusually poor weather conditions at critical points of crop production: very wet weather for preparing the soil and sowing, too dry in the spring when the crops should have established, and bad weather for harvesting.

There is not yet enough data to know how the number of football matches cancelled in the UK due to climate change-induced extreme weather has changed over time, but there is a growing body of anecdotal evidence that the situation is getting worse.
At the same time, there are many scientific studies saying that extreme weather is increasing – and that this is as a result of climate change.
A 2021 study from energy company Utilita estimates there are 40,000 amateur football teams in the UK, which have an average of 5.4 games postponed or cancelled a year.

And another study, by the Sport and Recreation Alliance, found that more than a third of grassroots teams lose two to three months of playing time a season due to the weather. And the situation has deteriorated since then, experts say.

“Today, we’re witnessing undeniable impacts of climate change on football, with the grassroots and women’s game being impacted the most. And things are getting worse,” said Elliot Arthur-Worsop, founder of Football For Future, a charity set up to make football sustainable that has worked with Tottenham Hotspur, Chelsea FC, and Fifa, the international governing body of football.
One of the most obvious ways in which the UK is changing is in the steps that are being taken by large numbers of the British public to cut their greenhouse gas emissions.
These include eating less meat, buying an electric vehicle, ditching their gas boiler, cycling more, using public transport, flying less and switching to a green energy  supplier.
Polling by the Met Office in March showed that more than half the British public are consciously making low-carbon choices, with nearly two-thirds wanting to do more.

In a YouGov survey, a representative sample of the British public was asked about the action they are taking to reduce their carbon footprint and their perceptions as to whether people in the UK are doing enough to reduce their carbon footprint.
The data show 59 per cent of those surveyed are making conscious decisions to live a low-carbon lifestyle, including 17 per cent who make these decisions even when it is inconvenient for them.
When asked if people in the UK are doing enough to lower their carbon footprints, nearly two-thirds of respondents said we should be doing more.

“Everyone can see that we’re experiencing frequent extreme weather… the UK public are already engaged in reducing their carbon footprints and many people indicate they want to do more,” said Professor Jason Lowe, Head of Climate Services at the Met Office.

“The only way we are going to avoid the very worst impacts from climate change is by lowering our emissions of greenhouse gases, and quickly. But we also need to adapt our lifestyles and the world around us to cope with the impacts from the climate change we’re already committed to.”

Dr Camilla Mathison, lead on Climate Mitigation Science at the Met Office, said: “Even small changes to daily life make a big difference when it comes to your carbon footprint. A simple example is personal travel, by walking or cycling short journeys you are not only saving CO emissions but also improving air quality and improving your personal health.”

title: Chicken tikka masala price soars due to climate change
lead: The cost of the ingredients for a chicken tikka masala has soared by 37 per cent in two years – and climate change is largely to blame
author: Tom Bawden

body.text: The cost to make Britain’s favourite curry, the chicken tikka masala, has rocketed by 17 per cent in the past year – and it’s largely the fault of of climate change.

One of the UK’s most loved dishes, and according to one theory, said to have been created by Glaswegian chef Ali Ahmed Aslam in his Indian restaurant in Scotland in the 70s, it combines pan-fried chicken marinated in a spice-laden yogurt base with a creamy tomato curry.

The key ingredients have helped it become a firm favourite among British curry lovers – but they are also most vulnerable to the effects of a changing climate, according to new analysis for UK climate change charity Round Our Way.
Supermarket canned tomato prices have risen by 32 per cent in the past year, while onions are up 26 per cent and cooking oil by 38 per cent.
The total cost to make the dish from scratch now stands at £25.81, as the ingredients needed have risen by £6.94, or 37 per cent – since 2021, the analysis finds.
Some ingredients in these calculations, such as butter and olive oil, probably won’t be used up in a single meal while others, such as canned tomatoes and chicken, probably will be.
So there may well be some ingredients left over after the family has made a curry but that is the cost of buying the ingredients needed to make one from scratch, the researchers said.
“Many of us are having to cut back on takeaways and now even a home-cooked curry is rocketing in price, thanks to climate change’s impact on the weather,” said Roger Harding, Round Our Way director.
Rising energy prices are a significant driver of the increase of this dish – and the high rate of food inflation generally.

But the additional costs of dishes such as chicken tikka masala are also largely a direct result of climate change, which is estimated to be responsible for about a third of the price increase, according to the Energy & Climate Intelligence Unit (ECIU) research group which carried out the analysis on official ONS data.
These additional costs come from increased heatwaves, droughts, storms and rainfall that are happening as a result of climate change – both at home and abroad.
These reduce yields, destroy crops and affect livestock health which, in turn, leads to supply shortages and pushes up prices.
Researchers warned that prices will continue to rise unless more is done to tackle the climate crisis.
Tom Lancaster, land analyst at ECIU, said: “British people love a curry, but climate change is forcing us to fork out more for one of our nation’s favourite dishes.

“With climate-driven extreme weather wrecking harvests in the UK last year, and around the world this summer, we can expect to pay more for our weekly curry in the future unless we do more to reach net zero emissions, as an essential step to preventing the worst impacts of climate change.”
Floods and heatwaves are the biggest weather events responsible for driving up the cost of curry ingredients. Essentials hit include tomatoes, peppers, onions, rice and cooking oil.

Drought in 2022 reduced UK onion yields by 30 per cent, while extreme weather in North Africa and Southern Europe in early 2023 led to shortages and price increases for tomatoes and peppers, Mr Lancaster said.
Meanwhile, unpredictable weather is threatening supplies of rice in south and south-east Asia including in India, which banned exports of basmati rice in July after damage to crops from heavy rain.
Mr Lancaster added: “We know that climate change has had a major impact on food prices this year and last.

“If the ingredients for a chicken tikka are representative of other foods, it is likely that climate change accounts for around a third of the price increases that shoppers have seen since the beginning of 2022.”

Last year a separate report from ECIU on food prices in 2022 found that extra costs relating to climate change added £170 a year to the average UK household food bill – representing 37 per cent of food inflation.

Professor Wyn Morgan, University of Sheffield, and one of the authors of that report said: “The analysis underpins how the UK food system as a whole is exposed to global climate change and events on world markets and points to the importance of action to promote a more resilient food and agricultural sector in the UK.”

Nicky Amos, public affairs chair of the National Federation of Women’s Institutes, added: “Although it may not say climate change on the till receipt, it’s definitely showing up on our shopping bills.”

And Professor Corinna Hawkes, director of the centre for food policy, at City, University of London, said: “This important piece of analysis is one of the first times we have seen how important climate change is in influencing food prices. Climate change is not a distant threat, but affects the money we all have in our pockets every day.”

title: ‘Firesale’ of HS2 land could be delayed as Rishi Sunak faces ‘very likely’ legal challenge
lead: Prime Minister’s decision to axe the high speed rail line has come under sustained criticism
author: Richard Vaughan

body.text: Ministers face the threat of a judicial review from the rail industry and local councils if the Government pushes ahead with its plans to sell off land bought for HS2,  understands.

The Government has said it will soon start selling land that had been acquired under compulsory purchase orders in a move that will make it near impossible for any future administration to try and deliver the high speed line north of Birmingham.
The decision to sell the land came after Rishi Sunak announced plans to scrap the northern leg of HS2 beyond Birmingham, pledging instead to invest £36bn into transport schemes across the country.

Transport Secretary Mark Harper told MPs last month that his department will begin the process of lifting the safeguards around land purchased for the Birmingham to Crewe leg of HS2 “within weeks”, prompting fears of a firesale.
But senior rail industry sources have told  that they will consider launching a judicial review if the Government seeks to sell the land “precipitously and cheaply”.

A separate business source added that a legal challenge was also “very likely” from local authorities affected by the decision to scrap the northern leg of HS2, with the two groups potentially joining forces to mount a legal bid.
Any such move would force the Government to pause any plans to sell the land until the legal challenge was completed.
Industry experts also suggested that the fire sale could also fall foul of the Government’s “best value duty” to secure a decent return on the sale of any assets.
Reports last week suggested the Government could cost the taxpayer more than £100m by engaging in a fire sale of the land and property it bought as part of the HS2 phase 2a leg.
Just under £220m was spent on compulsory purchasing land and property for phase 2a, equating to around 29.2km2 of land safeguarded to build the high speed line.

Rail Minister Huw Merriman responding to a parliamentary question last week said the Government would sell land under so-called Crichel Down Rules, which requires the state to offer any surplus land to the former owner “at the current market value” before going to the wider market.

Several groups are calling for a delay on any sale of land, including the National Infrastructure Commission, which advises the Government on major infrastructure schemes, which warned it would be a “mistake” to sell the land and urged ministers to keep their options open.

Henri Murison, chief executive of the business lobbying group the Northern Powerhouse Partnership, urged the Government to delay any sale of the phase 2a land to allow for the private sector to step in and help fund the rail link.

“Some more time – as already guaranteed for phase 2b as part of the Northern Powerhouse Rail line to Manchester – is essential to give a private sector-funded option its best chance to succeed,” Mr Murison said.
Shadow Transport Secretary Louise Haigh criticised the approach to the land sale, warning the Government had “wasted billions on a line [Rishi Sunak] has now scrapped” .
“Now millions more will be wasted in this fire sale of the land, which so many people had to give up their homes and businesses for,” she added.

A Department of Transport spokesman said: “We are currently developing the programme for selling land no longer needed for HS2 and will set out more details in due course. We will ensure our approach provides value for the taxpayer and will fully engage with the communities who are affected throughout this process.”

title: Covid inquiry: No 10 downplayed Boris Johnson’s illness due to fears over hostile states
lead: Officials gave a ‘more positive impression’ of the then PM’s health over concerns terrorists could exploit an apparent power vacuum
author: Jane Merrick

body.text: Senior civil servants actively played down the seriousness of Boris Johnson’s Covid illness in April 2020, bombshell evidence to the Covid inquiry has revealed.

Officials gave a “more positive impression” of the then prime minister’s health to journalists because they were concerned that terrorists or hostile states could exploit an apparent power vacuum, that it would cause chaos on the financial markets, and that it would trigger panic among the public who were being asked to comply with lockdown regulations.

Former deputy cabinet secretary Helen MacNamara’s written statement to the inquiry reveals that, while Mr Johnson lay “very ill” in hospital on Monday 6 April 2020, but before being admitted to intensive care, journalists listening in to that morning’s phone-in lobby briefing were told that he was still able to take his red box while on the ward.

This was because, while the deputy PM at the time, Dominic Raab, was ready to stand in for Mr Johnson, officials had not yet arranged what exactly would happen if the then prime minister became incapacitated and could not communicate his wishes.

The account given to the 6 April lobby briefing was “technically accurate” but “right on the edge of what was comfortable”, Ms MacNamara says in her statement. She says however this was essential for national security and would make the same decision again.

Unlike the United States, where the 25th amendment enshrines a formal delegation of powers to the vice-president if the president is incapacitated, the UK has no formal constitutional plan for this scenario.

At the time Mr Johnson was ill, No10 faced questions over how transparent they had been about Mr Johnson’s condition, but this is the first admission from someone senior in government that there had been a concerted attempt to play it down.
Ms MacNamara gives the first official insider account of the chaos inside No10 when the then PM became seriously ill and had to be admitted to intensive care later on the Monday.

She admits that officials were “making it up as we went along” about who held the reins of power and that so many key players in No10 were sick and/or isolating with the virus during that period – including Cabinet Secretary Sir Mark Sedwill, chief medical officer Chris Whitty, health secretary Matt Hancock, Dominic Cummings and herself – that “the continuity of government felt illusionary”.

MacNamara says there was a “nervousness” inside No10 that “if the wider public were aware that so many decision makers and senior civil servants were incapacitated (even briefly) this would impact on confidence”.

In a sign of how chaotic the situation was, officials inside No10 only found out on the Monday that Mr Johnson might need to be admitted to intensive care at St Thomas’s Hospital, London, when his close protection officers were asked to “recce the route” from his ordinary ward to avoid him being spotted, and the officers relayed this back to No10, Ms MacNamara reveals.

Only a small circle in No10 and Buckingham Palace, including Ms MacNamara, the Cabinet Secretary, principal private secretary Martin Reynolds, the Queen and her PPS, and Mr Johnson’s communications chief Lee Cain knew the seriousness of Johnson’s condition before he was admitted to hospital on Sunday 5 April.

At the morning briefing to lobby journalists on Monday 6 April, his spokesman James Slack said the PM “remained in charge of the Government, was receiving updates in hospital and was continuing to receive a box” but the reality, MacNamara says, was he was “very ill”: “This [the account to journalists] was technically accurate but right on the edge of what was comfortable. It was a lot to ask of James Slack in particular…

“It is fair to say that the lines used allowed for a more positive impression of the Prime Minister’s health at that point. The Prime Minister was conscious, and it was possible to contact him and for him to make decisions but he was very ill. In practice in terms of ‘taking a box’ the Prime Minister had not in fact been working at his normal rate for a few days.”
Ms MacNamars says on the Sunday and early Monday her “primary concern” was to keep everyone calm and “getting through this new aspect to the crisis with the least harm possible”.

She adds: “We needed a few hours to make sure everyone was lined up behind the answers so there would be no risk of any disagreement or disquiet, and – in so far as it would be possible – make sure the Prime Minister would be content.”

“My caution was that although there are always robust and practised arrangements in place that are resilient to individual absence, it is still dangerous to national security in the broader sense to allow an illusion of uncertainty about who is in power. This could be exploited by bad actors.

“I was also concerned about the potential impact on the financial markets as well as wider national confidence if it looked as if there was any sliver of ambiguity about who was in charge. We did not want people to panic. Perception of grip and confidence matters anyway and particularly did in those first fragile weeks of the pandemic.”

There were so many people absent with Covid in No10 and the Cabinet Office during this period that there was a “chaotic environment”, the former top civil servant says, adding: “In reality, continuity of government felt illusionary.”

title: Elon Musk and King Charles warn of AI danger as 28 countries sign ‘Bletchley declaration’ at Sunak tech summit
lead: Leading figures including Elon Musk and Kamal Harris warned of the risks of AI at the UK-hosted summit
author: Hugo Gye

body.text: Global governments including the US and China have agreed for the first time to work together to control “potentially catastrophic” artificial intelligence but fell short of setting binding rules for tech giants to follow.
Leading figures including Elon Musk, Kamala Harris and King Charles warned of the dangers posed by the technology at the AI Safety Summit in Bletchley Park, Buckinghamshire.

On Thursday Rishi Sunak will join world leaders for a further joint statement on how to head off the most extreme risks, followed by a live-streamed discussion with Mr Musk, the boss of X, formerly known as Twitter.

On the summit’s first day, 28 countries including 15 members of the G20 signed the “Bletchley declaration”, which states: “Substantial risks may arise from potential intentional misuse or unintended issues of control relating to alignment with human intent. These issues are in part because those capabilities are not fully understood and are therefore hard to predict.”

Governments agreed to work together to form an “internationally inclusive network of scientific research on frontier AI safety” – with further summits taking place in South Korea in six months’ time and France in a year.

Matt Clifford, the Prime Minister’s AI envoy, said: “This summit is focussed on next year’s models.
