What we know right now is that the leading AI companies are training models in some cases with up to 50 times more resource than the current models. That’s what this summit about, how do we address potentially catastrophic risks from those models.”
He suggested that by the time of the next summit, leaders would know enough to decide whether international regulations are needed to control the risks posed by more powerful technologies.

Mustafa Suleyman, a British entrepreneur who co-founded DeepMind and now runs Inflection AI, said that governments should set up a global co-ordinatory body similar to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. He also said it would be “a very sensible question to ask” whether at some point in future cutting-edge AI development should be paused completely to assess its dangers.

In a video address to the summit, King Charles said: “The rapid rise of powerful artificial intelligence is considered by many of the greatest thinkers of our age no less significant, no less important than the discovery of electricity, the splitting of the atom, the creation of the world wide web or even the harnessing of fire.”

He added: “AI continues to advance with ever greater speed towards models that some predict could surpass human abilities, even human understanding. There is a clear imperative to ensure that this rapidly evolving technology remains safe and secure.”

Mr Musk said AI was “one of the biggest threats to humanity” because it could soon become “far smarter than the smartest human”, adding: “It’s not clear to me we can actually control such a thing, but I think we can aspire to guide it in a direction that’s beneficial to humanity.”
US Vice President Ms Harris warned of risks including cyber attacks and bio-weapons, but also pointed to more everyday dangers such as disinformation, faulty algorithms and deepfake images.

title: Inside the Alliance for Responsible Citizenship conference with Michael Gove and Kemi Badenoch
lead: Delegates from all over the world gathered in Greenwich, south-east London, to discuss the future of conservative values
author: Eleanor Langford

body.text: In the shadow of the O2, politicians and thinkers from around the world are currently gathering with the aim of guiding the future of global conservatism.
More than 1,000 attendees are expected at the three-day inaugural conference of the Alliance for Responsible Citizenship (ARC), which was founded earlier this year.

Among the crowds was a sizeable delegation from Australia, with one attendee claiming that there had been a “buzz” about the UK conference in conservative circles in the country, especially as the former prime minister of Australia John Howard was among those on the agenda.

Numerous Americans also made the trip across the pond, although some congressional representatives were said to have been forced to pull out last minute, due to the furore over the selection of their new House Speaker, Mike Johnson, last week.
There was also a smattering of Tory MPs among the crowd, with Cabinet ministers Kemi Badenoch and Michael Gove set to speak alongside backbenchers Miriam Cates and Danny Kruger.
This worldwide appeal is no coincidence, according to one attendee, who told  they view the purpose of the conference as “creating a new global story” for conservative values.
The main themes of the programme include the promotion of family values, improving ties in society, building a new moral framework and rethinking the current economic system.
Christian faith is also a quieter but ever-present concern at the conference, with Bible verses among the inspirational quotes from world leaders and thinkers adorning the walls of the main hall.
The atmosphere inside is convivial and high-brow, with string-quartet interludes between sessions and gourmet finger food on offer at lunch.

Not everything is so genteel, however, as one panel included an interview with Willie and Korie Robertson from , an American reality television series about a Louisiana family running a business selling duck-hunting products. The pair were there to discuss the legacy of the show, which ended in 2017, in promoting Christian values in family life.

There is also a very American feel to the high-production value of proceedings. During a session on the future of the family, the hall’s four giant screens show a professional short film spelling out the challenges facing young boys in modern society.

To drill home the point about the importance of present fathers, the session ends with a five-piece ensemble giving a rendition of “It’s Quiet Uptown” from the musical Hamilton – a song detailing Alexander Hamilton’s grief after his son died in a duel.

International attendees were reluctant to reveal how much they had spent to get to the conference, but one said it was “worth every cent” for them to “experience a forum for true conservative values”.

The conversations they flew thousands of miles to hear included American theoretical physicist Steve Koonin insisting there was “scant support” for climate change, and controversial author Jordan Peterson leading a panel discussing how the “great loser of the sexual revolution has been children”.

Levelling Up Secretary Michael Gove took a more measured tone in his speech on Tuesday, claiming that big corporations have “co-opted” diversity and inclusion to “insulate themselves” from resentment at their wealth.

He added that these “privileged” groups have allied themselves with “the resentment industry” – a phrase he used to describe diversity and inclusion initiatives – which he described as “the biggest growth industry in the world”.

What the conference means for the Conservative Party in the UK is unclear, but one London-based attendee said he hoped it was the start of more alignment between US, Australian and British right-wing groups in the future.
“The conservatives over there can teach us a lot about what we need to do here,” they said.

title: Rishi Sunak warned over ‘mad’ and ‘idiotic’ decision to put Elon Musk at centre of AI Safety Summit
lead: The owner of X and the Prime Minister will take part in a live-streamed ‘conversation’ about artificial intelligence on Thursday
author: Hugo Gye

body.text: The Government plans to put “maverick” Elon Musk at the centre of the AI Safety Summit this week, despite warnings from Tory insiders that the “idiotic” move could backfire.

The owner of X, formerly Twitter, was a co-founder of tech firm OpenAI, and has called for a six-month pause on the development of new artificial intelligence in order to minimise the risk that it escapes the control of humans and threatens our collective future.
However, during his leadership of the social media platform he has been accused of sharing conspiracy theories, promoting misinformation and making controversial interventions in politics.

Mr Musk, who runs Tesla and SpaceX as well as X, will attend a number of events at the summit on Wednesday and Thursday, followed by a reception for business leaders on Thursday evening and a “conversation” with Rishi Sunak about AI risks which will be live-streamed.
Downing Street strategists believe his involvement will help draw attention to the summit and have planned a detailed publicity campaign around his appearances.

A No 10 insider said: “We are obviously delighted that he is coming, it is certainly eye-catching. Elon Musk is not someone that will jump on a plane and come for anyone, it shows the UK is a strong draw. A lot of what Rishi has done is about restoring the UK’s position and reminding our allies on the world stage what Britain has to offer.”

However, Frank Luntz, a leading US pollster with close ties to the Republican Party, warned that Mr Musk no longer had the same broad appeal that he once had following controversy over his X ownership. He said: “He was given the gift of credibility, influence and popularity but he threw it all away. It was different two years ago, but now he is seen as cruel and harsh.”

A former official who worked on UK tech policy told : “If I was still there, I would be telling them they are absolutely mad for doing this – it is idiotic. It is going to be the final nail in the coffin for a number of careers of people in No 10.
“And if I was a Prime Minister with an election in a year, I wouldn’t prioritise what people in America think of my summit.”

In response a Downing Street source said of the tech boss: “He is a maverick. We are not going to agree with everything that he says, but the point is you get together and you find areas of agreement.”
Mr Musk’s appearances were negotiated over a period of several months and only finalised in recent weeks. A number of Conservative MPs backed the idea despite the tycoon’s controversial reputation.

Greg Clark, chair of the Commons Science Committee, told : “I think it is beneficial to have a wide range of views represented on AI safety. Since Musk is both a major deployer of AI and has called for a pause on safety grounds it may be useful to hear from him directly.”

Another ex-minister added: “It is a massive coup. Because a lot of the point of this summit is getting tech bosses to agree to share their systems with government – and it is very hard for him to show up and say, we are not going to co-operate with you.”
The MP suggested Mr Musk would be less confrontational in person than he is online, saying: “Always Musk has been a childish caricature on Twitter, and in person is very different.
“It’s like the issue around inviting the Chinese – the only thing worse than having him there is not having him there. And even if he does go bonkers it’s not Rishi’s fault.”

A former Twitter staff member, who was laid off in Mr Musk’s first round of cuts after he took over in October 2022, said they couldn’t understand why the Prime Minister was choosing to take part in the live-streamed chat, because they felt Mr Musk had little goodwill among the UK electorate.

His decisions while in control of X also worried other experts. “It’s an exceedingly odd move for a world leader to share a platform with a man who has been actively pushing misinformation on a range of issues as well as crippling what once was a key part of the public sphere,” said Steven Buckley, a lecturer in media and communications at City, University of London.

“There is a plethora of experts Rishi could speak to if he wanted to learn more about social media platforms and the development of AI. The fact he’s chosen to share a digital stage and discuss a range of important issues with Elon, who on the best of days has little clue what he is talking about, is perplexing.”

The AI Safety Summit, at Bletchley Park in Buckinghamshire, is being attended by companies including OpenAI, Microsoft, Google DeepMind, China’s Alibaba and Tencent, and Facebook owner Meta, which is sending its vice-president Sir Nick Clegg.

Leaders and ministers from the US, EU, France, Germany, Italy are coming, plus China’s junior science minister Wu Zhaohui. Multilateral organisations such as the UN will also be represented. The UK Government hopes for an agreement to “fence off areas of risk that are so bad we need to work together to mitigate them”, a source said.

title: Labour splits over Gaza ceasefire calls set to widen despite Keir Starmer facing down rebels, insiders warn
lead: More MPs are poised to call for a ceasefire while the Labour leader could face more direct criticism as pro-ceasefire rebels get more ‘frustrated’ over party position
author: Arj Singh

body.text: Labour splits over the Gaza war could intensify with more MPs calling for a ceasefire and Sir Keir Starmer facing more direct criticism, insiders warned despite the Labour leader’s attempts to heal divides.
But the Labour leader appeared to have avoided a full blown civil war after the Shadow Cabinet’s effective spokeswoman for pro-ceasefire MPs made clear she would not quit.

The Labour leader faced down party rebels who reject his policy on the Israel-Hamas conflict in a speech on Tuesday where he insisted that his backing for a “humanitarian pause” to allow aid into the Gaza Strip was the “only credible approach” because a ceasefire would “embolden” Hamas and “freeze” the conflict with the militant group capable of launching another 7 October-style terror attack.

But in an attempt to heal the rebellion which has seen a dozen shadow ministers speak out against his position and others lobby privately for a policy change, he suggested he would back a ceasefire once Israeli, British and other hostages are released by Hamas and the militants’ power has been broken.

And he took a harder line on Israel, insisting it cannot have a “blank cheque” to do whatever it wants in self defence, while stressing settlements in the West Bank were “unacceptable, awful” and have “to stop”.

As he refused to deny he was taking advice from Sir Tony Blair on the conflict, Sir Keir was also backed by the ex-prime minister’s ally Lord Mandelson, who told the podcast that calls for a ceasefire were “ridiculous” because “we have to defeat cold blooded murderers”.

But while Sir Keir appeared to have avoided triggering a full blown civil war as the Shadow Cabinet’s only Muslim member, Shabana Mahmood, made clear she was not going to resign, he was warned that the revolt may grow if and when more civilians are killed in Gaza.

A Labour MP said Sir Keir, whose speech triggered a small pro-Palestine protest at the door, had “nothing to say” about the civilians being killed by Israeli bombing in a speech full of “scripted empathy”.
The MP said that colleagues had so far stuck to calling for a ceasefire rather than directly attacking Sir Keir due to the seriousness of the situation.
“That won’t necessarily last forever though,” the MP warned.
“Because people will get more and more frustrated, and if things get worse in Gaza as we unfortunately predict, then people’s attitudes and self-discipline on that could recede.”

After Alex Cunningham became the latest frontbencher to call for a ceasefire less than an hour before Sir Keir’s speech, a Labour insider said at least three more Labour MPs were set to join the calls this week.
The insider, who supports Sir Keir’s position, said they had endured “horrible meetings with the Muslim community” this week and that the speech did not change anything.
“We are just going to have to live with being divided for a while, until the situation changes,” the insider added.
A second party insider said any MP with a large number of Muslim voters and members locally would be concerned.
“I think it’s a big problem and bigger than Keir’s team realise and one they clearly didn’t see coming,” the insider said.
“I fear we’ve dug a deeper hole for ourselves than we realise”

title: ﻿Starmer must stand firm on Israel-Gaza – calls for a ceasefire are hugely naive
lead: Hamas is not a ceasefire kind of organisation
author: Anne McElvoy

body.text: The Labour ceasefire did not last long. The Starmer army is once again embattled in an internal war over foreign and security matters, as calls mount to suspend Israel’s counter-attacks on Hamas, embedded at its deepest among civilian infrastructure, in northern Gaza.

The resulting damage to innocent Gazans has been dreadful to behold. “Houses can fall down on the heads of residents at any moment, any time. We don’t sleep or rest at all,” as one resident cowering in the rubble of air attacks told the BBC. It is wholly unsurprising then that the Opposition’s early strong claim that Israel has the right to defend itself  – which in real terms, means rooting Hamas out of Gaza’s tunnels, buildings and the civilianredoubtwhere it embedded itself by forcing out the moderate Fatah leadership in 2006.

Many on the left have missed this rather crucial development – Hamas is itself an interloper (and one which always acts by force) in the strained politics of Gaza. The government of Benjamin Netanyahu has been a blunt cosh to hopes of a two-state solution to decades of violence, but it is also one which has widespread support, despite its deadly security lapses, when it comes to the determination to drive Hamas operationally out of Gaza.

This is the reality on the ground and whatever is said at Westminster makes no material difference. The only country with leverage is the US and falling out with a Democratic, centrist president facing a maverick, isolationist, unreliable contender in Donald Trump is not where Keir Starmer would like to be. When I spoke to him only a couple  of months ago on a trip to North America for a podcast, he was adamant that Labour had left its Corbyn era “Uncle Sam” bashing behind and was finally back as an Atlanticist force.

The blood-thirsty horror inflicted by Hamas on Israel on 7 October and the malign prolonging of its traumatic impacts by the seizure of hostages made for an easy denunciation for Starmer and his shadow Foreign Secretary David Lammy. At Labour conference, the party’s showcase of readiness for power next year, this line held because the only horrible images around news networks were the (necessarily edited) footage of Hamas’s multiple atrocities in the Be’eri kibbutz. That has changed sharply as the counter-attacks on Hamas in Gaza have multiplied. Attending a Labour fundraiser two weeks ago, I watched London Mayor Sadiq Khan praise Keir Starmer’s leadership (gritted teeth may be required, but the prospect of power can unify internal foes).

But this was an illusion of unity. Starmer’s issue is that it is not the pro-Soviet, America-bashing hard left which is his problem right now, it is that the “soft left” faction to which he belonged not long ago. Khan in London, Andy Burnham as Labour’s showpiece Mayor in Manchester and popular back-benchers including Jess Philips are defying Starmer outright and calling for a ceasefire.

On the face of it, this sounds like a good idea. It is not. For a start, it will not happen – Israel cannot afford to say “time out” about its 9/11 day and let Hamas continue to hold the ring in Gaza. Supporting that position is in opposition to Israel and also vastly naïve. Hamas is not a ceasefire kind of organisation. It will re-arm and re-attack – and its hostage tactics are to prolong the suffering for Israel long enough for Western support to falter and other bad actors, including  Russia, to begin to influence events.

However, Starmer cannot ignore the warnings from his shadow foreign secretary and Wes Streeting either (the latter being most properly “centrist” member of the Shadow Cabinet after Rachel Reeves, the shadow Chancellor who is keeping out of this fray).

In essence, they are worried that the slightly robotic Starmer line about demanding adherence to international law is looking like an evasion. And in truth it is: no disrespect at all to Starmer’s human rights advocacy as senior lawyer, but having covered conflicts in Bosnia, Croatia and Kosovo, international law turns out to be a bit of a chocolate teapot when conflicts are raging. Israel will say the UN view is stacked against it by Realpolitik. Palestinians and allies will complain that their suffering is not weighted equally. We are, frankly, no further forward on this score.

The one area where Starmer could sharpen his message is on humanitarian aid. The present call for £10m from the UK is paltry. Formally, Labour’s position is very little different from the Government’s – but it could be stronger on the need to allow fuel into the territory. There is an objection that Hamas has a deadly habit of commandeering such supplies but frankly at this point, civilian suffering is so acute and Hamas so well supplied by its main backers, Iran and Hezbollah, that this is a risk worth taking to save lives in the general Palestinian population.

When choices are invidious, there is still a decision to make. The alternative is that everyone else will start to make policy on the hoof. Starmer should certainly not accept a poorly-argued ceasefire demand from parts of his party who are fair weather supporters of Israel at a time of a geopolitical tempest. But he can amp up support for humanitarian help and take the Government to task for its own blind spots on this aspect of this woeful story. Be less the lawyer, Keir – and more the leader.

title: Margaret Thatcher can teach Keir Starmer and Rishi Sunak how to deal with a crisis in Israel
lead: The former PM was a critical yet supporting friend
author: Ian Birrell

body.text: Two years after becoming prime minister, Margaret Thatcher gave an interview to The Jewish Chronicleabout her forceful condemnation of an Israeli attack on a nuclear reactor in Iraq. She said such actions caused “great grief” for the country’s friends by cutting the ground from under their feet, explaining how her opposition to such aggression was rooted in a passion for freedom and contempt for terrorism.

“I believe firmly in fair dealing and fair principles,” she said. “Don’t you see, if I openly condemn the PLO [Palestinian Liberation Organisation] for terrorism, I have to condemn everyone for the use of violence and terrorism?”

This attack in 1981 was defended by Israel’s leadership on the basis of thwarting development of weapons of mass destruction. “There won’t be another Holocaust in history,” said the Israeli prime minister Menachem Begin, leader of the Likud Party. “Never again.”

Such statements did not intimidate his British counterpart. “If we are not going to live by a system of international law, we are going to live by international anarchy. Then no people anywhere in the world are safe,” responded Thatcher, saying this sentiment drove her desire for Middle East peace. “You cannot be selective in your defence of law – you cannot say: ‘I like that law, I will uphold that one, I will not uphold the other.'”

Her words have eerie resonance reading them four decades later as Israeli forces step up an assault on Gaza under another Likud leader and hopes of peace shrivel further. The circumstances today are very different as Israel responds to atrocities committed against citizens on its soil – and as Thatcher said in that interview, every country has the right to defend itself. Yet every bomb, every bullet, every death, takes that tormented region further from peace. And we must not forget British people are both hostages and stuck inside Gaza.

Thatcher’s resolve that Israel should respect democratic values and international law offer sharp contrast to the pusillanimous response of both Rishi Sunak and Sir Keir Starmer to the latest unfolding horrors in the Middle East. Her stance is all the more instructive when she is rightly seen as such a firm supporter of Israel, a nation she admired as an oasis of democracy and enterprise surrounded by autocracies, and her philosemitism went far beyond the representing of Finchley with its many Jewish constituents. “I simply did not understand antisemitism,” she wrote in her memoirs.

This dated to her teenage years – and what she called her greatest accomplishment in helping rescue a young woman from the Nazis in 1939. Edith Muhlbauer, a 17-year-old Austrian, wrote asking to stay with her pen pal – the future prime minister’s big sister Muriel – and in response, the family worked with their local Rotary Club to raise funds for her travel and lodging in Grantham, Lincolnshire. Margaret was shocked when their “very sophisticated” guest – who shared a room with her at one point – detailed Jews being forced to scrub the streets. “She told us what it was like to live as a Jew under an antisemitic regime,” recalled Thatcher later.

This was, bear in mind, a time of bigotry in Westminster and open prejudice barring Jews from public places; indeed, she joined one protest as a young Tory politician against a golf club excluding Jewish people. Several members of Edith’s family were murdered in the Holocaust, so she believed she might have died too without the intervention of that grocer’s family in Lincolnshire. “Never hesitate to do whatever you can, for you may save a life,” said Thatcher.

When Thatcher died 10 years ago, Benjamin Netanyahu hailed her as “a staunch friend of Israel and of the Jewish people”. She admired the values of the community in Britain, saying that in 33 years representing Finchley: “I never had a Jew come in poverty and desperation to one of my surgeries.” She was a supporter of Soviet Jewry, pushing their cause in Moscow. She promoted many Jewish ministers. And she was such a strident backer of Israel that some British diplomats fretted she might damage relations with the Arab world.

But Thatcher was a pragmatist and accepted both parties in the Arab-Israeli conflict had what she termed “unimpeachable moral cases”. She opposed the expansion of settlements in the West Bank, seeing them as a barrier to peace. In 1980, just one year after entering Downing Street, she backed a landmark European declaration to Begin’s fury that called for an end to Israel’s “territorial occupation” and the PLO to have a role in peace talks. Two years later she authorised foreign office talks with PLO leaders despite fierce public hostility to terrorism amid the raging conflict in Northern Ireland.

Her views on the Middle East even led to friction with Washington after she pushed the United States to talk to the PLO, warning that its uncritical support for Israel was hampering a peace process that needed to be rooted on justice for Palestinians. She condemned Israel’s disastrous invasion of Lebanon in 1982, comparing it with Argentina’s attack on the Falklands two months earlier. Then she spoke out against “pure barbarism” when war crimes were committed after Israeli forces allowed their allies to massacre civilians in two refugee camps.

Thatcher’s foreign policy and stand against racial bigotry were far from perfect, as seen in South Africa. She governed also in a very different era. Yet, she respected the rule of law and knew the real meaning of friendship between nations. As fears grow that Israel has rushed into a trap set by Hamas and Iran with its siege and savage pounding of Gaza, our current generation of leaders on all sides of the political spectrum might do well to learn from her moral clarity on these issues.

title: One year of Rishi Sunak and the verdict is… dismal
lead: His biggest success is not being Liz Truss. His best quality is failure
author: Ian Dunt

body.text: Rishi Sunak’s greatest achievement came on the day he took office. It was that he is not Liz Truss.

Later, when the history books are written, they will allow him that one solitary consideration. For all his flaws, for all the manifest inadequacies and unforced errors he has demonstrated in power, he is not as bad as the most inept prime minister in British history. But that really is the only credit we can give him. In every other aspect, he has been a political failure.
As of today, Sunak has been in power for one year.

When he arrived at Downing Street he seemed like a perfectly average and unremarkable figure, the sort of person who in any normal country would have been a decent junior secretary in the Treasury, but through the mad volatile contortions of British parliamentary democracy had risen right to the top of the political system.
On the steps of No 10 he promised “integrity, professionalism and accountability”. And then immediately afterwards he appointed Gavin Williamson and Dominic Raab to the Cabinet.

Williamson was the most embarrassing figure to ever become defence or education secretary – a combination of Dracula and Frank Spencer. Raab had presided over the moral calamity of the Afghan withdrawal, where countless thousands of people who had supported Britain were left to the mercy of the Taliban. Both had been accused of bullying. Sunak gave them senior positions anyway and soon afterwards, in a manner that was perfectly easy to foresee, they both had to resign. His promise of integrity had lasted for a matter of hours.
His commitment to competence endured a little longer. When he came to power, this was one of his main electoral advantages. YouGov polling gave him a +28 rating on competence in October last year.

Then, in January 2023, he made a keynote speech outlining his five pledges to the country: halve inflation, grow the economy, reduce the debt, cut NHS waiting lists and pass legislation to stop small boats coming to the UK.

It was a bizarre collection of half-formed aspirations. Inflation was predicted to halve anyway so he was merely trying to take credit for a process which was expected to take place regardless – although even this cynical gambit fell apart when the level remained stubbornly high. His pledge on migrants crossing the Channel in small boats was simply to pass legislation, but it was immediately translated into a commitment to stop the boats themselves, which he would never be able to do.

The promises on the economy, debt and NHS waiting lists were largely out of his hands, or negated by other commitments. His second pledge of “growing the economy”, for instance, became much harder given that the Bank of England had to ratchet up interest rates to satisfy his first pledge of reducing inflation.

None of the pledges have been fulfilled and some of them, like waiting lists, are going backwards. They took his chief perceived attribute – competence – and subjected it to a highly public test over which he had no control whatsoever and in fact would have to sometimes work to undermine. It was as if he’d strapped himself to a mast and then commanded a sorcerer to summon up a devastating storm.Within a year, his YouGov competence rating had fallen to -12.

In the background, the edifice of a functioning British state began to crumble. School classrooms were so unsafe that they threatened to fall in on the children. Prisons are so full that some rapists may not be sent to jail. There was a failure of basic governance, in nearly every policy portfolio, across nearly every department. He had not created it. But he did nothing to improve it.

The image of Sunak as a competent technocrat was a mirage. But at least it was an image. He had that, at the very minimum. And then, during last month’s Tory party conference, he decided to undermine even this. Sunak the technocrat was gone. In his place was Sunak the change candidate – a man who would discard the failed “30-year consensus” and demonstrate “long-term thinking for a brighter future”.

That approach involved slowing down Britain’s net-zero commitments, inventing a collection of imaginary policies on things like bin collection and then promising to stop them, cancelling a high-speed rail line, reforming A-levels and banning smoking.

It was like a random policy party bag. You put your hand in and grabbed something with no idea what would emerge when you pulled it out again. There was no narrative thread to unite all these disparate elements. They were a collection of the bizarre, the self-sabotaging, the irresponsible and the banal.

Even here, his new image was skin-deep. His package of alternative rail commitments to replace HS2 included a Nottingham metro extension that already existed, an A1 road upgrade that had been originally promised in 2010, and a mass transit system for Bristol that was subsequently deleted from the website.
Sunak later insisted that these were only “illustrative” and not meant as pledges.

What ultimately is the point of Sunak’s premiership? Does he uphold integrity? No. Is he an effective technocrat? No. Is he a change candidate? No. Does he demonstrate long-term thinking? No. He is a political absence.

If we can ascribe to him any quality at all, it is this: he fails. On every different variation of his projections. He didn’t even succeed in the leadership contest which made him Prime Minister – Truss did. He was simply handed the post in a scramble to minimise the damage.
And sometime soon, when an election is finally called, he will fail again. But somehow we have to survive another year of this before that happens.

title: Creating new laws to stop ‘jihad’ protestors will set a dangerous precedent for free speech
lead: Free speech restrictions have unintended consequences
author: Ian Dunt

body.text: The word was spoken sometime on Saturday afternoon, as demonstrators marched through London to protest Israel’s bombardment of Gaza.

A separate Hizb ut-Tahrir protest saw a man address a small crowd of people. “What is the solution to liberate people in the concentration camp of Palestine?” he asked. The answer was “jihad”. The police failed to arrest him. And from that moment a debate has erupted about police powers, anti-extremism legislation and the need for more controls on what people can say.

But there’s a problem. We’re in no position to have this debate. We currently don’t have the maturity as a country to engage in it. The term “free speech” has been mangled by years of self-interested culture war nonsense. The Government and right-wing commentators are biting at the leash to crack down on pro-Palestinian demonstrators. Labour will commit to whatever No 10 suggests so it doesn’t end up looking weak on law and order. And everyone’s emotions are heightened by what’s happening in the Middle East.

This is an issue that needs patient, judicious, cautious appraisal, with a full assessment of competing rights, and an awareness of the unintended consequences of legislation. But we are governed by cynical dimwits, without a basic grasp of the issues they pontificate on, reacting instinctively to events they barely understand. It’s a dangerous combination.

Immigration minister Robert Jenrick got in first, saying he was “surprised” by the police response and demanded protestors face the “full force of the law”. Home Secretary Suella Braverman will tell Met police head Mark Rowley today that the police “must crack down on anyone breaking the law”.

The Met is pushing back by saying that the real fault lies in the law itself. Rowley authored a report a couple of years ago which claimed there was a “gaping chasm” in legislation which allowed hate groups to act with “impunity”.

In truth, neither position is correct. Jenrick doesn’t have the basis to understand the operational decisions made, on the spot, about what was taking place. Rowley is wrong that the police do not have the powers to act if they need to.

It’s honestly very hard to understand why the police didn’t act on Saturday. They have plenty of legal mechanisms available to them. The Terrorism Act 2006 outlaws statements which indirectly encourage “the commission or preparation of acts of terrorism”. The Counter-Terrorism Act 2019 prohibits “an opinion or belief that is supportive of a proscribed organisation” like Hamas. The Public Order Act 1986 outlaws “threatening, abusive or insulting words or behaviour” which are intended to “stir up racial hatred”.

The Met released a statement saying that the word jihad “has a number of meanings”. This is true – it can apply to a personal religious struggle as well as religious war, but to my mind it was perfectly obvious which version was being deployed, given the circumstances and the speaker’s preceding statements.

Perhaps the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) advised that the chances of a successful prosecution were not high. Or maybe officers at the scene worried about the public disorder consequences of making the arrests. These assessments would have been taking place in a volatile, dynamic and fast-moving situation. The police are frequently disastrous, but cases like these, which are delicate and volatile, are about as hard as it gets. They deserve the benefit of the doubt.

There is a dangerous consequence to the political attack on the police and the Met’s response that they need more legal powers. It pushes towards creating new laws to further inhibit free speech, when the ones we have are perfectly adequate to the task.

Rowley’s 2021 report wanted to ban activity or materials which “create a climate conducive to hate crime, terrorism or other violence”. It all sounds perfectly reasonable. The problem he has – and indeed that all attempts to write this kind of legislation have – is that these kinds of terms capture all sorts of free speech which we would typically want to protect. Indeed, it would likely cover the type of political speech which right-wing anti-immigrant politicians, like Braverman herself, regularly deploy.

In 2019 for instance, Brenton Harrison Tarrant killed 51 people in two consecutive terror attacks aimed at mosques in New Zealand. Amid the reading material he consumed were articles referencing “white genocide” and the “great replacement theory” – the false idea that white Europeans and Americas are being purposefully replaced by non-white groups, predominantly Muslims.

The conservative writer and associate editor of , Douglas Murray, has dabbled in great replacement theory. “Any trip to thousands of locations across Europe,” he wrote, “can spark the fear of what the French writer and philosopher Renaud Camus has characterised as ‘le grand remplacement’.”

Murray attended a National Conservatism event earlier this year alongside several other people who have expressed support for the theory. Other attendees included Braverman and Michael Gove. And indeed, Braverman herself has sailed perilously close to the wind with a recent speech on multiculturalism which was celebrated by far-right groups like Britain First and the Neo-Nazi Patriotic Alternative.

“Uncontrolled immigration, inadequate integration, and a misguided dogma of multiculturalism have proven a toxic combination for Europe over the last few decades,” she said. “We are living with the consequence of that failure today. You can see it play out on the streets of cities all over Europe. From Malmo, to Paris, Brussels, to Leicester.”

We might not mind this idea being banned. Certainly it is hateful and certainly it can, in Rowley’s words, “create a climate conducive to… terrorism”. But free speech restrictions have unintended consequences. We pass laws in one context to apply to one group of people and then suddenly find them being used in another context to apply to another group of people. And eventually we find that they are being applied to us.

The way to legislate in this area is cautiously, during a moment of sober reflection, under the authorship of serious people. But our current political culture is defined by over-excitement, failure of comprehension and a government of the perennially inept. We’re simply not grown up to have this conversation right now. We should be wary of letting them have it.

title: Labour Gaza row deepens as suspension of Andy McDonald for ‘river to sea’ speech described as ‘obscene’
lead: Andy McDonald was suspended following his comments at a pro-Palestine rally at the weekend
author: Eleanor Langford

body.text: The Labour Muslim Network has said the party’s suspension of MP Andy McDonald over comments he made at a pro-Palestine rally is “obscene and deeply offensive”.
Mr McDonald, who has been MP for Middlesbrough since 2012, had the party whip suspended on Monday for using the phrase “between the river and the sea” at the rally.
Critics of a chant which contains the phrase “from the river to the sea” argue it implicitly calls for the destruction of Israel.

But Mr McDonald has rejected this interpretation of his words, claiming they were a “heartfelt plea for an end to the killings in Israel, Gaza, and the occupied West Bank, and for all peoples in the region to live in freedom without the threat of violence”.
Speaking at the event on Saturday, Mr McDonald said: “We won’t rest until we have justice. Until all people, Israelis and Palestinians, between the river and the sea can live in peaceful liberty.”

Explaining the suspension, a Labour spokesperson said: “The comments made by Andy McDonald at the weekend were deeply offensive, particularly at a time of rising antisemitism which has left Jewish people fearful for their safety.
“The chief whip has suspended the Labour whip from Andy McDonald, pending an investigation.”

Earlier this month, Home Secretary Suella Braverman urged police chiefs to consider interpreting the phrase “from the river to the sea” as an “expression of a violent desire to see Israel erased from the world”, an interpretation backed by Israel and many Jewish groups.
In a statement published shortly after the suspension was confirmed, the Labour Muslim Network described the decision as “both obscene and deeply offensive”.
The statement said: “The fundamental right to live in peace, with liberty and self-determination is one which should be applied to all peoples. It is the principle on which our democracies are built.
“The only conclusion that can be drawn is that those who have made this decision do not see Palestinian and Muslim life as deserving of this fundamental principle.”
Mr McDonald said he was “saddened” by the decision and that he would be “engaging and fully co-operating with the inquiry”.
“Throughout the past two days, there have been a number of misrepresentations of my words in the media,” he continued.
“These have furthered baseless and extremely harmful accusations against me, which I feel obliged to respond to now, in order to avoid any further errors in the press.”

He added that his speech “should not be construed in any other way than they were intended, namely as a heartfelt plea for an end to the killings in Israel, Gaza, and the occupied West Bank, and for all peoples in the region to live in freedom without the threat of violence”.

“I will be happy to explain these views to the investigation when it convenes, and trust that the whip will be restored. In the meantime, for the sake of humanity, I hope and pray that we see an end to the war in Gaza, and steps are taken towards a lasting peace,” Mr McDonald added.
Jeremy Corbyn’s former shadow chancellor John McDonnell defending Mr McDonald, stressing that he had not used the conested chant but “turned a slogan some are concerned about into a peace plea”.

He added: “Now he has been suspended from the Parliamentary Labour Party. This isn’t just unjust it is absolutely nonsensical. It was a brilliant way of turning something that some misinterpreted as a negative into a positive contribution.”

North of Tyne Mayor Jamie Driscoll, who quit Labour earlier this year, said: “Suspending a great local MP like Andy McDonald for calling for Israelis and Palestinians to live together in peace and liberty is shameful. Sir Keir needs to reverse this decision. Everyone should be calling for peace.”
Matt Wrack, Fire Brigades Union general secretary, said: “The Labour leaders’ office has got this profoundly wrong. Keir Starmer must intervene to reverse this appalling decision.”

Shadow Cabinet minister Darren Jones earlier said “from the river to the sea” was not a phrase that he would use and acknowledged it had “very deeply held connotations for people who are either from the region or have connections to the region”, telling Times Radio: “All of us in politics need to work extra hard to choose the right words.”

title: ﻿Keir Starmer suspends senior Labour MP Andy McDonald over ‘river to the sea’ speech
lead: The MP said his remarks had been ‘misrepresented’ and were a plea ‘for all peoples in the region to live in freedom’
author: Arj Singh

body.text: A senior Labour MP has been suspended from the parliamentary party after making comments described as “deeply offensive” at a pro-Palestine rally.
Andy McDonald was initially not expected to face disciplinary action for using the controversial slogan “from the river to the sea” to express backing for Palestine at the weekend’s march.
But following fast-paced internal discussions on Monday afternoon, he has had the party whip suspended.

The left-leaning former Shadow Cabinet minister, who quit Sir Keir’s team in 2021 after a row over domestic policy, has insisted that he was supporting peace between Israelis and Palestinians, both of whom he referred to in his remarks.
He had said:  “We won’t rest until we have justice, until all people, Israelis and Palestinians, between the river and the sea can live in peaceful liberty. Free, free Palestine!”

A Labour spokesperson said: “The comments made by Andy McDonald at the weekend were deeply offensive, particularly at a time of rising antisemitism which has left Jewish people fearful for their safety.
“The chief whip has suspended the Labour whip from Andy McDonald, pending an investigation.”

After his suspension, Mr McDonald said: “I am saddened to have received the news from the opposition chief whip that I have been placed under ‘”‘precautionary suspension” for a period of three months, which is reviewable pending an investigation by the Labour Party.
“I look forward to engaging and fully co-operating with the inquiry.
“Throughout the past two days, there have been a number of misrepresentations of my words in the media.
“These have furthered baseless and extremely harmful accusations against me, which I feel obliged to respond to now, in order to avoid any further errors in the press.”

Mr McDonald said that his words “should not be construed in any other way than they were intended, namely as a heartfelt plea for an end to the killings in Israel, Gaza, and the occupied West Bank, and for all peoples in the region to live in freedom without the threat of violence”.

He added: “I will be happy to explain these views to the investigation when it convenes, and trust that the whip will be restored. In the meantime, for the sake of humanity, I hope and pray that we see an end to the war in Gaza, and steps are taken towards a lasting peace.”

Rishi Sunak’s official spokesman previously said the use of the chant “from the river to the sea, Palestine will be free” at protests in London was of “significant concern to many”, while education minister Robert Halfon, who is Jewish, said hearing the phrase being chanted was “horrific” and “scary”. Mr McDonald did not use that phrasing.

Home Secretary Suella Braverman has previously said the chant is anti-Semitic and claimed that it is “widely understood” to call for the destruction of Israel, although pro-Palestinian protesters have contested this definition.
A senior Tory source meanwhile stressed to that it was “a phrase widely used by extremists”.
Calls for a Palestinian state “from the river to the sea” – the River Jordan to the Mediterranean – are sometimes interpreted as implying that Israel should no longer exist.
But allies of Mr McDonald said that his comments had been “completely misinterpreted” and insisted the MP was supporting peace between Israelis and Palestinians.
Jeremy Corbyn’s former shadow chancellor John McDonnell stressed that Mr McDonnell had not used the conested chant but “turned a slogan some are concerned about into a peace plea”.

He added: “Now he has been suspended from the Parliamentary Labour Party. This isn’t just unjust it is absolutely nonsensical. It was a brilliant way of turning something that some misinterpreted as a negative into a positive contribution.”
The decision to suspend Mr McDonald triggered an immediate backlash from some in the Labour Party.

The Labour Muslim Network said the decision was “obscene and deeply offensive,” adding: “The fundamental right to live in peace, with liberty and self-determination is one which should be applied to all peoples.
“The only conclusion that can be drawn is that those who have made this decision do not see Palestinian and Muslim life as deserving of this fundamental principle.”

Jeremy Corbyn’s former director of strategic communications, James Schneider, said the decision was “deranged McCarthyism,” adding: “A call for peaceful liberty for all gets you suspended. Through the looking glass stuff.”

North of Tyne mayor Jamie Driscoll, who quit Labour earlier this year, said: “Suspending a great local MP like Andy McDonald for calling for Israelis and Palestinians to live together in peace and liberty is shameful. Sir Keir needs to reverse this decision. Everyone should be calling for peace.”
Matt Wrack, Fire Brigades Union general secretary, said: “The Labour leaders’ office has got this profoundly wrong. Keir Starmer must intervene to reverse this appalling decision.”

Shadow Cabinet minister Darren Jones earlier said “from the river to the sea” was not a phrase that he would use and acknowledged it had “very deeply held connotations for people who are either from the region or have connections to the region”, telling Times Radio: “All of us in politics need to work extra hard to choose the right words.”
A senior Labour source echoed Mr Jones’s comments, adding: “It’s not language the leadership or Shadow Cabinet will be using.”
Asked in a briefing with reporters about the chant during protests, Mr Sunak’s official spokesman said: “We understand clearly this is a deeply offensive chant to many.
“And again, I think people need to be responsible with their use of language.

“Obviously it’s up to the police to make an operational decision about the use of that language if they see fit to do so, but I can understand how the use of that language and others will be of significant concern to many.”

He added: “Right now, communities across Britain, Jewish communities across Britain, need to be reassured that police and indeed the wider Government, national and local are protecting them because these will be deeply concerning times after a traumatic terror event.”

title: ‘I’d never do I’m A Celeb’: Labour’s Mid-Beds by-election hope takes swipe at outgoing Nadine Dorries
lead: Alistair Strathern talks about his speech impediment, plus his views on Corbyn, Blair, Dorries, and feminism
author: Patrick Strudwick

body.text: The headline in The Sun this summer was not ideal for someone trying to pull off a historic by-election win: “Wannabe Labour MP unmasked as ‘zombie’ Greenpeace zealot”. The picture was worse. Alistair Strathern, the man Labour has selected to try to snatch Nadine Dorries’s former seat in mid-Bedfordshire, smothered in white face paint, with red blood marks smeared from his mouth and black streaks trickling from his eyes. He was protesting with Greenpeace last year against the Public Order Act. They were all dressed as zombies.

The nice folk of mid-Bedfordshire – a collection of tiny towns and villages amid lush countryside – are likely not huge fans of zombies. The image jarred too with how Strathern looks out of zombie drag: smiley, svelte, and rubbery faced, with an air of maths teacher about him. (This is no coincidence. Before politics, and before working for the Bank of England, he was indeed a maths teacher).

Impressions matter in politics. And this by-election – to be held on Thursday – matters dramatically to the three main parties. Dorries, who eventually quit after not being given the peerage by Boris Johnson she expected, leaves a Conservative majority of over 24,000. This seat has been Tory since 1931. To lose it would be a kick in the kidneys to the ruling party.

A recent local poll places Labour neck and neck with the Conservatives, just ahead of the Liberal Democrats. The Conservative candidate, Festus Akinbusoye, is the current Police and Crime Commissioner for the area, but following requests by to interview him, the Conservatives said due to his “current commitments” and a “busy schedule until election night” it would not be possible.

But who is Strathern? An “eco zealot”? An Oxford-educated, Bank of England posh boy? On the surface the 33-year-old seems dependable, almost old-fashioned. There’s a whiff of corduroy about him. His manner is upbeat but a tad shy; as if he’s fought hard to be socially confident. The reason for this becomes apparent later, as he talks about his speech impediment, the bullying he received, and his attempts to overcome it. But first, politics, and that picture. Does he regret it?

“I don’t regret the protest,” he says, as we sit in a pub in Shefford with his partner Megan, who works for Greenpeace. “I regret maybe not taking a bit more time over, you know, hair and make-up – if I had known that photo would be front page.” He’s partly joking.

Although the protest was against the Public Order Bill, which was criticised for curbing the right to peaceful protest, his participation in it with Greenpeace, was spun as an eco-warrior stunt. He’s currently on unpaid leave from the Bank of England where he is the climate lead for the insurance sector. Given his dedication to climate causes, is he a vegetarian?
“No,” he says. Meat is one of the key contributors to climate change, so why not?

“Lack of moral integrity?” he replies, laughing, adding a “no” to correct his answer. You’ll definitely regret saying that, I say. “I think there’s a lot more low-hanging fruit for tackling climate change than trying to change every aspect of people’s behaviour. Tackling climate change and doing better by young people are probably my biggest two personal-political passions.”

Voters may wonder where Strathern fits within the left or right of his party, so I ask how he feels about two former Labour leaders: Jeremy Corbyn and Tony Blair. Corbyn was suspended from Labour in 2020 (and then blocked from standing as a Labour candidate) after saying the extent of antisemitism in the party had been “dramatically overstated”, following a critical report by the Equality and Human Rights Commission.

Should Corbyn be welcomed back into the party? “He is yet to apologise for the statement he put out after the publication of a report into some really shocking failings in the Labour Party under his leadership. If he’s not in a position where he can acknowledge the issues … then he has no place in a Labour party that is looking to be a party of government.” And Blair? Was it a mistake to invade Iraq? “Yes,” he replies.

Another politician looms large over the conversation: Nadine Dorries. The superfan of Boris Johnson became widely criticised over her commitment to her constituents. She didn’t speak or vote in the Commons for over a year.

Even the Prime Minister, Rishi Sunak, questioned Dorries’s commitment as a constituency MP in August: “people aren’t being properly represented”. Over the summer a large banner was strung up in Flitwick, the largest town in the area: “DOSSER DORRIES OUT”.
Dorries, for her part, told the  podcast over the summer that she and her team were “working daily with constituents”.

“There’s been a real sense that for the last few years this area has felt taken for granted,” says Strathern. “They haven’t had an MP for a long time now who has felt like they really understand and care for the community. The way Nadine behaved over the last few years, and certainly over the last few months of her tenure, felt like the last straw for lots of people who have seen politics become more and more removed from our communities – typified by someone who took such a little interest in the everyday lives of people here. And that worst stereotype of politicians who are in it for themselves.”
This impression first formed a decade ago when Dorries appeared on ITV’s  Would Strathern ever do a reality show?
I wouldn’t, but even if I wanted to my partner would kill me,” he says, with a glancing smile in her direction. So he can categorically rule out any appearances? “Categorically rule out, yes.”

The Liberal Democrats, meanwhile, could still win in Mid-Bedfordshire, with their candidate, Emma Holland-Lindsay. Strathern has attacked the Lib Dems online for wanting to “legalise drugs”. In fact, they want to decriminalise one drug – cannabis. But are the drug laws working?

“I certainly wouldn’t look to defend this government’s approach to tackling drug crime,” says Strathern, as he attacks the Tory record on combating organised crime such as county lines gangs, amid overstretched police resources. But would he defend the laws against drugs? “Yes”.
Why should police devote their limited resources to combating cannabis when rapists are walking free?

“It’s a truly sad picture of how broken law enforcement has become in this country if you are telling me it has to be an either or,” he says. “It’s so important that we up the number of rapists going to trial.

“It is shocking the low conviction rates, the low prosecution rates, and the understandable deterrence that has on women coming forward because they simply do not have confidence that this system will do right by them. But that cannot be at the expense of continuing to tackle other crime. We have to fund and resource a police force that’s able to do all of that.”
Is Strathern a feminist?
“Yes,” he replies immediately. He is less quick answering the follow-up, about whether he believes feminism should include or excludes trans people.

“What do you mean by that dichotomy?” he asks, looking uncomfortable; aware of the political minefield. I clarify my question: that, for example, some feminists see trans people as fellow victims under patriarchy, and some fear they pose a threat in women-only spaces. Which camp is he in?
“It’s about treating people as human beings, recognising, cherishing that identity and ensuring they’ve got access to all of the healthcare and guidance that that identity requires,” he says.

“But that does not mean disregarding the rights of independent groups, such as refuges, to make distinctions about who they feel they can accommodate safely within that space. I think the Equality Act provides opportunity to make distinctions based on biological gender, where certain institutions feel that it’s appropriate. And for me, it’s absolutely right that refuges have that protection to make that judgement.”

One of Strathern’s five key pledges to constituents in mid-Bedfordshire is tackling the cost-of-living crisis. So why won’t Labour commit to scrapping the cap on benefits to families with more than two children?

He begins by criticising the Conservatives, and “how tired people are of broken promises”, and the “risks of doing too much too quickly” before admitting the bind his party is in. “There are obviously things that we would like to be able to do differently,” he says. If Labour win the general election next year “the complete mess we’re inheriting will restrain our ability to deliver the full range of support we want to”. But he cites certain pledges such as “ensuring no primary school child starts [school] hungry”.

There are policies Labour could deploy that would raise money not cost the government, like increasing income tax on the highest earners. Why not do that? Strathern says they have to be “measured” in what they do and adds instead, “We will close a tax loophole that non-dom citizens benefit from. They can afford to pay more tax in this country and they should.”

And private schools? Some people are confused about what the Labour policy is, as it seemed to change from removing charitable status to now simply removing VAT exemption. Either way, he says it would mean more money to the Treasury “and that feels to me like an understandable prioritisation, making sure we’re not giving that exemption to people who pay school fees at a time when state schools are really, really struggling.”

At first glance, someone could look at Strathern’s life and think he doesn’t understand the struggles of everyday people, and when I ask about what brought him into politics, his answer about seeing vast inequality in Oxford doesn’t seem to cover it, so I begin to probe into his own life.

After his grandmother died, his grandfather came to live with the family. “It became clearer the slow grip of a dementia was taking more and more of him away,” he says. “Seeing the toll that took on him personally, but also my whole family and particularly my mum, was really, really hard.” He eventually had to be looked after in a care home, before he died. It was, says Strathern, “truly heart-breaking.”

As an adult he’s had knocks, in a more literal sense, too. In his late twenties, playing football he suffered a concussion so bad he was off work for three months. “I got quite depressed – it’s a depressing thing not to be able to spend time with your friends, not to be able to do your job, not to know if you’re going to get any better. Because to begin with it was getting worse, not better.”

Now, he wants young people to have better mental health provisions. “The capacity of the system is far below the needs,” he says, particularly with waiting times, and says if elected he will work with mental health charities to try to plug the gaps.

As we talk, there’s something I want to ask but don’t quite know how, because it’s personal. It sounds like he has a speech impediment, a rarity in the harsh world of politics, but one that affects around 1.4 million children in Britain, according to Speech and Language UK.

“Yes, I do,” he says. “I have a slight lisp. I had a much more pronounced lisp as a child. It still comes and goes – it becomes more pronounced particularly when tired and exhausted. I had speech therapy when I was growing up.”

Were kids at school calling him names? “Oh god, yeah – kids are kids. Less so at primary school.”  The bullying, he says, “became more pronounced at middle school and upper school. I became more aware of it in a negative context socially at middle school.” He describes the form this bullying took.

“Negative impressions. Hostile impressions. Physically mocking. That did stay with me. So I think for a very long time after that I was not a very confident speaker at all. There were a lot of reasons why I decided to become a teacher. But I think there was an element of wanting to prove to myself that I could be in front of people, all day every day, and I could do a profession which relied on me speaking. To force yourself to get more confident.”

“There’s no more intimidating audience,” he says, than an unruly classroom on a Friday afternoon. “There’s no more imaginative and fun group of people that want to throw insults at you.” At least going into politics, I say, he has experience of being mocked. He seems to agree. “After that,” he replies, smiling, “anything is a breeze.”

title: What time is Ed Davey’s speech today? When to watch Lib Dem party conference address live
lead: The Lib Dem leader will say “voting Conservative is bad for your health” and pledge to ‘fix our economy with care’ after the Tories ‘broke’ it with ‘carelessness’
author: Alex Finnis

body.text: Liberal Democrat leader Sir Ed Davey will close his party’s conference today with a speech targeted at winning over Conservative voters.
A theme of the conference has been attempting to win over disaffected Tory voters in dozens of “Blue Wall” seats ahead of the next general election.
In his keynote speech today Sir Ed will attack the Conservatives over the economy and the NHS.
The Lib Dem leader will say “voting Conservative is bad for your health” and pledge to “fix our economy with care” after the Tories “broke” it with “carelessness”.
Sir Ed’s speech is the final event of the conference, and is scheduled to begin at . There will be a live stream of the speech, as well as other events from the main stage, on the .
The conference, which started on Saturday, is being held at the Bournemouth International Centre.

The Lib Dem strategy at the next election will be to target traditionally Tory seats, where the party, buoyed by a series of by-election and local election successes, hopes it stands a chance of making significant gains.
Party workers have about 80 seats in their sights where they came second to the Conservatives at the last election.
As such, much of Sir Ed’s focus is on local health services and the environment, which his party believes are crucial to woo voters in places like southern England.

In what could become a catchphrase during the long campaign, Sir Ed will tell conference: “Perhaps there should be a warning on the ballot paper, like there are on cigarette packets: Voting Conservative is bad for your health.”

Sir Ed will tell delegates the Lib Dems are “the strongest campaigning force in British politics” as he seeks to boost party morale, describing conference as the moment the “starting gun” is fired on electioneering.
“I am so proud that we Liberal Democrats have consistently led the way in highlighting the crises in the NHS and proposing solutions,” he will say.
“Reversing cuts to GP numbers and guaranteeing an appointment when you need one, tackling life-threatening ambulance delays, and improving access to NHS dentists.
“Health and care both are key parts of our plan for the economy. The Conservatives broke our economy with their carelessness. Liberal Democrats will fix our economy with care.”
He is expected to add: “Britain isn’t working, because the Conservatives aren’t working. They’re more like a bad TV soap opera than a functioning government.
“The factions and the feuds. The personal vendettas. The shock exits and unwelcome returns. The total lack of connection to reality. Each episode worse than the last.
“Well it’s time to change the channel… The British people are desperate to see the back of this appalling, out-of-touch Conservative Government, and we are the ones who can make it happen.”

title: Keir Starmer is making a mistake by waiting for America’s lead on Gaza
lead: The Labour leader says the party’s biggest enemy is ‘complacency’, yet he appears to have fallen prey to it
author: Paul Waugh

body.text: When Sadiq Khan, Anas Sarwar and Andy Burnham came out in support of a ceasefire in Gaza, it’s fair to say Keir Starmer’s allies were not exactly surprised.

The separate moves by the Mayor of London, Mayor of Greater Manchester and Scottish Labour leader followed similar demands from some of Starmer’s frontbenchers, MPs, local parties and even usually loyal trade unions like Unison.

For the time being at least, Starmer is not budging from his current position of refusing to back such calls for a ceasefire, preferring instead to support “humanitarian pauses” to allow essential aid to civilians.

Unless he changes his mind and changes his party’s official line, it’s perfectly possible that several shadow ministers could resign in protest, especially if reports of Palestinian suffering and deaths mount up in coming days.

But Starmer is in no mood to budge. The primary reason for that is the one that he expressed, albeit ineptly, in the  radio interview that has sparked the backlash of recent weeks: Israel’s desperate need for (and right to) security.

After the truly horrific and traumatising atrocities carried out by Hamas on 7 October, many Israelis believe that attack is the best form of defence, and that going into Gaza to dismantle its military and terrorist infrastructure is the main priority.

Yes, pauses may happen to allow humanitarian assistance, especially if Hamas agrees to an “aid in, hostages out” scenario. But the possibility of any kind of lasting ceasefire looks doomed, at least for several weeks.

Once Israel deems it has met its objectives, it is unlikely to want to get bogged down in administering Gaza and will instead erect a much bigger buffer zone around it, and only then “cease” firing if Hamas stops its rocket attacks. That’s the most likely “ceasefire” on the horizon.

Hamas has said it is open to discussing a truce or “something of that sort” with Israeli officials, having “achieved its targets”. Given those “targets” included the barbaric acts of 7 October, it’s not surprising Israel is in no mood to stop its military retaliation.

Just as importantly, Starmer strongly believes that the West has to stick together and won’t be changing policy unless Joe Biden’s administration shifts its position first. That’s been the pattern so far, not least because the US has the most clout in influencing Israel directly.

That need for Western unity stems from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and both Starmer and Rishi Sunak believe that the only beneficiaries from a fragmented, squabbling West are Russia, and possibly China. In fact, some around Starmer mutter that calls from Jeremy Corbyn and others on the left for a ceasefire in Ukraine have been shown to be naive at best and dangerous at worst.

President Zelensky repeatedly said that a fully-fledged ceasefire – as opposed to humanitarian access for Black Sea grain supplies – would be a reward for Russian aggression. “Just imagine if Corbyn was in charge right now?” is the frequent refrain of Starmer allies – on both Ukraine and Gaza.

It’s true that ceasefires are not always as benign and consequence-free as their backers assume. They’re often a chance to regroup and rearm, a “sticking plaster” solution of the kind that Starmer has rejected in other areas of public policy. But the brute fact is that Ukraine is not Gaza and even some Stamer loyalists want him to stop treating them as if they’re the same.

For one thing, Israel has shown a marked reluctance to side with Ukraine, mainly because its pilots fly alongside Russians over Syria. Its neutrality, beyond offering humanitarian aid to Kyiv, led President Zelensky to complain: “Israel has given us nothing. Nothing. Zero.”

More importantly, the complex and deep-seated nature of the Israel-Hamas conflict can’t be compared to Moscow’s invasion of a neighbouring sovereign state. Ceasefires have proved useful in the past, especially the ones that are harnessed to a genuine attempt to find a two-state solution.

The UK waiting to follow America’s lead can leave it looking impotent too. After US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken met Turkish foreign minister Hakan Fidan, he actually used the “c word”. He tweeted that he had “encouraged Turkey’s advocacy for a ceasefire and the release of all hostages by Hamas immediately”, but deleted the post soon after.

Since then, Biden’s press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre has described calls for a ceasefire from progressive members of Congress as “repugnant” and “disgraceful”. An internal State Department memorandum even instructed its diplomats not to use three key phrases – “de-escalation/ceasefire”, “end to violence/bloodshed” or “restoring calm” – in public statements about the Gaza conflagration.
To some allies of Starmer, calling for a ceasefire is the lazy option which fails to recognise that Israel has to pursue the murderers and that Hamas deliberately uses civilians as human shields.

Yet even some supportive MPs think he hasn’t said forcefully enough that supporting Israel’s right to self-defence is not the same as giving its right-wing government a blank cheque to do as it likes – which many believe is where the British public are, as well as being the right stance.

There are legitimate concerns among some in the Shadow Cabinet at Starmer’s refusal to condemn Israel’s mass displacement order to the residents of northern Gaza, and some MPs want him to condemn the reprisals meted out by settlers in the West Bank.
Starmer’s handling of the Gaza row may have little impact electorally, especially with an election a year away and the cost of living crisis and state of the NHS the key priorities to most voters.

If he’s shrewd, he will allow the dissent from Khan, Burnham and Sarwar, while stressing his priority of balancing the upholding of international law with Israel’s right to root out the terrorists who committed that atrocity.

But working out and stating clearly his own strategy, rather than leaving it to the Americans or to reactive LBC interviews, would help too. Given Labour’s polling leads, Starmer says its biggest enemy is “complacency”, yet on Gaza, he has appeared pretty complacent about the need for clarity of messaging and purpose.

title: After Labour backlash over Gaza, Keir Starmer must learn to listen to those who disagree with him
lead: Labour’s leader is lucky his poor comms have been exposed in Opposition, not government. He needs to find the right words to unite his party and the country
author: Paul Waugh

body.text: When shadow minister Yasmin Qureshi got up in Prime Minister’s Question Time to raise the plight of the people of Gaza, her words were impassioned and direct.
She cited an email from a constituent with family in the Palestinian territory that read: “We are being massacred, relentlessly bombed. Homes destroyed. No water, no food, no electricity.”

Qureshi criticised “the collective punishment of the Palestinian people in Gaza, for crimes they did not commit” and asked how many more must die before the Prime Minister called for a humanitarian ceasefire.
But while Qureshi’s query was aimed at Rishi Sunak, its other, more immediate, target was Keir Starmer – and a very difficult question time of his own.

Her references to the state of siege imposed by Israel were a less than veiled allusion to the Labour leader’s now infamous LBC radio interview on any limits on its reaction to the massacres committed by Hamas.
Starmer’s reply to the question “Cutting off power, cutting off water?” was to say “I think Israel does have that right.”
Although he then went on to say “obviously, everything should be done within international law”, the clip went viral within minutes and sparked a row that has burned through his party ever since.

Later in PMQs, when Sunak said that the UK Government had shifted its position, and was now calling for “specific pauses” in the Israeli bombardment to allow humanitarian aid, it was Starmer who looked more uncomfortable than the PM.

Although it sounds crass to view the awful events in the Middle East through the lens of domestic politics, the reality is that fresh conflict was always going to prove much more problematic for Labour than for the Conservatives.
That’s not just because the plight of Palestinians has long been a concern of Labour Party members. It’s also because Labour has more Westminster seats with a significant Muslim population.

Anger with Labour was certainly highest among the Muslim population after the Iraq War, though more hard-nosed Blairites never tire of pointing out that Tony Blair still won a healthy Commons majority in 2005. And that George Galloway’s Respect party was never more than an irritant.

But it was notable that in the dark days of Jeremy Corbyn’s disastrous election campaign in 2019, he made an election-day stop toBedford, one of the few seats in the South that actually avoided the rout by Boris Johnson. Bedford’s Asian voters stayed loyal, despite everything else.

Although some older hands in Labour despair that the issue of Palestine is reduced to one of religion rather than a territorial dispute, they recognise that anger over a succession of Israeli governments’ marginalisation of Palestinians runs deep.
And even some of those loyal to the Labour leader think that the latest row has exposed some flaws in his operation – both in terms of his communications and his strategy.
Some MPs think that Starmer has spent so much time fighting the left of his party that he has become stuck in a rut of seeing dissent as something to be rooted out.

There’s no question that his aides felt that some of the instant reaction to the LBC interview was done in bad faith. They believed that a fair reading of his admittedly clumsy wording (he claims he was answering an earlier question) would be that he was not backing an Israeli blockade of water and electricity.

Yet it was his failure to swiftly correct that blunder that allowed the problem to fester and grow. It took his spokesman a full week to claim it was all a misunderstanding based on “overlapping questions and answers” on LBC. It took Starmer a full nine days to give an on-camera statement denying he wanted any such blockade.

One former insider tells me: “Because they don’t understand comms and politics in 2023, they have slow creep news cycles that build up on them and shouldn’t be big stories but keep building to crisis point. Nothing has caused any serious damage before so they’ve got away with it, but this is different.” Another party figure said: “It’s not the end of Starmer but it should be the end of his comms people.”

The poor comms were underlined by a post on Starmer’s Twitter account after a visit to South Wales Islamic Centre last weekend, which appeared to suggest the visit had gone well, when in fact there were robust exchanges.

MPs who met Starmer this week say he suggested the ill-advised tweet stemmed from his staff working late on a Sunday night. One source told me that the Labour leader didn’t write that post but when I asked his spokesman who wrote his tweets, I was told the party doesn’t get into such matters of process. Which was not exactly a denial.

Some in the party worry that the whole controversy will confirm their suspicion that Starmer has a split political personality that leaves him conflicted on big calls. One insider says the Labour leader has “a Blairite head with a Milibandite heart”, saying his soft left instincts are in conflict with his ruthless desire to win an election at all costs. Some point out that on Iraq, Starmer was very much an opponent of Blair’s intervention.

Although many in Labour recognise this crisis of internal party dissent needs much more careful management, some suggest there is an upside if it means Starmer changes his operation. Shadow Cabinet ministers like Angela Rayner and Lisa Nandy, previously seen as outside the leader’s tent, have impressed by trying hard to mend fences with those councillors and MPs most upset.
Starmer is in some ways also lucky that this row has blown up while he is Opposiiton, rather than government, as it gives him time to correct the errors.
The irony is that in Parliament, as opposed on radio phone-in shows or online, Starmer has shown the kind of statesmanship that his MPs like.
His early, forthright condemnation of the atrocities inflicted by Hamas was powerful, and in his first PMQs after the attack he struck a more prime ministerial tone than Sunak.

Yet since then, he’s struggled. Some in his party would like him to sound much more like Barack Obama, who wrote this week that “all of us need to do our best to put our best values, rather than our worst fears, on display”.

His comms could be better, so could his outreach to his backbenchers and councillors. But ultimately Starmer needs to find a reasonable tone that reflects what he says are his values of empathy and compassion and justice. In the end, getting that tone right isn’t just about party unity, it’s about national unity too.

title: Labour in crisis as Starmer battles to quell mounting revolt over stance on Israel-Gaza conflict
lead: After a meeting with Muslim MPs the Labour leader put out a new statement condemning the ‘completely insufficient’ level of aid getting into Gaza
author: Chloe Chaplain

body.text: Sir Keir Starmer has told Muslim Labour MPs that the party is committed to two-state solution to resolve the Israel-Palestinian conflict as he sought to hold the party together amid mounting anger over his handling of the crisis.
Labour Party sources said there had been a concerted effort to get MPs and councillors on the same page after disquiet across the party over its messaging around the conflict.

It came as more than 150 Muslim Labour councillors wrote to Sir Keir urging the party leadership to call for an immediate ceasefire in the region, and after resignations of Labour councillors over the past week.

Muslim Labour members have expressed concern over the party’s stance on the Israel-Hamas conflict and in particular an interview Sir Keir gave on LBC after the 7 October attacks by Hamas in which he appeared to suggest Israel was justified in cutting off the water and power in Gaza.
