body.text: Klaksvik is a town of exactly 5,094 people on the island of Bordoy, one of the northernmost of the Faroe Islands. It fits snugly and peacefully between two inlets that lie back to back, forcing the town’s houses along the water’s edge and up the sides of the vast hills that rise on every dry side. Climb a little up any of them and you stare down on a vista of single-storey coloured houses that gives the impression of a cute model village.

This has always been a fishing town; for so long you couldn’t make money from anything else. But, to the rest of Europe, Klaksvik is a football place now. Whatever happens between now and next May in any competition, KI are the story of European football this season. Klaksvik has become a sporting Lourdes, the natural home of miracles.

Vid Djupumyrar, a revamped stadium with only 1,300 seats, is literally and figuratively at the centre of the community – mostly around it is a ring of industry and construction and then comes the residential band. But behind one goal, on Bogota, domestic windows offer the perfect matchday view. A good friend of the club’s media officer, Solby Anna Christiansdottir, lives in one; she often goes to her friend’s to watch the matches through the kitchen window.

To a football tourist, what immediately jumps out is the collection of footballs that sit behind the goal nets. They create a flash of nostalgia for that most precious of childhood discoveries: the found ball. Here it is far more common. In the Faroe Islands, every single outdoor football pitch has an open-door policy. Children can literally walk into the national team stadium for a kickabout. At night, the floodlights are switched on to facilitate further play. That alone is enough to make the heart leap.

The Faroe Islands are a magical place, a land of high peaks and low clouds, of yellow-green pasture and ice-cold, clear water that falls incessantly over jet-black rock. It is impossibly stark and achingly beautiful, less of a sightseeing treasure trove than an all-you-can-see buffet. In other places you ask for directions to the beautiful view. In the Faroe Islands, so the joke goes, you just turn around on the spot.

The journey to Klaksvik from the south is expedited by three sea tunnels, double-laned and often lit in multicoloured shadows. But further north, these tunnels are single lane structures with passing places that feel like driving into the back of a giant’s cave. The changeable weather and omnipresent potential for fog requires car headlights to be on at all times. Such is the lack of traffic that those traversing the side of mountains appear like a string of fairy lights across the landscape.

Little of this terrain may suggest a natural football obsession, but you cannot miss it on the ground. In Klaksvik’s two sport shops, the windows are adorned with shirts of Liverpool, Manchester United and Aston Villa. But the pride for the national team and KI – pronounced “coy-ee” – is just as intense.

To offer a sense of the depth of Faroese football despite the challenges of travel, weather and economy, the territory’s four organised men’s football divisions contain 44 teams, many of which are reserve squads for top-flight clubs. Do some rough maths: 44 squads of 18 players is a conservative estimate of roughly 800 players. There are only just over 7,000 males aged between 15 and 35 in this country.

That in itself is almost unique. In the Faroe Islands, a kid can look out of his bedroom window and have a good chance of seeing the floodlights on the local stadium. If they want it enough and have a reasonable amount of talent, they have a very good chance of playing for that club in league football.

The basic equation is this: everybody plays football here. Go to Sandavagur on Vagar island and get lucky and you can find a view that encapsulates the Faroe Islands perfectly, standing on Dalsbour and looking out over the sea inlet. In the foreground is the Virkishusid Vid Anna-Valloyran football pitch. Behind it stands the beautiful, ornate cream-and-dark-pink Sandavags church. In the background you will occasionally see a fishing trawler heading out from Midvagur. These are the three pillars of life.

Eight years ago, in Klaksvik, Mikkjal Thomassen had a dream for this town and this club: he said that it could become the first ever from the Faroe Islands to play in the group stage of European competition. Christiansdottir and Tormundur Danielsen, head of KI’s “Blue Wave” fan club, both laugh and agree: “Everybody thought that he was crazy, of course.”

Before then, KI’s recent history had been difficult. They won the league title in 1999 but were relegated exactly a decade later. According to chairman Tummas Lervig, who took over shortly before relegation, the problems were not unusual: KI had lost all their best players to other clubs and the money had run out. There had been some European pedigree before, a 3-2 second-leg qualifying victory over Maccabi Haifa in 1995 (albeit after a 4-0 first-leg defeat), but potential had perished since.

“In a way it was healthy,” Lervig says. “It allowed us to clean up everything. We worked with sponsors, gave them new advertising. We had to go to businesses in the community and ask them to play a part. So many people helped us. Somehow it brought us even closer to the people than before.”

The subsequent investment  – most notably from major local fish producers JFK – allowed KI to reverse the talent drain to domestic rivals: HB and B36 in Torshavn, NSI in Runavik, Vikingur in Leirvik. They began to build a squad in which Faroese players combined with Scandinavian imports and the odd recruit from far further afield. In 2019, KI won the title for the first time in exactly 20 years and the first stage of Thomassen’s plan had been fulfilled. Everyone I meet agrees: this was the turning point. KI subsequently won titles in 2021 and 2022.

Under Thomassen, there was European progress too: a first European tie victory, over Birkirkara of Malta in 2018; two in the same season in 2019, against Tre Fiore of San Marino and Riteriai of Lithuania; a Europa League play-off against Dundalk in 2020 (which they lost 3-1 and only reached because of a Covid-related walkover). But let’s be frank: this was a minnow beating other minnows.

“People definitely thought that the club was crazy,” says Lervig. “But that was Mikkjal, and people always slightly believed things when Mikkjal said that they were going to happen. The coach and me as the chairman probably made people shake their heads a little bit, but here we are. And then we started winning.

“Mikkjal was a visionary. When he was offered an undecorated room downstairs in the clubhouse, and was asked what he would want it for, he said ‘tear this wall down and put these machines in here at a cost of £50,000’ because he wanted to have a physical trainer and to strengthen up the players because the goal was to get into Europe. The big difference before him was the lack of clarity on the goals and how to achieve them. He brought that clarity.”

In November 2022, a familiar problem. Norwegian club Fredrikstad – then in the second tier but now promoted under him – approached Thomassen and he left for Norway. Joannes Bjartalid, KI’s No 10 and best player, would leave for the same club.

Thomassen’s replacement was Magne Hoseth, a former Norway international who had spent four years as an assistant coach, was looking for his first job as a first-team manager and had rejected an approach from Vestur 07 in the Faroese league a year earlier. Hoseth laughs when I ask him whether he was sure that he was making the right choice.

“When I arrived, it was about an hour and 15 minutes from the airport and we landed quite late,” he says. We are talking in a lounge that overlooks KI’s pitch. “You go in and out of those tiny places. My eldest kid was sleeping in the back and I thought that my wife was too. And I just said to myself ‘What the f**k am I doing here?’ Going in and out of these tiny villages on winding roads in December.
“The team was stripped. We had lost between six and eight players. At least six were regular or semi-regular starters, including the best player who went to Fredrikstad in Norway with the manager.

“But then we came here, to the stadium, and met the people. And you just feel the love straightaway. I’m not a guy who needs love, but I’m a family man and when you work with players they become your family too. You could just feel the love, feel the heat. So did my wife and children too. Then I knew that this was the right place to be.”

This season, something truly remarkable happened to Hoseth, KÍ and Klaksvik. It began with the hardest draw possible in the first qualifying round for the Champions League: Hungarian champions Ferencvaros, who just three years previously had faced Barcelona and Juventus in the Champions League group stage. At Vid Djupumyrar, they managed a 0-0 draw.

“After drawing at home, we thought that it was going to be a fantastic experience for the players in Hungary,” Hoseth says. “I really didn’t think that we were going to go through. But I did have hope that we wouldn’t f**k up because they attacked us here and that would be the same out there. And we had created a couple of chances. I thought that it wouldn’t be a terrible time.”

By half-time in the away leg in Budapest, KI were 3-0 up. Everybody I speak to during the week I spend in the Faroe Islands says the same thing: it was as if reality had been immediately shifted, their world turned upside down in a glorious way, as if they were watching another team in KI colours from that moment on. Hoseth admits that he had no idea what to say in the dressing room before the second half – he hadn’t planned for this scenario.

“I wanted to go to Hungary, but I couldn’t get time off work at the fish farm,” Danielsen says. “We were all sat in the local pub [a grey house that stands at one corner of the stadium]. We got the penalty kick early on and everybody went quiet – you could have heard a cricket move. And then when it went in, everybody went crazy. We just wanted to pinch ourselves to check this was happening to little old us.”

In the second round KÍ again got the hardest draw, against Swedish champions Hacken. Again they drew the home leg 0-0, again they feared heavy away defeat. Again they scored three goals in the second leg away, but this time conceded three too. With the tenth penalty of the shootout, Vegard Forren – once on the books of Southampton and Brighton without playing a game and now 35 – scored to put KI through. In the stands, Bjartalid, their recently departed star, stood with tears in his eyes. The chairman invited him down onto the pitch to hug his former colleagues.

Forren’s penalty was one of the most significant moments in Faroese football history. Through the vagaries of Uefa competition qualifying and the formation of the Europa Conference League, it meant that KI would at least make the group stage of European competition. Although Thomassen had made his impossibly bold prediction before a third competition was created, we’ll spare him the over-examination of the details. The dream had been realised.

That would have been enough. KI would lose their other qualifying ties (which they did, eventually, despite beating Norwegian champions Molde at home) and then enter a Europa Conference League group stage in which they were grossly out of their depth. They would receive six beatings that were only made worse by the patronising that accompanied them.

You clearly haven’t been listening. On October 5, KI got the most extraordinary result of all. It did not cause as much of a ripple because it came during the group stage and so did not bring with it a landmark achievement. But against Lille, then fourth in France’s Ligue 1, KI managed a 0-0 draw during which the French side failed to have a single shot on target.

“It was a strange feeling after the Lille match because, isolated, I think that’s a far bigger result even than beating Hacken and Ferencvaros because Lille won Ligue 1 two years ago,” Hoseth says. “It’s incredible. That result didn’t get as much publicity. Maybe people started to think that this is a regular thing for us, but I promise you that it isn’t!

“I was so proud, but so disappointed at the same time because, actually, it was the worst match that we played with the ball. They did their job defensively, but not with the ball. We could have created big chances and we didn’t believe enough that they belonged there.”

“I followed Lille when they won the title,” Danielsen says. “They were unbelievable, playing against Paris Saint-Germain, Marseille, Monaco, Lyon and beat them all. So to see them here a few years later, not in a friendly but a group-stage match. It was just the most bizarre thing I have experienced in my life. And they didn’t even beat us!”

Do not sleep on the vast overachievement here. Do not slip into the trap of allowing the Uefa branding to blur the lines between competitors in its competitions. Spend even a few days in the Faroe Islands, hear the amazed laughter at what has happened, and you get it. They have beaten champions of major footballing nations and they have done it repeatedly. They have drawn against Lille with their squad worth hundreds of millions of Euros.

This is not just a tiny club in a tiny town in the fourth smallest of Uefa’s 55 nations by population, after San Marino, Gibraltar and Liechtenstein. This is a semi-professional football club. There are players in the squad who work in the fish factories or as handymen, whose training schedules have to be adapted by the manager because they spend all day on their knees or climbing up and down ladders. Arne Frederiksberg, the top scorer in Champions League qualifying, works as a director for a local wholesale food business. Midfielder Rene Joensen is an electrician.

The same is true of everybody else besides. Chairman Lervig has another job. Media officer Christiansdottir works as a broadcast journalist. On matchday, there are around 60 volunteers who help to get everything ready: washing the kit, preparing the coffee, selling the tickets and programmes. When KÍ have spent time with officials from other clubs in their Conference League group, they cannot believe the comparatively miniscule budgets that have fuelled this run.

“It all blew up because one of the players talked to the international media after the Ferencvaros game,” says Hoseth. “He mentioned that he is only a part-time footballer. Everybody just went mad: what is this team? How can they beat Ferenc if they are not professional?”

“I have been in football as a professional since I was 17 – I’ve never worked a day in my life. So it is a little bit strange for me. The challenge for me is to develop a training course that is demanding but not too demanding. I can’t adapt everything from what I learned on courses. At first it was hard, but we have clearly found a rhythm that works well.”

The immediate assumption is that being part-time would make the scale of the task ten times greater, not without sound logic. But another theory soon emerges: instead, it has fuelled this journey. Several of the players have been offered the opportunity for the club to make them professional in recent weeks and have turned it down.

They want something else to think about. They want to be able to rely upon something other than football for their wage, because then they are playing football purely for the love of the game. The local players are just people of their town, playing for their town.

“That is the special thing about this place,” says Johann Lutzen, editor of the local newspaper  (which translates as Northern Lights). As if to fulfil the prophecy that everybody in this town has been or knows a KÍ player, Lutzen played in the victory over Maccabi Haifa in 1996 and used to be a board director.

“Even if we count all the citizens we are 55,000. But we are still a nation, we have our own dialects. We identify as from where we come from. We wake up in the morning and we are husbands and wives, fathers and daughters, sons and daughters. But we are from Klaksvik and then we are from the Faroes.

“This part of the country has a special pride. We are not the capital. We don’t have all the money coming from Denmark. If we want money then we need to work and we always have. That is the mentality of Klaksvik, that you need to work hard for what you get.”

The semi-professional status ensures that this can never be anything other than a community club, whichever football giants are slain at the bottom of the hills. When KI win, the whole town wins with them and the work rate at the fish farms genuinely increases. When they lose, everyone drowns their sorrows together. It has never been any other way here.

After the away victories in Hungary and Sweden, the population gathered at the end of the sea tunnel that brings you to the top of the town to welcome them back as heroes. These are their heroes because they are their equals embarking on an unprecedented journey. “They are us” as Danielssen says. “You can hug them, you can speak to them, you can invite them out for tea.”

There is the first ever win for a team from the Faroe Islands in European competition proper. Piece out tomorrow on an incredible week with a semi-professional club doing unprecedented things. pic.twitter.com/5YK35dzFva

It is early Thursday evening and we are not in Klaksvik but the capital Torshavn, where the cold wind seeks out the gaps in your clothing with ghoulish efficiency. Uefa’s regulations allowed KÍ to play their first two home qualifiers – against Ferencvaros and Hacken – in their own town, but they were forced to move to the national stadium thereafter. It is a shame, most at the club concede, because home provides a far greater comfort and advantage.

For supporters like Danielsen, a more practical problem: most can only get off work at 4pm at the absolute earliest and that doesn’t leave much time to get home and then journey south across the islands. They are not used to regular midweek football around here and earning money has to come before spending it. Danielsen makes it to a spot behind the goal, drum in hand; many others don’t. The attendance is 1,100, lower than they would have got in their smaller home.

Thursday’s home game may be against another domestic title winner – Slovenia’s Olimpija Ljubljana – but it is also viewed as the most winnable group fixture and such brings with it unexpected pressure.

“Tomorrow is actually the first game where I need to put something extra on the players,” admits Hoseth on Wednesday. “Because we can win – this is the one. But then you look at that Olimpija squad and it still has good international footballers in it. It’s silly – it’s still such a different level. But that’s how it goes here.”

A rise in expectation is something of a theme in this country’s sporting psyche according to Eli Hentze, with whom I spend the day of the game. Hentze is the assistant manager of the national team, a Uefa ‘A’ licence holder and coaching educator. He explains how the pride and determination that is inherent with every Faroese person creates a stubbornness that is both a great strength and an occasional source of some frustration: “They refuse to accept the reality. They see it not as a cemented reality, but as something to be changed.

“So we’re playing someone better, so what? We are the Faroe Islands and we will fight”. That is the attitude of this place. It has not grown out of confidence and certainly not arrogance, but an unshakeable spirit born out of tough lives spent surviving. So when the chance at a dream comes along, you move heaven and earth and rock and sea to give yourself the best shot.

And this attitude is why I have come, to Klaksvik and to Torshavn, although I am scared to admit that to anyone before the game. I am here to report on the miracle but also to witness an extra one. Thomassen’s dream was for KI to reach a European group stage, but what if they actually won a game and went one better even than the guy who everyone thought was crazy predicted? It also happens to be four years to the day since KI won their first title in 20 years. Surely this is the completion of the perfect circle?

We know how this normally ends, a painful defeat during which the bubble doesn’t burst but slowly deflates over the course of an evening and then along comes the patronising from the guy from England. Except that this is KI, who are here to say: sorry, are you still not listening?

Not only do they take the lead through Joensen – the electrician – but 33-year-old striker Pall Klettskard adds to it before half-time and then captain Andreasen – the marine engineering student – heads home a third shortly after it. “Magne’s at the wheel,” sings the Blue Wave in English. They have been infrequently ole-ing every pass since the fifth minute and mock-cursing the opposition in English.

At this point, I don’t really know what to feel and that’s not just because of the wind and rain. I have come to see a minnow, semi-professional club try to punch above their weight and all I’m getting is a… competent football team. They know each other’s jobs. The defend deep and fight. They break quickly. They are absurdly comfortable in seeing out a lead. This is a new reality for me.

As the final whistle goes, people around me have tears in their eyes. The players go over to first the main group of supporters and then the Blue Wave behind the goal, milking the adoration and my god can you blame them? Magne Hoseth congratulates his coaches and then calls for his two little boys to come onto the pitch to play.

Tummus Leirvig strides out too with the walk of a man who could keep going and do a lap of the world if he was given half the chance, spreading the good word of KI. I message Solby Anna Christiansdottir – “Never in doubt!” – and she looks up from the pitch up to me with the same look of disbelief I’ve seen everywhere all week.

In the meantime, news has filtered through from Lille, where the home side have turned around a first-half deficit to take the game and leave KI two points off a qualification position. Win in Ljubljana and beat Slovan Bratislava at home, and that will probably be enough. And why not? Why shouldn’t KI become the first Faroese team to qualify from a European group stage? It’s only reality, after all. And reality is something to be changed.

title: Jordan Henderson playing in front of 696 fans in Saudi Arabia – that’s sportswashing in action
lead: This sure feels like football’s uber-capitalist end game: ludicrously overpaid, ageing players operating at half pace in the sweaty heat of plastic bowl stadia to the entertainment of roughly nobody watching live
author: Daniel Storey

body.text: Roughly in the middle of the main stand of the Prince Faisal bin Fahd Stadium, opposite the TV gantry, a group of 150 or so Al-Riyadh supporters form a small clump and, in their defence, try and make as much noise as possible. Roughly a hundred yards to their left, a hub of Al-Ettifaq fans watch their team lose 1-0.

The stadium holds 22,200, although it is due to be doubled in capacity. The club of Steven Gerrard, Jordan Henderson, Moussa Dembele and Georginio Wijnaldum have been welcomed and then beaten. The reported attendance? 696.

There is a wonderful paragraph on the US website of the Saudi Arabian embassy about the nation’s love of football. It mentions children “scrimmaging on playgrounds”, presumably a football/soccer misunderstanding, and gives a promise that Saudis of every age have taken soccer to heart, which is something that supporters always say to one another.

“There is a professional Saudi soccer league that is wildly popular among Saudis,” is the site’s second claim, a sentence that you’d struggle to beat for powerful energy. “Friends and families often gather to cheer on their favorite teams, both on television and in stadiums.”

Over the first few months of the Saudi Pro League-rebranded power grab, it’s fair to assume that most of the friends and families who have gathered to cheer on their favourite teams have gone for the television option, if at all.

Eight of the 18 Saudi Pro League clubs have an average attendance of under 4,000 this season. Even the highest two, Al-Hilal and Al-Ittihad, leave a combined average 80,000 empty seats in their combined capacities.

The SPL is operating on a 75 per cent empty stadium model. The lowest reported attendance, unsurprisingly between two of the clubs not now owned by the Gulf state, was 133. That was beaten this weekend by Selsey FC of the Southern Combination Division One.

Even the Western media that frothed over a potential power shift has largely lost interest, save ESPN tweeting after every Cristiano Ronaldo goal with a goat emoji because social media isn’t fun anymore.

This sure feels like football’s uber-capitalist end game: ludicrously overpaid, ageing players operating at half pace in the sweaty heat of plastic bowl stadia to the entertainment of roughly nobody watching live.

There is no pretence of organic growth, of using ticket sales to fund spending. You just buy what you want to buy and then comes the boring bit. No worries – another transfer window will be along soon and maybe Mohamed Salah fancies joining the silent disco.

It is easy to find a good deal of this quite funny, so let’s. Henderson, who appears to see morality as a movable feast that depends upon whether he wants to earn mega or mega-mega money, justified this dive into Scrooge McDuck’s pool of coins because he had long been fuelled by a desire to “grow the game”. I suppose it does make it easier if you get to shake their hand one by one and still make it back to the dressing room for Stevie’s post-match debrief.
Riyad Mahrez tweeted that he could “hear and see the fans”, but was not specific on numbers. Do they know that we know that they are being played?

This should be a morality tale. For Saudi Arabia themselves, who possibly presumed that signing some of the most famous players in the world and Jason Denayer might immediately manufacture a footballing culture and are learning that some things require organic growth.

For the broadcasters, who will be acutely aware that nothing undersells a game’s buzz like empty seats – perhaps a return to the piped-in noise of Covid times? For the players, who have dropped so quickly from our radar. When was the last time you thought about Allan Saint-Maximin or Sadio Mane?

But then that misses the point: nobody in charge gives a flying Fahd. This league was not created to provide joy to the masses and the Public Investment Fund’s budget is enough to make revenue a quaint little matter to be readily ignored.

Saudi Arabia wanted a World Cup – no matter how many rules had to be changed in the process – and they have almost certainly got one. They signed the players not to score goals, but to sing like canaries in support of their bid. “Go Saudi Arabia 2034,” was the Henderson message, uttered between vast gulps of Kool Aid.

“If sportswashing is going to increase my GDP by 1 per cent, then we’ll continue sportswashing – I am aiming for another 1.5 per cent,” said Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman on Fox News last week. That is the mission statement and the whole of the law. Football supporters at matches might buy tickets, a drink or a scarf. They are unlikely to increase your GDP. So their presence or otherwise barely matters.

title: Sir Jim Ratcliffe won’t sack Erik ten Hag but Man Utd boss will lose transfer powers
lead: British billionaire ready to rip up the club’s strategy to reduce coach’s involvement in decisions with buyout set to take place ‘within weeks’
author: Mark Douglas

body.text: Sir Jim Ratcliffe‘s faith in Erik ten Hag remains seemingly unshaken by Manchester United’s recent dip in fortunes – but the head coach is likely to have his responsibilities reduced.

A deep audit of the club’s football operation is in the pipeline when his investment is finally confirmed. And this will include,  understands, putting player recruitment in the hands of experts, leaving Ten Hag to coach.
Ten Hag gave himself too much to do, with his preference for former Eredivisie players bringing little reward thus far.

While much has been made of Ratcliffe’s previous proclamations about poor recruitment and a lack of identity, he intends to see for himself what is and isn’t working. A detailed and thorough audit of recruitment processes, the club’s fledgling data operations and how deals are worked on is expected to be set up.

The Manchester-born billionaire is understood to favour the approach adopted by Manchester City, who had CEO Ferran Soriano and director of football Txiki Begiristain already in place before Pep Guardiola had been appointed. “We’re in the same direction, me, the CEO, the sporting directors, the chairman,” Guardiola admitted after Sunday’s derby win. “That is why the club is so stable.”
i exclusively reported earlier this month that former Tottenham head of recruitment Paul Mitchell is a frontrunner to become Ratcliffe’s new sporting director.

Mitchell has just left his role at Monaco, where he lived close to Ratcliffe and “operated in the same circles”. He has also moved back to the Manchester area and is interested in a move to Old Trafford.

However one feels about the prospect of the Glazers clinging on to overall control of the club, surveying the wreckage of another derby demolition by Manchester City it is obvious that new ideas and some certainty around the ownership is required at Old Trafford. Belatedly, it is coming.

has been told that negotiations have accelerated in the fortnight since Sheikh Jassim Bin Hamad Al Thani’s Nine Two Foundation withdrew from the takeover process. Ratcliffe’s Ineos group have been working “night and day” to conclude the investment however neither a resolution nor an announcement on a deal is anticipated this week.

Instead it will be next week “at the earliest” although the expectation is the deal will be rubber stamped well before the end of November. “There’s still confidence the deal will be done,” a source close to the bid told .
But Ten Hag, who Ratcliffe has “only ever been positive about” in private, is unlikely to be under any immediate pressure even after the most awkward results of his tenure.
“Everyone can have opinions on what has gone wrong or what is being done right but until you actually get in there it’s difficult to make those big decisions,” an Ineos insider told .

After a predictably rough weekend for the Red Devils, the size of the challenge that awaits Ratcliffe and his team of football experts was etched out by the scale of Manchester City’s dominance in the derby.
Even if results got significantly worse, though, there is a belief that any mid-season move to replace the manager would send the wrong message.
Managerial instability is not in the club’s DNA and lessons from the missteps of Todd Boehly’s group at Stamford Bridge have been absorbed.

Ten Hag remains in significant credit at Old Trafford both for Champions League qualification and winning the Carabao Cup, a competition they remain in with a repeat of last season’s final at Old Trafford on Wednesday. They remain alive and kicking in a relatively gentle group in Europe too after a dramatic win over Copenhagen last time out.

But few could portray this is a good start to the season. It is starting to look like United – despite the heavily Ten Hag influenced recruitment of the summer – are even going backwards and the former Ajax boss is not entirely immune to criticism.

Ten Hag’s withdrawal of the willing but raw Rasmus Hojlund prompted jeers from a significant number of United fans, which could be read as a sign of impatience with an approach which did not work in the second half. Unlike last season, his substitutions diminished rather than improved his team.

The Dutchman was unflustered. He said that the reason for the game plan fraying at the edges was that a controversial first-half penalty meant he had to redraw his tactics. From going – in his words – “toe-to-toe” with City they had to chase the game and when they became more attacking, they made more mistakes and allowed the champions to dominate.

He deserves credit, at least, for the sense of composure he has brought to the position. United’s due diligence on him included praise for his ability to work under intense pressure and his approach and methodology does not change with results.
Despite the winds of change that are about to sweep into Old Trafford, Ten Hag is likely to stay unmoved.

title: Man City are everything Man Utd aren’t – Erik ten Hag is no closer to bridging the gap
lead: Two goals from Erling Haaland and one from Phil Foden ensured Man City remain just two points behind league leaders Spurs, while Man Utd stay eighth
author: Mark Douglas

body.text: OLD TRAFFORD — This was not one of those vivid, technicolour derby trashings that passes into folklore.

There’ll be no mural depicting the time an Erling Haaland brace undressed Manchester United on their own patch, no songs dreamt up to commemorate this resoundingly routine victory for the European champions.

No reckoning or calls for the overthrow of Erik ten Hag are imminent off the back of this either – the boos at the end were muted and barely audible. Manchester City comprehensively defeated United while toggling between second, third and the occasional foray into fourth gears. It is just what happens these days.

But it is precisely the lack of alarm bells clanging at Old Trafford which are the biggest concern. This is now United’s worst ever Premier League start, a fifth defeat in the league proving the recent late rescue acts were nothing more than a mirage, but it no longer constitutes cracked badge crisis club territory. Mediocrity has seeped into the red and white DNA and a floundering Ten Hag has played his part in that.

He has talked a good game since the summer but what progress have the club really made on his watch? A year ago they were walloped 6-3 at the Etihad and Ten Hag’s terse response garnered him plenty of plaudits. Here was the disciplinarian to shake the club from its torpor.
But a year and some £300m spent later, Ten Hag is no closer to bridging the gap to City and they appear to be falling behind well-managed top four insurgents like Newcastle United and Aston Villa.

Pep Guardiola’s side are some benchmark, with Rodri the midfield metronome and the sublime Bernardo Silva the supplier for chief executioner Haaland, but United were so feckless, their team selection so bewildering that their manager can’t escape his share of the blame.

We are told that Sir Jim Ratcliffe – whose investment and new ideas are imminent and will have been confirmed by their next home league game in November – intends to back Ten Hag. Surely, though, that is just canny PR so as not to unsettle the current coaching incumbent. If Sir Jim is serious about shaking things up, things will have to get better sharpish or his new football committee’s first job will be finding another manager.
What was going through Ten Hag’s head here?

Raphael Varane sat on the bench while Jonny Evans started. “Tactical,” Ten Hag said before the game. But their defensive line was so deep, their back four so flat footed, that City’s buccaneering forward line was always going to make hay against them.

There was no Casemiro in midfield while Mason Mount, the man Ten Hag urged his bosses to win an auction for to offer his team some control over games, sat on the bench. Scott McTominay, a player United have been hawking around for the past three transfer windows, was preferred in his place.

Predictably, there was no control. This is a United team who can’t bend Crystal Palace to their will, so expecting them to weave patterns against last season’s treble winners was a flight of fancy. Counter attack is their best strategy – their only strategy – and at the outset there was a flash of hope when McTominay and Rasmus Hojlund darted decisively to ruffle City feathers.

But City’s class, quality and gameplan were a million miles more convincing. Remember they arrived in a rare mini-wobble, back-to-back away defeats in the league offering rare signs of sky blue vulnerability.

Not here, though. Haaland is supposedly in a bit of a slump and lesser men might have dwelled on being unable to force the issue when Onana scrambled the ball away from his feet a few yards out with eight minutes on the clock.

Was it going to be one of those days? Haaland’s response, when Hojlund’s tug on Rodri in the penalty area was spotted by VAR, was emphatic. He rolled the spot kick passed Onana and bawled at the Stretford End. Chants of “Keano” – a reference to the career-ending injury his father suffered on this ground – encouraged him to cup his ear to the crowd. Those days of red dominance are long, long gone.

Andre Onana was the only measly positive for United and kept them in the game. He delivered a performance of real heft here, pulling off three world class save to keep the game competitive. He took a couple of unnecessary risks with his feet but with his hands he was brilliant, a strong right arm keeping Haaland from scoring four or five.

Contrast the Norway striker to United’s great Dane. Hojlund has something but he is so, so raw. Sent away by a loose sky blue pass just after the half hour mark, he overran the ball and City scrambled clear. It was a rare moment to punctuate the visitors’  dominance.

City scored again after the break, a brilliant move that ended with the sublime Silva overlapping before teeing up Haaland for a header, and United’s resolve dissolved. Phil Foden added a third with ten minutes remaining. It could easily have been five or six.

There are some things this club can still get right and the tribute to Sir Bobby Charlton was pitch perfect, poignant for its simplicity. All four corners of the ground – including the massed ranks of City fans – applauded.
Of course they did. For all the attention afforded a few immature morons last weekend, the real fans were always going to show their true colours.

title: How Newcastle ‘carnage’ shaped one of the EFL’s brightest managerial talents
lead: MK Dons’ new boss Mike Williamson explains his approach to management and how he has brought his philosophy to the Football League
author: Mark Douglas

body.text: Mike Williamson did not give the impression he was a man in a rush.
The view from the office at Gateshead’s International Stadium was dazzling, the autumn sun stretching across the pristine playing surface.
His club – Gateshead – were flying high in the National League, on an upward trajectory that began when Williamson took over as player-manager four years ago at the age of 35.

We spoke about his family, his love of taking training and then picking up his children from school across the city, how he managed to retain perspective and his boyhood enthusiasm for the game through the “carnage” at Newcastle United and how he offered to pay teammates’ mortgages during Gateshead’s darkest days, when bankruptcy seemed certain.

And then there was a long, fascinating chat about his football philosophy and how he had turned the club with the smallest budget in the National League into one of its most attractive teams. As we shook hands on the staircase, there was an open invite to return in the future to watch training.
Then four days and 200 miles later, he was being unveiled as the manager at League Two club MK Dons.

“Football really is mad,” Williamson tells  over a phone call from his new office in Buckinghamshire. “It was not on the cards when we spoke the first time and it all moved fast. It’s one of the few industries where it could happen – you get a phone call and you just go. You’re halfway across the country, away from your family but that is the industry,”

There is a buzz around Williamson, a coach whose philosophy and style of play has turned heads in the National League. After defeat in his first game, his MK Dons snapped a nine game losing streak by thrashing Bradford City 4-1 on Tuesday in a performance of attacking verve. Williamson’s methodology requires time and buy-in, but the early signs are it could be the start of something special for both manager and his new club.

“Of course it was a wrench to leave Gateshead, I didn’t necessarily see it coming but as soon as MK Dons spoke to me, I knew it was a good fit. The club itself has got a way of playing, an identity and that aligns with what I want to do,” he says.

“The short conversations we’ve had have been really good, there’s a project here and the people too. It appealed and all came together. It’s a huge challenge but I’m looking forward to getting on with it.”
