title: When does the Real Living Wage increase? How much pay will rise, and if national minimum wage is going up
lead: So far about 400,000 workers are paid the voluntary Real Living Wage, which is different to the government’s National Minimum Wage
author: Alex Finnis

body.text: The voluntary Real Living Wage is to increase by about 10 per cent to reflect the continuing cost of living crisis for workers, it has been announced.
It means more than 460,000 people working for 14,000 employers who pay the rate will receive a wage rise.
The Living Wage Foundation, which sets the rates, said they will increase to £12 an hour outside London – a rise of £1.10 – and to £13.15 an hour in the capital – a £1.20 increase.

The foundation said the rise, coming into effect on Tuesday, reflects “persistently high costs” for low-paid workers. Employers who sign up for the scheme will have six months to implement the par rises.
As well as the national living wage, which is statuatory and set by the government, there is also the voluntary Real Living Wage.
This is calculated by the Living Wage Foundation, and is based directly on the cost of living.
Aviva, Burberry, Ikea, KPMG and Nationwide are among the companies that currently subscribe to the Real Living Wage, along with football clubs such as Chelsea and Everton.
The rate applies to everyone over the age of 18, and can earn workers significantly more per year than the statutory government minimum.
A full-time worker earning the new Real Living Wage will earn £3,081 a year more. We than someone on the current National Living wage, and an additional £5,323 in London, according to the foundation.
More than two out of five low-paid workers say they regularly use a food bank and almost as many report falling behind on household bills, said the foundation.
Its director Katherine Chapman said: “As inflation eases, we cannot forget that low-paid workers remain at the sharp end of the cost of living crisis.
“Low-paid workers continue to struggle with stubbornly high prices because they spend a larger share of their budget on food and energy.
“These new rates are a lifeline for the 460,000 workers who will get a pay rise.” The foundation said record numbers of employers were signing up to pay the voluntary rates.
Unions  welcomed the raise, but called on the Government to match the effort and pointed out that thousands of workers providing public services will not benefit.
Unison general secretary Christina McAnea said: “This is good news for hundreds of thousands of low-paid workers whose employers do the right thing – that’s pay them a decent wage.
“But many more providing essential public services will miss out. These employees include care workers, who’re often on poverty pay, in a sector already struggling to fill record vacancies.
“Today’s increase means thousands of workers employed by the NHS on the lowest pay bands – like porters, cleaners, domestics and security staff – will be significantly short of the new rate.
“The Government must follow suit and boost the minimum wage so millions are better able to weather the cost of living pressures causing such deep financial pain.”
The increase was announced today , although companies will have six months until to implement the changes.
While people often refer to the minimum wage as a catch-all term, there are different minimum wages.
The  applies to everyone aged 23 and over. The current rate is .
The  applies to people above school leaving age but under 23. The current rates are:
The minimum wage for apprentices is based on people aged under 19, or people over 19 but in the first year of their apprenticeship.
If apprentices are above 19 and have finished the first year of their apprenticeship, they are entitled for the minimum wage of their age group.

at the Conservative Party conference this month, Chancellor Jeremy Hunt announced he planned to raise the National Minimum Wage to at least £11 an hour in 2024, following a recommendation from the Low Pay Commission.
The pledge will meet a 2019 manifesto commitment to increase pay for the lowest paid workers to two thirds of median earnings.
The Chancellor said: “We promised in our manifesto to raise the national living wage to two thirds of median income – ending low pay in this country.

“At the moment it is £10.42 an hour and we are waiting for the Low Pay Commission to confirm its recommendation for next year. But I confirm today, whatever that recommendation, we will increase it next year to at least £11 an hour. A pay rise for over two million workers.
“The wages of the lowest-paid are over £9,000 a year higher than they were in 2010 – because if you work hard a Conservative government will always have your back.”

title: Money Moral Maze: Our lottery syndicate won £3k. Should our friend who always forgets to pay in get his share?
lead: A group of friends have won thousands of pounds on the lottery – but should the winnings be split evenly?
author: Callum Mason

body.text: My friends and I have a lottery syndicate. Every month, the other five send me £10, and I add my own £10 to this.

I then use the £60 and buy a series of lottery tickets and scratch cards for the month. It’s a bit of fun, but of course, usually we never get anything out of it – so much so that they’ve started to question whether I’m using the money to enter (which of course I am!)
This month though, we did finally win. The full amount was just under £3,000 which between the six of, would be more approaching £500 each.

However, on checking my bank account, I haven’t received payments for the last five months from one of the group. I’ve still been entering with £60 on the assumption that everyone was chipping in, but in effect, I’ve been subbing his £10 each month with my own money.
This isn’t entirely isolated. He’s terrible at paying people back, whether it be for drinks, booked holidays, or anything else, even after you chase him.
So should he receive his share of the money, or should we split it between the five of us?
This is tricky dilemma, slightly sweetened by the fact that it is over something positive – winning money – rather than something negative.

Thinking logically, then really, your friend’s money has not actually paid for the ticket that resulted in you winning the money £3,000. Purely on that basis, it immediately seems to me like they shouldn’t receive their split.

There are a couple of extra factors that push me towards this as well. Firstly, you say this has happened for several months, and isn’t unusual. If they had forgotten to pay their share once or twice, or were late with it, this would be a different matter. But the truth is, if you hadn’t won the cash, would you have noticed that they hadn’t paid? Would they have owned up of their own accord? From what we’ve heard, it sounds like the answer is no.

The amount you have won is a large amount, but it isn’t life-changing. Cutting your friend out from receiving their share would be very harsh if you’d won a million pounds or a similarly high figure, where the original £50 or so that they had missed out on paying was small fry in the context of the prize. But in this instance, it’s a fairly large chunk of the pay out.

I’m inclined to say they at least don’t get an even split. Could you perhaps reduce the portion they receive of the winnings? Maybe this is the kick they need to start paying people back in the future.
Lottery syndicates are meant to be fun way to connect with workmates or friends – along with the chance of winning some serious cash.
However, it seems in this case you’re considering not extending that community spirit to those who don’t follow the rules to the letter.

I can understand why it might be a little frustrating to chase someone for money but we all have our quirks and it sounds like your friend’s might just be forgetfulness and perhaps a lack of organisation.
This may be irritating but as a supposed mate, I think it can be forgiven, especially when it comes to this situation.
Imagine you had forgotten to pay a couple of times and then a “friend” refused to hand over the cash after winning the syndicate? Not much of a friend, I would say.
You’ve said this is a “bit of fun” so if that really is the case I would dock the £50 off the £500 and give him the £450. It’s only fair and worth it for the sake of maintaining a friendship.

Going forwards, your mate is more likely to transfer the funds in a timely manner, and you can keep the peace for the group. Withholding the funds will only cause trouble and you have to ask yourself is it worth making things awkward for the sake of a few forgotten payments? Probably not.

title: ‘I refuse to pay council tax because my local authority banks with Barclays which invests in fossil fuels’
lead: Dr Jane McCarthy said she doesn’t want to hand over money to a council that invests in ‘damaging the planet’
author: Laurie Havelock

body.text: A 72-year-old woman is taking a stand against her local council over its decision to bank with Barclays, who invest in fossil fuels, by refusing to pay her council tax, despite being threatened with bailiffs.

Dr Jane McCarthy, from Aylesbury in Buckinghamshire, joined a campaign to urge her local council to withdraw its pension fund from fossil fuel investments before the pandemic, as part of a wider effort across the region.

She then started a solo effort as part of a larger campaign to urge Buckinghamshire Council to stop using Barclays to process council tax payments as the institution “funds more fossil fuel projects than any other bank in Europe”.
As a result, she has withheld paying her council tax since 2022 in an attempt to pressure the council to use a different bank.
“They need to find a better bank,” Dr McCarthy told. “If that doesn’t exist, they should be researching alternatives and engaging with the Barclays management team to stop funding new fossil fuels.”

Non-payment of council tax can result in a court case, but it is typically considered a civil offence rather than a criminal one. Those who don’t pay may be subject to recovery proceedings and the right to pay by instalments could end. People can be sent to prison for up to three months if the court decides you don’t have a good reason to not pay your council tax and you refuse to do so.

Barclays is Europe’s largest financer of fossil fuel projects since 2016, with $190bn (£149bn) invested in them, according to a Rainforest Action Network report. It is Europe’s second-largest funder of fossil fuel expansion, with $55bn provided to such companies between 2016 and 2022.
Several other banks also invest in fossil fuels including HSBC, NatWest and Lloyds. As such, it is likely many other councils will bank with institutions that invest in fossil fuels.

Two of Dr McCarthy’s fellow campaigners lodged an online petition outlining her stance and urging Buckinghamshire Council to divest from fossil fuels and stop using Barclays to process council tax payments, which received enough public support to be read at a council meeting earlier this year.

After trying for some time to engage with her local councillors and encourage them to change who they banked with, Dr McCarthy said she would only pay 90 per cent of her tax bill if the payment did not go through Barclays. She added that she would pay the remaining 10 per cent once the council’s pension fund commits to withdrawing its investments in fossil fuels by 2028.

“They’re asking me to hand money over that’s destroying the future of the planet, because of the way that they’re using it,” said Dr McCarthy. “It’s a matter of conscience. It’s got to the point where they don’t even reply anymore.”

Rather than engaging with her request, however, Buckinghamshire Council appointed recovery agents from Chandlers to reclaim her outstanding council tax payments, which now stand at £1,430.44 for the 2022-23 financial year.

Dr McCarthy is still shielding from Covid-19, after she had several cancer diagnoses in recent years which have impacted her immune system. She asked the council for some assurances that bailiffs would not be visiting her at home – putting her health at risk – or seizing possessions like her car, which she relies on to drive to hospital appointments.
“It means every time I step outside my front door, I’m really nervous,” she said. “I’m worried they won’t follow guidelines. My home is my safe space.”
She added that the council advised that if she neither paid up nor allowed bailiffs entry, she may be liable to committal proceedings or a bankruptcy process because she “willfully” refused to pay.

However, after Dr McCarthy contacted , Buckinghamshire Council confirmed that enforcement agents would not need to visit her home in order to collect payment – though added that Chandlers “will proceed with action against you in respect of the debt outstanding”.
Dr McCarthy, who has two grandchildren, says that she hopes her stand will draw more attention to the issue. “We need better alternatives,” she added.

“People are really unaware about how much our pension money – whether with councils, or private pensions, or workplace schemes – are contributing to fossil fuel investments, and how much we’re destroying the very future that pensions are supposed to be supporting.

“I feel passionately worried about this beautiful planet and the future for my grandchildren, and all the children on earth. It’s bleak and it’s getting bleaker by the day. The way in which we use our finances is a crucial part of what we can do to make a difference.”
Tim Butcher, Buckinghamshire Council’s deputy cabinet member for resources, confirmed that Dr McCarthy’s petition had been heard by the council.
“This petition was presented at our full council meeting on 12 July, 2023 and the content of this petition has now been referred to our cabinet for discussion at a subsequent meeting,” he added.

A spokesperson for Barclays said: “We believe that Barclays can make the greatest difference as a bank by working with customers and clients as they transition to a low-carbon business model, focussing on facilitating the finance needed to change business practices and scale new green technologies.

“This includes many oil and gas companies that are critical to the transition, and have committed significant resources and expertise to renewable energy. Where companies are unwilling to reduce their emissions consistent with internationally accepted pathways, they may find it difficult to access financing, including from Barclays.”

title: What time is the interest rates announcement today? What to expect from Bank of England base rate update
lead: Inflation is one of the main factors that influences whether the Bank of England chooses to raise or lower the base interest rate
author: Alex Finnis

body.text: The Bank of England will announce its latest interest rate decision today, with analysts widely predicting them to hold steady again.

It comes after inflation stayed flat at 6.7 per cent in the year to September. Economists had predicted a slight fall, but higher petrol costs and the price of hotel stays resulted in the rate staying put, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said.
Inflation is one of the main factors that influences whether the Bank chooses to raise or lower the base interest rate.
The base rate determines the interest rate the Bank pays to commercial banks that hold money with it. It also influences the rates those banks charge people to borrow money or pay on their savings.
The Bank generally raises rates to combat inflation. The logic is that if borrowing is more expensive, then people have less money to spend, and so there is less demand for goods and services.

This is why is has been raising rates so consistently over the last two years, as it attempts to bring inflation back towards its eventual 2 per cent target, down from a high of 11.1 per cent in October 2022.
Earlier this year, when inflation sat above 10 per cent, Rishi Sunak pledged to halve it by the end of 2023, meaning it would sit at just above 5 per cent by December.
Here’s exactly when the Bank will make its next announcement, and what to expect.
The Bank of England’s monetary policy committee (MPC) reviews and updates interest rates every six weeks. Its next decision will be on , with the announcement expected at .
The MPC last updated interest rates on Thursday 21 September, keeping them at 5.25 per cent.
It was the first time since November 2021 that it hadn’t upped rates, following a record 14 consecutive increases.
Forecasters have suggested that, with inflation remaining at 6.7 per cent, the MPC is likely to  in November.
Paul Dales, UK economist at Capital Economics, told  there would not be any more rate rises this year, but warned that “we don’t think rates will be cut until late in 2024”.

Stephen Millard, deputy director at the National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR), said: “I feel that the MPC has done enough. I think 5.25 per cent is going to be the peak which means there will be no change in November and December.
“They need to hold rates up there long enough to get to the 2 per cent inflation target. We should get inflation to target in two years.”
However, one former MPC member said there was a case for “a precautionary increase” to head off any impact of the Israel-Gaza conflict on inflation.
Willem Buiter, who used to be part of the MPC, said he expected no rise on Thursday, but believes there is a strong case for rates to go up.
He told : “I think the bank rate will be left unchanged at 5.25 per cent, following a likely similar decision on Wednesday by the US Federal Reserve.

“I do think rates will rise when there is greater clarity about the evolution of the Middle East conflict. With the CPI inflation rate at 6.7 per cent in September 2023 and CPI core inflation at 6.1 per cent, policy rates (and long-term rates) will have to be higher for longer to get inflation back to 2 per cent in a sustainable fashion.

“The MPC is likely to interpret the need for greater caution as an argument not to raise bank rate. I believe it may actually strengthen the case for a precautionary increase in bank rate, as the conflict in the Middle East boosts the odds of another inflationary impulse (through a rise in oil and gas prices) but not of another direct disinflationary impulse.”
Some economists, meanwhile, are calling on the Bank to lower rates due to growing concerns of an impending recession.

Trevor Williams, a former chief economist at Lloyds Bank, said the Bank needs to “act now”, adding: “There is mounting evidence that the UK’s monetary policy could lead to a potential recession in the interim.”

Politicians have also joined the calls for rates to be cut. Former Tory leader Sir Iain Duncan Smith told : “We’ve already seen the latest figures on broad money (the measure of the amount of money circulating in the economy) and it is heading downwards at a rate of knots.

“It is sending signals that we may well have overtightened and that we need now to think seriously about getting growth back into the economy. If the figures are right (on broad money), it might suggest if we are not careful that we are heading into a recession.
“We have to now be very careful about doing more tightening. If the Bank of England was to raise interest rates, I think it would be very damaging. I would prefer that they cut them.”

title: Iain Duncan Smith joins growing calls for the Bank of England to cut interest rates amid recession fears
lead: ‘We may be in recession if we’re not careful,’ the former Conservative leader warned
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: Iain Duncan Smith has joined growing calls for the Bank of England to lower rates as it prepares to announce its latest interest rate decision on Thursday amid growing concerns of an impending recession.
Sir Iain, the former Conservative leader and secretary of state for work and pensions, joined leading economist Trevor Williams in arguing that the Bank should start to lower rates.
The Bank’s Monetary Policy Committee is is widely expected to hold rates at the current level of 5.25 when it meets on Thursday.
Sir Iain told : “If the Bank of England was to raise interest rates, I think it would be very damaging. I would prefer that they cut them.”
Trevor Williams, a former chief economist at Lloyds Bank, also called for a rates cut.
He said: “There is mounting evidence that the UK’s monetary policy could lead to a potential recession in the interim.”
Unemployment has risen to its highest level since 2017, at 4.3 per cent. High unemployment can be a signal of a recession ahead.

Danny Blanchflower, a former member of the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) and outspoken critic of the current regime at the Bank of England, added: “The UK economy is clearly slowing. This is no time to raise rates – high unemployment has a worse impact on well-being than high inflation.”

The Institute of Economic Affairs – a free-market think-tank, of which Mr Williams is one of its economists- said it is concerned that the current rate 5.25 per cent base rate is “excessive” and has called on the Bank to decrease rates by 0.25 percentage points when it meets tomorrow to 5 per cent.

Sir Iain added: “We’ve already seen the latest figures on broad money and it is heading downwards at a rate of knots. (Broad money is a measure of the total amount of money circulating in the economy.)

“It is sending signals that we may well have overtightened and that we need now to think seriously about getting growth back into the economy. If the figures are right, it might suggest if we are not careful that we are heading into a recession.
“We have to now be very careful about doing more tightening.”

It comes as it was announced that the number of businesses filing for insolvency has hit the highest level since the financial crisis in 2009. Some 6,319 businesses tipped into insolvency in the second half of this year as medium-sized business are now under financial distress, as well as smaller ones.

So far this year, Britain has narrowly avoided a recession, however the Bank’s economic forecasts which will be announced alongside a rate rise tomorrow, could show weakened activity projected for later in the year.
A recession is usually defined as when GDP falls for two three-month periods – or quarters – in a row.
“We might not get an official recession, but it’s still going to be miserable,” said Dr Edward Jones, a senior lecturer in economics at Bangor university.
“I don’t think rates need to be cut now to avoid recession,” added Alastair McQueen, head of savings and investment at Aviva.

“We need confidence, not surprises. The economy has shown remarkable resilience, despite everything that has been thrown at it. The Bank seeks to perform a delicate balancing act – to ensure inflation maintains its downward trajectory, with high rates, without pulling the wider economy down with it. Cutting rates too quickly could dent this fragile confidence.”

At the moment City traders are expecting the MPC to hold interest rates where they are. The expectation is for rates to be maintained where they are for possibly a year, unless developments in the Middle East see energy prices go higher which in turn could increase inflation.

This approach, to leave rates where they are to calm stubborn inflation, has been coined “table mountain” by the central bank’s chief economist Huw Pill, referring to the flat-topped peak that looms over Cape Town in South Africa.

A group campaigning for a fairer money and banking system, Positive Money, is also calling on the Bank of England to decrease rates. It says that high interest rates are not tackling the issue of inflation – and it wants the Government to step in to increase taxes on banks and use this to help families struggling with the cost of living.
In the past two years, the Bank of England has raised interest rates 14 times – sending households’ mortgages soaring in the process.

Daniela Gabor, an economics professor at the University of the West of England told  this summer that inflation in the UK “is not an excess demand phenomenon that can be addressed through interest rate rises.”

title: Premium Bonds winners November 2023: Winning NS&I numbers this month and how to check if you won
lead: Two premium bond holders – one from the West Midlands and one from West Sussex – win this month’s top prize of £1m
author: Alex Finnis

body.text: Two premium bonds holders – one from the West Midlands and one from West Sussex – are the lucky recipients of this month’s top prize of £1m.

The first bond number drawn was 060PS313350 and is held by a winner based in the West Midlands. The winner has a holding of £5,050 in premium bonds and purchased their winning bond in May 2000. They become the fifth jackpot winner from the West Midlands.

The second millionaire is based in West Sussex and holds Bond number 466PQ093728. The winner has £50,000 in Premium Bonds and purchased their winning Bond in August 2021. This win makes them the 12th millionaire from West Sussex.
In the November 2023 prize draw more than 5.7 million prizes will be handed out in total, worth more than £471m.
Premium bonds are one of the UK’s most popular ways to save, and can be a fun option just as long as you’re happy to accept that there’s no guarantee they will offer a consistent income.
The form of investment is offered by National Savings and Investment (NS&I), a savings bank owned by the Government.
Instead of earning regular interest on their money in the usual way, holders of the bonds are entered into a random draw at the start of every month, with tax-free prizes worth between £25 and £1m.
The prize fund rate has increased significantly this year – reflecting the UK’s rising interest rates – and currently stands at its highest point in almost a quarter of a century.
If you hold premium bonds and want to check if you’ve won a prize in the latest monthly draw, you can use the NS&I online prize checker here.
Alternatively, you can download the free app from iOS or Android, while Amazon Alexa devices can also check for you, “remembering” back across the past six prize draws.

To check on your Bonds, you will need your unique holder’s number, which can be found on your bond record or by logging into your account on the NS&I website. It will have either nine of 10 digits, or be an eight-digit number with a letter at the end.
Prizes don’t carry a time limit, so you can claim as far back as the original 1957 draw.
According to MoneySavingExpert, as of November 2021 there were more than two million unclaimed Premium Bonds prizes, with a total value of almost £75m.
To reduce the potential for leaving prizes unclaimed, premium bonds holders can opt to have them paid directly in their bank account or automatically reinvested into more Bonds.
NS&I says that almost nine out of 10 prizes are now paid this way, and you can find out more details here.
At the start of this year, the interest rate of its prize fund rose from 2.2 per cent to 3 per cent, before increasing further to 3.3 per cent.
In July it took a further increase, to 3.7 per cent, then jumped again to 4 per cent ahead of the August draw.
NS&I raised the prize fund rate again for September, with a – the highest since March 1999.
This change means the odds of any single bond winning have also improved, from 24,000/1 in July to 21,000/1 – their best level since the April 2008 draw.

title: How I Manage My Money: Office administrator on £21k who’s taken £9k from pension to pay off credit card debt
lead: Lisette Davidson said she hasn’t always made the best decisions when it comes to her finances
author: Jane Denton

body.text: I take home between £1,350 to £1,650 per month from my job. My commission can be up to £300 a month. My annual salary is around £21,000.
My children, who live at home, pay us £500 each a month for their keep. Nick, who I’ve been married to for over 35 years, is a house husband.

Mortgage, groceries, £600; council tax – this includes water, £143, electric, £250, money into savings, anything from £1 to £150 per month, money into work pension, £35, broadband, mobile phone and landline, £50, life insurance, £18.58, home insurance, £27.32, hobbies like camping or buying magazines, £15. I walk everywhere and don’t drive so I have no fuel costs. I never eat out and for day trips out, we make our own entertainment!

I was born in America, but grew up in Scotland. My parents divorced when my sister and I were very young and money was tight. I remember often being hungry and there sometimes being no heat or lights on at home.

I started working in hotels from the age of 13, doing everything from being a chambermaid to waitressing. Later on, I got a job working for an electronic point of sale company. After working at the company for 15 years, I took voluntary redundancy in 2015. For a long time I felt rudderless. We lived on my £10,000 voluntary redundancy pay for over two years, and just before it was about to run out and we considered selling the house, a former colleague asked if I’d like to join his new company.

I now work in the same office with many of my former colleagues in my current job as a sales and office administrator. Before deductions, my salary is about £21,000 a year. On a monthly basis, my salary is between £1,350 and £1,650 per month, including commissions of up to £300 per month. It would be great to be earning £25,000 a year.

I have my dream job and recently increased my retirement age to 70. Thanks to my qigong regime (an exercise scheme) I feel fit, healthy and unwilling to give up my job. I love it and do not want to do anything else. I have no desire to stop working and stagnate.

I add £50 to my work pension each month and have about £30,000 saved up in all my pension pots. I might increase my monthly contribution to my work pension at some point. I haven’t really given the state pension a thought and have no idea how much I’d get for that.

I haven’t always made the best decisions when it comes to my finances. I never learnt to budget or manage my money as a child and believe this is part of the reason I got into debt. I was used to having no money as a child, so when I did start earning, I took on the spend, spend, spend approach.
In the past, I’ve had an adverse credit score. I used to think of credit as free money and made some very foolish decisions while acting as if I had more money than I did.

Early on in my working life, I was in more than £11,000 worth of credit card debt. It became insurmountable and I went to Citizens Advice, who introduced me to a debt charity. I eventually got an individual voluntary arrangement sorted out. I paid off all of that debt, but then it began to creep up again as I still had multiple credit cards. These were high-interest ones to start with, but gradually I began moving them over to 0 per cent interest deals and paying them off until I had paid them all off.

However, I have had further credit debt to pay off since. Earlier this year, I took out £9,000 from my pension to get £8,000 worth of credit debt paid off. I reasoned to myself that this was the most sensible use of the money. In January I was finally able to clear the credit card debts, close the accounts and cut the cards up.

I used the remaining money I withdrew from my pension to update our kitchen. It’s been a slow and soul destroying process getting my credit card debts paid off and I didn’t want to reach 60 with these millstones weighing me down. I’m pleased I’ve made progress and the sense of freedom is immense.
I don’t have any stocks or shares and only put money into a cash savings account with the Bank of Scotland. I’m not sure what the interest rate is, but I don’t think it’s very high.

The house we live in now, which is semi-detached and has three bedrooms, was a council house and we purchased it for £48,000 in 2000 while we were living in it. It was a struggle to afford it, but I’m glad we did. Over the years, we’ve remortgaged twice and added to the mortgage to do things to the house.
In recent months my mortgage has leapt from £215 to £499 per month. The interest rate on my standard variable rate mortgage is currently 7.55 per cent. I hope it will now stabilise.

In 2007, with my income at the time, all I could get was a half interest, half repayment mortgage, also known as a half and half mortgage. There are 14 years left to run on it and to this day there is still no vehicle in place to cover the £40,000 that remains on interest only. The repayment balance is only £23,000. I have recently gone to both my bank and current mortgage provider to ask if the mortgage can be changed to a repayment only one, or if an appropriate remortgaging deal was available. I passed the credit score requirements, but failed the affordability criteria, which is a source of frustration for me.

Unfortunately, no mortgage provider is able to count the keep money that our children pay to us as income. Consequently, it looks, on the surface, as if I don’t have enough income to be able to afford to pay off a repayment only mortgage. I’m keen to remortgage next year when I turn 60 and take out a 10 year repayment only mortgage, so it would be paid off by the time I’m 70. If my affordability rating improves, I might be able to do this.

I do not find money important, but I always know exactly how much I have in my bank account. I keep a paper budget in a loose leaf folder and make a note of all my expenditure. Having made mistakes in the past, this gives me a sense of security. Money doesn’t buy you happiness, but it can bring a gilt-edged form of misery.
When I eventually retire, we might sell the family home and relocate to the Cornish coast, where Nick grew up.

title: The growing movement demanding an end to high interest rates
lead: The base rate has rocketed from a record low of 0.1 per cent to 5.25 per cent – a level not seen since before the 2008 financial crisis
author: Callum Mason

body.text: A group of financial campaigners is calling on the Bank of England to not only keep interest rates where they are when they meet tomorrow – but to decrease them.

Positive Money, a group campaigning for a money and banking system which “supports a fair, democratic and sustainable economy”, believes that the high borrowing costs currently punishing families with mortgages are simply not working.

It says that high interest rates are not tackling the issue of inflation – and it wants the Government to step in to increase taxes on banks and use this to help families struggling with the cost of living. In the past two years, the Bank of England has raised interest rates 14 times – sending households’ mortgages soaring in the process.

The base rate – the rate at which the Bank lends to commercial banks – has rocketed from a record low of 0.1 per cent to 5.25 per cent – a level not seen since before the 2008 financial crisis. The Monetary Police Committee decides where rates should be, and will announce its next decision at noon tomorrow.
Although the increases have added thousands of pounds per year on to the housing costs of many, the logic has been that this will all be worth it.

Inflation – the rate at which the costs of goods and services increases – was sitting in double-digits last year, and is still at 6.7 per cent, more than three times the target rate of 2 per cent. The orthodox thinking is that an increase in borrowing costs is the key tool to get this number down – by squeezing peoples’ finances, so that they spend less, and prices are forced to ease.

But if you had visited the Bank’s Threadneedle Street home on any of the days when it announced its increases to the base rate this summer, you would have seen campaigners from the group vocally arguing against this.“We definitely do not want the MPC to increase rates any more,” explains Positive Money’s head of campaigns, Hannah Dewhirst. “They’re a blunt tool for fighting the situation we’re in, and they are really an instrument of inequality,” she says.

She believes that the high rates currently been seen are causing “enormous harm” to mortgage holders and renters – who are often seeing landlords’ costs passed on to them – and are “increasing unemployment and suffering” – by slowing down economics activity – but most crucially, she does not think they are working in their aim.
Conventional economics suggests that if you push up the costs of borrowing, and quell spending, you reduce demand, and this is what reduces inflation.
“That’s not what caused this crisis” says Dewhirst. “This is a supply-side crisis, and the Government has not stepped in, in the way that is needed.” This view is one that has been expressed before.

Daniela Gabor, an economics professor at the University of the West of England told  this summer that inflation in the UK “is not an excess demand phenomenon that can be addressed through interest rate rises,” while Martin Lewis, founder of MoneySavingExpert.com, tweeted back in May: “I’m no economist, but I struggle with the logic behind base rate rises currently. Inflation seems supply-side driven – but rate rises dampen demand.”
The right wing think tank, the Institute of Economic Affairs, agrees with Positive Money, saying the Bank should cut interest rates to avoid a recession.

Trevor Williams, Chair of the Shadow Monetary Policy Committee and former chief economist at Lloyds Bank, said: “There is mounting evidence that the UK’s monetary policy is too tight and could lead to price deflation in a few years and potential recession in the interim. The Bank of England should act now by lowering interest rates.”
Rates could now be at their peak, with much of the added pressure on households already being seen. So what else is Positive Money calling for to fix things?

The group wants to see a “windfall tax” on what it says are banks’ “ballooning profits”, and then says the excess money raised – which it claims could be £20bn – should be used to support struggling households. How would it do this? It wants to see the bank surcharge ratcheted up from 3 to 35 per cent.

The likelihood of current Chancellor Jeremy Hunt doing this seems to be close to zero, especially given the rate was recently cut from 8 per cent, but if it hypothetically was possible, is the group not worried that it could add more fuel to inflation, given it would put more money into people’s pockets?

“Firstly, we don’t think that would happen – because as we’ve said we don’t think that’s the cause of inflation” says Diwhurst. “Secondly, even there was a slight uptick in the figure, it’s still worth doing because people are literally living in extreme poverty with foodbank usage through the roof. We should be supporting people who need it rather than continuing to reward bankers” she says.

Again, though this view that an increase in inflation can be justified is not typical by any means among mainstream economists, the group are not alone. Danny Blanchflower, a former member of the Bank of England’s MPC who consistently voted for rate cuts during the financial crisis, is another who has espoused the view that sometimes, the cure for high inflation can be worse than the disease.

Part of Blanchflower’s work has been in a field known as the economics of happiness, and in a paper entitled “The Happiness Trade-Off between Unemployment and Inflation”, he and others conclude: “A one percentage point increase in unemployment lowers wellbeing nearly six times more than an equivalent rise in inflation.”
“In a nutshell, unemployment hurts more than inflation,” it concludes.

Although economic thought like this is often referred to as “heterodox”, in that it radically differs from the norm, there will be those who continue to argue that the approach the policymakers and bankers have taken to this current cycle of high inflation has been the wrong one, regardless of whether rates increase again this week or not.
We want to hear from you about any thoughts, worries or trends related to money that you might have noticed.
Is there a story you want to tell or a company you think has wronged you? Do you want to perhaps highlight something you think isn’t receiving enough coverage?
Let us know: money@inews.co.uk

title: It used to be the rich and poor that retired early – now it’s only the rich
lead: People are having to work longer to save up enough more for their retirement
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: Poorer people are less likely to be able to retire earlier now than they were 20 years ago, a new study shows, while richer people are more likely to stop working ahead of the state pension age of 66.

Between 2002 and 2003, the number of those who retired between the age of 55 to 64 was fairly similar across the wealth distribution, according to findings by the think tank Institute of Fiscal Studies (IFS).

It found 20 per cent in the poorest fifth of people were retired compared to 28 per cent for the wealthiest fifth, suggesting their income level was less likely to determine their chances of retiring early or not.
In contrast, by 2018-19, only 7 per cent of the poorest fifth were retired, while for the wealthiest fifth it was 24 per cent.
This is likely to have been impacted by the cost of living crisis meaning more people have to work for longer in order to survive.
As a result, average people have had to work longer to build up a sizeable pension pot as economic times get tougher and bills get more expensive.
Fewer people having a final salary pension (also known as a defined benefit scheme), which pays a retirement income based on your salary and length of service, could also have played a part.

The schemes are often seen as unpopular due to their inflexibility when it comes to making withdrawals. You can’t vary the income you take from it or draw out larger lump sums, apart from the tax-free lump sum offered by some final salary schemes.

Steve Webb, partner at consultants LCP said: “Those who have the privilege of a generous final salary pension can often enjoy the option of an early retirement with enough to live on until the state pension cuts in. But growing numbers of people do not have this luxury.

“Many are struggling to build up a pension pot big enough to support them once they get to pension age, and few can afford to stop early.  For those on lower incomes, stopping early is less likely to be a choice and more likely to be forced upon them by a mixture of poor health or difficulties finding decent work.
“The low level of pre-retirement benefits means that this group can face a very tough period between stopping paid work and starting to draw a state pension”.

The discrepancy in retirement finds can also be attributed to ill health, IFS research shows. Increasingly, the wealthiest in our society are able to retire early while those with a smaller income are likely to stop working due to ill health.
Some 39 per cent of the poorest fifth of people in 2018-19 were not in the labour force but not retired as most of them reported themselves as permanently sick or disabled or looking after family.
This is unchanged from 2002-03 and compares to only 9 per cent of people in both the middle fifth and the wealthiest fifth.
Those in the middle are the most likely to remain in paid work until state pension age.
Although many more people are in employment in their late 60s and early 70s in England, compared to 20 years ago, the patterns of work are very different to those seen below the state pension age.

Wealthy people are disproportionately likely to be in paid work in their early 70s. Among people aged 70 to 74, the employment rate is 15 per cent for the richest fifth, compared to 11 per cent for the middle and 6 per cent for the poorest fifth.
This is consistent with existing research that finds that those who work beyond state pension age often do so because they enjoy the work or to keep active, rather than for financial reasons.
People working above state pension age are disproportionately likely to be self-employed or working fewer than 16 hours per week.
Jonathan Cribb, Associate Director at IFS and author of the report, said: “As some in their late 50s and early 60s accumulate high levels of wealth, they take the chance to retire early.
“In contrast, the poorest in this age group often stop work for other reasons, most notably poor health, and spend long periods on state benefits.

“One of the most remarkable changes of the last 20 years has been the big increase in the numbers of people on average levels of wealth who carry on working until their mid 60s, and this is not simply due to increases in the state pension age.
“These people often don’t have the financial security to retire – for example many have an outstanding mortgage.”

title: Scottish Widows pulls mortgages for new customers as property market weakens
lead: Mortgage approvals have fallen in recent times as people cannot afford to buy or move home
author: Grace Gausden

body.text: Scottish Widows has pulled all mortgages for new customers purchasing and remortgaging as the number of people applying for home loans plummets.
The lender, one of the smaller in the market, said it was simplifying its offerings and will instead focus on the lifetime mortgage market, including equity releases.
It is being speculated the pension and insurance company owned by Lloyds Bank is dropping its mainstream offerings due to the large drop in mortgage approvals.

Figures published by the Bank of England show the number of new mortgages obtained fell to 43,300 in September. This is 35 per cent lower than in September 2019, prior to the pandemic. Approvals for remortgaging dropped to 20,600, the lowest number since January 1999, and last week Santander revealed that it is currently lending £1bn less a month than last year.

Higher borrowing costs and the cost of living crisis have contributed to people finding it difficult to make the sums work to buy or upsize, as well as fewer people wishing to buy as they wait to see if prices drop further.
“Scottish Widows could think that now is the right time to change the dynamic and restructure their group,” said Nick Mendes, spokesperson for John Charcol brokers.
Scottish Widows’ specialism for later life products could also have an impact on the decision, experts say.

Aaron Strutt of brokers Trinity Financial added: “It is a tougher, more competitive market and perhaps so it may be that Scottish Widows is focusing on being a recognised specialist lifetime brand rather than struggling to compete in the mainstream markets.”
Mortgages for new customers will be removed from sale on Friday 17 November but any applications submitted up to Thursday 16 November will be able to proceed to offer and completion as normal.

Lifetime mortgages, where you take out a loan secured on your home which does not need to be repaid until you die or go into long-term care, are unchanged and new applications for these can be submitted as normal. The interest on this type of home loan is added to the loan amount (and compounds), rather than paid off monthly. This means how much you end up can be sizeable.

Scottish Widows were the largest provider in the offset mortgage market, a type of loan that lets you link your savings accounts to your mortgage. Typically you get no interest on your savings but it reduces your loan size by the amount of your savings, so you pay interest on less.

Mr Strutt said there has been an increase in demand for this type of mortgage as mortgage rates homeowners continue to use their savings to offset the higher interest rates while still having access to their cash.

The latest data from the Financial Conduct Authority’s Mortgage Lending and Administration Return shows that in December 2022, there were 830,000 offset mortgages – a total of 7 per cent of all mortgages in the UK.

Lenders offset the total balances of your linked accounts against the amount you owe on the mortgage each month, and then work out your mortgage interest on the lowered balance. For example if you have a mortgage balance of £100,000 and offset £20,000 in savings, you will only be charged interest on £80,000.
Whilst the narrower niche of offering offset mortgages has helped Scottish Widows to be more flexible and bring in customers, it hasn’t always maintained the same profile in recent years.
Mr Strutt said: “Scottish Widows really is one of the go-to lenders when it comes to offset mortgages, but the brand has been struggling to get enough business for years.
“There are other lenders offering offsets like Accord, Barclays and Coventry Building Society, but for the moment the withdrawal will mean there are a lot less offset rates available.”
He said it seems unlikely other lenders will pull their offset mortgages for the moment but added hopefully this is an opportunity for the other banks and building societies.
Mr Mendes said: “It remains to be seen now whether Lloyds or Halifax, within the same group, will take on offset mortgages.”

A Scottish Widows spokesperson told: “Scottish Widows Bank’s business has naturally become more focused on lifetime mortgages, with other borrowing needs served by our other brands. This move reflects and cements that position in the market.”

title: 7 reasons Apple TV+ is worth the money – even after the price hike
lead: Streamlined, easy to use and with a carefully curated selection of (mostly) excellent content, this streaming service is the best value
author: Emily Baker

body.text: Netflix, Disney+ and now Apple TV+ – just as our collective purse strings are being pulled tighter, the streaming services are upping their prices. It might be basic economics, but that doesn’t make it any easier on those of us who have had to make a tough decision on which of our subscriptions to cancel.
Apple TV+ has just one simple subscription tier, the price of which has risen from £6.99 to £8.99. It might not sound like a lot, but that’s an extra £24 a year. Is it even worth the money?

I’m afraid so. If I was going to only live with one streaming service for the rest of my life, Apple TV+ would certainly be the one I would choose. Streamlined, easy to use and with a carefully curated selection of (mostly) excellent programmes and films, I firmly believe Apple’s streaming service is the best value for money. Here’s why:

The number one reason Apple TV+ is still worth the money – despite the price increase – is the undeniably brilliant quality of its original programming. While it feels as though every other Netflix series is a dud, almost every Apple drama is worth your time.

, a psychological drama set in an office where employees have their work and personal lives surgically separated, acerbic spy thriller multi-generational Korean epic and edge-of-your-seat airborne thriller are just a handful of the series that have kept me gripped since the streamer launched in 2019. I voted Sharon Horgan’s murderous comedy series my favourite TV show of the year in 2022. Even the “bad” programmes (which, in my opinion, are The Morning Showand ) are leagues ahead of some of the rival streamers’ best output.

Have you ever logged on to Netflix or Prime Video and been so overwhelmed with the sheer number of options that it becomes impossible to choose what to watch? Offering a lot of content might sound like an advantage for a streaming service, but in practice it adds a lot of pressure to what is supposed to be a fun way to relax.

Not so with Apple TV+ – since most of its library is made up of original programmes and films, the choice is not overwhelming, and without an over-complicated algorithm feeding you nonsense you would never choose to watch of your own volition, you’re more likely to find something engaging and interesting, rather than filler.

In 2021, Apple TV+ became the first streaming service to win the top prize at the Academy Awards with , a beautiful film about a young woman and her relationship with her deaf parents. Also nominated that year were Netflix’s and which had also missed out on a Best Picture award four times previously with , ,and

Apple’s TV programmes tend to sweep up at the Emmys and Golden Globes, too: has been nominated for an impressive 11 Emmys (including one win; ridiculous and cringey though it may be, it’s still hugely entertaining) and six Golden Globes over two seasons, while earned 14Emmy nominations (and two wins) for one season. Butit’s , Jason Sudeikis’s relentlessly positive comedy about an American coach who takes over an English football team that has the most Hollywood accolades, winning 11 Emmy awards out of 61 nominations.
If it’s critical praise and silverware that makes you watch a TV show or film, then an Apple TV+ subscription is a no-brainer.

From Tom Hanks’s turn as warship captain Commander Ernie Krause in the 2020 film to Jennifer Aniston and Reese Witherspoon’s double act as newsreaders Alex Levy and Bradley Jackson to Harrison Ford’s surprising role in Jason Segel’s therapy comedy , it’s no secret that Apple attracts some big, names.

And it’s not just actors – Martin Scorsese’s latest, , is an Apple production so will most likely be available only on Apple TV+ once its run in cinemas is over. Horror auteur M Night Shyamalan made his second ever TV drama, for Apple TV+, and Steven Spielberg has a deal with the streamer to create original TV dramas, starting with his offshoot which will arrive in January.

Alongside , perhaps the most highly anticipated film to come to Apple TV+ is Ridley Scott’s which stars Joaquin Phoenix as the titular French military leader. Other films on their way to the streamer include director Matthew Vaughn’s spy thriller starring Henry Cavill, Bryce Dallas Howard and Sam Rockwell, Steve McQueen’s British historical drama and an action flick led by Brad Pitt and George Clooney as two professional fixers who are assigned to the same job.

There’s plenty of TV to look forward to as well. A third series of is due on 1 December, while currently in its third season has unsurprisingly been renewed. As for new shows, there’s British period drama streaming from 8 November, based on Edith Wharton’s unfinished novel of the same name and following a group of American women who arrive on the dusty streets of 1870s London.

The first instalment of the MonsterVerse franchise (think Godzilla and King Kong alongside some new “Titans”), , is set to stream from Tuesday 17 November. The selection on Apple TV+ may be smaller, but it’s impossible to deny there’s a wide range of genres covered.

I’m not going to pretend Apple TV+ has never cancelled a series. the prehistoric thriller starring Jason Momoa, came to an end after three seasons, M Night Shyamalan’s  finished after four, and a (severely underrated if you ask me) adaptation of Paul Theroux’s novel of the same name which had run its course after two gripping seasons. But I’d argue that it’s never cancelled a series Online petitions weren’t created to save (proof that while a large majority of Apple TV+’s original programming is excellent, there are a few shows letting the side down).

Other streaming services (read: Netflix) are notorious for taking an axe to TV shows with dedicated followings, most controversially with . Since very few services share their viewing data, we have no idea what will inspire execs to give a series the chop, though its thought to be due to disappointing viewing figures in relation to the amount of subscribers a streamer has. Perhaps the fact that Apple TV+ has a roughly estimated 16 million fewer subscribers than Netflix is playing to its advantage.

After a seven-day free trial, Apple TV+ will cost you £8.99 every month. There are no confusing tiers with differing and baffling rules about password sharing or picture quality. You can share the account with up to five people and there’s just one straightforward subscription – and it’s cheaper than the Netflix equivalent, which is now £10.99 (and climbs by £4.99 for each member you add outside of your household). If it’s value for money that you’re after – and in the current cost-of-living crisis, who isn’t? – Apple TV+ is the best bang for your buck.

title: Stop criticising The Crown – it’s the perfect history lesson for millennials
lead: From Horrible Histories to Hilary Mantel, fiction has long helped us to understand the past – and forces us to question how historical narratives are formed
author: Emily Bootle

body.text: If I have ever found myself dropping historical facts about 20century Britain into conversation, I have also found myself ashamed by the inevitable confession that follows. I am not, as I may appear, a notable intellectual with a ludicrously impressive general knowledge. No, I will tell my compatriots – “I learned that on ”.

And yet, as excitement for the sixth series – the first four episodes of which will be released on Netflix on Thursday 16 November – builds, I think it’s time to put that shame aside. The drama has previously come under fire for its “historical inaccuracies”, and, two weeks ago, there was much furore about the revelation that Diana’s ghost would supposedly feature in the upcoming episodes (AN Wilson, writing in the Daily Mail, described it as a “sick joke”).

Yet proves that we can learn much about history through fictionalised accounts – and, in my experience, that a little bit of embellishment and character intrigue, and more focus on relationships, can drastically increase one’s tolerance for the hardcore facts that are nestled in between.

has been a mammoth undertaking for its writer, Peter Morgan, who originally conceived it as a film about Elizabeth II’s accession, before it quickly became clear there was a much bigger story to tell. This will be its final series, which means it will have documented the British royal family from 1952 until 2005 – the majority of the Queen’s reign (which, in its entirety, encompassed 15 prime ministers, multiple wars and drastic changes in perceptions of the monarchy).

It also included significant relationship drama for its members (including the acrimonious divorce of the former Prince Charles and the late Diana, Princess of Wales) – and works precisely because it is a gripping combination of history and soap opera.

The debate surrounding historical fiction – which has recently included the work of authors such as Hilary Mantel and Philippa Gregory – has raged for decades. Historian and historical fiction writer Simon Sebag-Montefiore has said that “historical fiction is simply fiction set in the past, and should be judged as such”: ie, it’s best not to dwell on how “true” it is to real life. But there are, of course, degrees of fiction, and degrees of history:Mantel’s Wolf Hall is a detailed character study of Henry VIII’s most trusted adviser, Thomas Cromwell, and is considered to be an accurate and detailed work, despite its fictionalisation.

Fiction restores humanity and life to the characters from the past. There’s no way that we can ever have a complete account of the conversations and feelings of the people we study through history. The best we can do is imagine it in order to better understand how they functioned, and why they did what they did – historians do this as well as fiction writers. (In a recent interview with, in fact, the classicist Mary Beard pointed out:  “Some of the most important historical facts are untrue. Whether or not you choose to believe it, these anecdotes, just like our anecdotes about monarchy or celebrity, are told for a reason. They reflect a truth about imperial power. They’re revealing a power structure of antagonism, of dissent.”)

For me – someone who is easily bored by the delivery of neat information but who is endlessly interested in emotions and human experience – this added depth means I am suddenly able to digest stories that might previously have eluded me, in the same way that children reading are able to understand facts about the Romans more easily when they involve toilet humour.

Perhaps this means I’m an adult baby millennial incapable of engaging with anything that’s not a high-budget Netflix drama that I can tweet about and eat avocado toast to. Well, so be it, because it works.

For a story like , set hundreds of years ago, it’s primarily historians and experts who would know if Mantel got it wrong. Technically, thousands of unsuspecting lay readers could absorb fiction as fact. In Mantel’s case, this hasn’t been found to be true – but it is the problem identified by critics of . And it is compounded by the fact that a great many people know the story is telling, because they’ve lived through it (including, most notably, the royal family themselves: Prince Harry has joked that he watches it in order to “fact-check”).

For me, this only serves to demonstrate further the subjectivity of historical accounts. I am aware that there are some “inaccuracies” in – which its historical director Annie Sulzberger has clarified to be creative decisions rather than simply mistakes – that are plainly not what happened (such as, as Wilson points out, the episode in which Prince Philip’s family come to visit him at boarding school and are killed in a plane crash; in fact, they were travelling to attend a wedding). But this is the soap opera element, the small details that fill in the gaps of the historical structure. The bits that are true are, unsurprisingly, the most interesting.

Nobody watching series six of will come away thinking that the ghost of Princess Diana is very busy with a packed schedule of hauntings (those inclined to think in such a way don’t need Morgan to influence them). And very few people will remember the minutiae of the dialogue to the extent that they learn it as fact.

What they will do, however, is absorb that Diana is a monumental figure in the imagination not just of the royal family but much of the British public. They will take in the atmosphere of the fabricated conversations surrounding the real events. They will remember the spirit of the characters they’ve been watching for hours on end – characters constructed in a similar way to those written into history books by people who can never be unbiased.

And they might come away with a renewed, or perhaps entirely novel, interest in the history of the country they live in. They might then google Aberfan, or Thatcherism, or the complicated legacy of the Commonwealth – and then they might even buy a book. All this because they’ve realised that history is about characters and relationships as well as wars and elections. Feelings as well as facts.
