title: The Kills, God Games, review: Cathartic – but so grimy you’ll need a shower afterwards
lead: With their first album in seven years, the duo have maintained an astonishing degree of consistency
author: Ed Power

body.text: The his ’n’hers rock duo was the early 21st century’s gift to humanity. From The White Stripes to The Ting Tings, for a few years the record industry couldn’t get enough of male/female duos – the scuzzier, the better.

The evolutionary zenith of the form was The Kills duo of Alison Mosshart and Jamie Hince. They had cheekbones to die for and a fashionably dishevelled sound that suggested all the best bits of the first three Velvet Underground albums playing at once.

They were also perfect chum for the tabloids by dint of Hince’s marriage to Kate Moss. Today, Moss and Hince are long divorced. But Mosshart has thoughtfully kept The Kills’ celebrity flames flickering with her new relationship with actor Damian Lewis.

Yet if the centre of gravity has shifted romance-wise, musically The Kills have maintained an astonishing degree of consistency on , their sixth LP and their first in seven years. Hince has explained that the goal was to write a collection of “godless spirituals”, which sounds like something Nick Cave would make up on the spot when asked what his next record sounds like.

In fact, Mosshart and Hince have made a Kills album that feels like a dead ringer of the other Kills albums (it features unobtrusive production by Adele hit-whisperer Paul Epworth). Mosshart’s vocals still sound as if they were recorded in a disused toilet in a Manhattan dive bar at 2am. Hince’s guitars have a gloriously grimy energy. It’s cathartic as anything, but you wonder if you’ll be needing a shower afterwards.

The songwriting is thumpingly solid. Mosshart’s growl has an implosive power on single “New York”. She is also the driving force on “LA Hex”, a drowsy hip-hop bopper that joins the dots between Massive Attack and Nine Inch Nails.

Best of all is “My Girls My Girls” – a wonderful, Lou Reed-type hymnal that, amid the wall-to-wall indie grindcore, alights upon a moment of stillness and beauty (and features backing from Compton Kidz Club, an after-school choir for disadvantaged children in LA). Hince may not have found God, but The Kills have served up another thrillingly bedraggled rumination on the unholy majesty of rock’n’roll.

title: The Future by Naomi Alderman, review: A terrific skewering of power-hungry billionaires like Elon Musk
lead: The author of the Women’s Prize-winning novel The Power returns with more prescient speculative fiction
author: Anna Bonet

body.text: Naomi Alderman is exceptional at world-building. We knew this already from her 2016 bestseller , in which she imagined the patriarchy being overturned when women develop an ability to release electric jolts from their fingers.

The way Alderman took everyday life and twisted it into something both unfamiliar yet totally recognisable was extraordinary; it was no wonder it became an agenda-setting novel that won the Women’s Prize in 2017, was named a book of the year by everyone from Barack Obama to Bill Gates, and was recently adapted into a TV series for Amazon Prime.

Here, in, Alderman pulls off that same feat: opening the pages of her first novel since  is less like reading and more like stepping into a parallel universe. Once inside, we are confronted with an environment where a handful of entitled tech billionaires are exploiting their power to the destruction of the planet. So far, so easy to relate to real life.

But Alderman has clearly had a lot of fun with imagining futurist technology – we have concepts such as private weather systems (rain can be swapped for sun) and screens that pop up from sleeve cuffs. The atmosphere, meanwhile, is constantly teetering on the brink of apocalypse, where “preppers” and forums dedicated to survivalism are the norm.

The plot is as intricate as the setting. The book begins as three tech chief executives – social media mogul Lenk Sketlish, computing boss Ellen Bywater, and chief executive of an Amazon-like business giant Zimri Nommik – have been informed by AI that the world is about to end. The cause? A pandemic worse than Covid. The trio board a private jet to a secret doomsday bunker, and the final sentence of this prologue sums up their self-centred elitism perfectly: “They weren’t leaving the world, the world was leaving them”.

then zips back in time “a few months before the end of the world” and across the globe to Singapore, just as Chinese-American survivalist influencer Lai Zhen is the subject of an assassination attempt. Despite the videos she has made about how to master your fear in emergency situations, it turns out all she hears inside her head as shots are fired is “her own stupid voice saying: You might piss your pants”.

Next, we rewind another six months, and are introduced to Martha Einkorn, who grew up in an oppressive religious cult and now works in California as an assistant to Sketlish. Martha and Zhen meet at a conference in London and quickly begin an affair,but the story properly kicks off when we learn Martha is plotting with a group of rebels to take control away from the Silicon Valley billionaires.
In this sense,  is a Russian doll of a book: a love story wrapped up in a tale of a heist, all of which is inside a fable about big tech, climate change, morality, and inequality.

The many layers of the novel unfold over different timelines, and this isn’t straightforward to follow. However, the prose itself is terrific. Alderman has been mentored by Margaret Atwood and it shows: this is high-calibre writing that crackles with more wit than you might expect given the themes.

It’s at its best with the tongue-in-cheek descriptions of the CEOs. “On the day the world ended, Lenk Sketlish […] sat at dawn beneath the redwoods in a designated location of natural beauty and attempted to inhale from his navel,” reads the book’s very first sentence.

Like  – and Alderman’s 2006 debut , about a woman returning home to an Orthodox Jewish community in north London, which became a 2017 film starring Rachel Weisz and Rachel McAdams –  is also destined to be adapted for screen. Thanks to the vivid prose, it already spools out in the mind’s eye like a high-budget drama.

Given Alderman also works as a video game writer, it’s little wonder she is skilled at the visuals – but there’s something else she has the knack for. When  came out, women worldwide were protesting the misogyny of the newly-elected Donald Trump, and a handful of months later, the #MeToo movement surged. We needed stories about feminism and gender power dynamics more than ever.

Now, arrives off the back of a pandemic (Alderman started writing it long before Covid), as ChatGPT makes AI mainstream and as Elon Musk’s power-hungry control of Twitter (or should that be X?) grows more unsettling by the day.
The clue is in the name: ’s greatest gift is prescience, and this alone makes Alderman a worthy contender for another major literary prize.

title: Jilly Cooper will never be too old to write sex scenes
lead: Writing and reading sex is that it’s an act of creative desire – any story that centres female desire, and boosts the erotic imagination, is worth telling
author: Daisy Buchanan

body.text: When I was a teenager, I turned to Jilly Cooper for my sex education. At school, we were taught the basics about our bodies. But it was Cooper’s characters who showed me how sexual desire really felt. Most importantly, her explicit scenes put women front and centre. It was all about what women wanted, and how they felt. In the 1980s, beloved bonkbusters  and  dominated the book charts. By the time they reached me 20 years later, they had become classics – and they still felt thrilling and fun.

Cooper is the ultimate saucy storyteller, and she has inspired me to write racy novels of my own, including  and . So I was shocked to hear that Cooper, my sex scene queen, recently revealed to an audience at the Cheltenham Literature Festival that she’s “forgotten” how to write the scenes that made her famous – and she’s worried that she might be too old. “I’m 86 now, and I’ve forgotten how to do it,” she recently told  magazine.

I love writing about sex, and reading about it. There are plenty of fantastic writers who are writing stories that sizzle. I love books by Melanie Blake, Abby Jimenez, and Akwaeke Emezi. But Cooper’s comments have made me wonder what readers want from sex on the page – and whether it’s hard to write sex when you’re 86 because there aren’t enough sexy books featuring older characters.

Cooper’s classics are filled with beautiful ingenues. In one of my favourites, the love interest is an “older man”… of 24. I’m certain that there’s a demand for erotic fiction starring older characters, and I’m sure there are brilliant writers who are creating those stories. I wonder whether publishers are making sure that those stories are reaching the readers who need them the most. I want these books, and I suspect Jilly does, too.

The best thing about writing and reading sex is that it’s an act of creative desire. You can be completely guided by your imagination – it’s a form of escapism. The hottest stories don’t focus on the appearance of characters’ bodies. It’s all about what’s happening in their heads – which gives the reader room to come along for the ride. (Sorry.)
As a reader, I don’t care how old the character is, or how old the writer is. If I can connect with the story, a hot book is a hot book.

Writing sex scenes is challenging, because you really do have to write like no one is watching. I like to lose myself completely on the page, and pretend that no one else is going to read what I’m writing. It sounds counterintuitive, but I believe that you can only ever write sex to please one reader – yourself.

However, we fans have been waiting with bated breath for Cooper’s new novel,  I’m sure she’s conscious of the fact that generations of us have loved her books and learned from them. I wonder whether she’s a victim of her own success – being able to write a great sex scene has nothing to do with age, but it’s difficult when you’ve set a very high bar for yourself and you know that your millions of readers have great expectations.

Those of us who have been inspired by Cooper have a responsibility to maintain her legacy. Her novels taught me so much – and my erotic education is ongoing. As we get older, we hope to become more confident, and know our bodies better. There’s room for novels to reflect those positive changes.

I believe any story that centres female desire, and boosts the erotic imagination, is worth telling. I also believe it’s up to us to write stories featuring the broadest cast of characters possible, where everyone gets to have great sex – long after they have reached the grand old age of 24.

title: Don’t underestimate Shetland – this Scottish drama is better than Scandi noir
lead: It has confused critics, but there’s nothing else on TV like the quirky detective show. With Ashley Jenson taking the lead for the eighth series, this could be its chance to shine
author: Gwendolyn Smith

body.text: Scandi noir has had its day. Modern crime drama is more about twisty, -esque police procedurals than moody landscapes and fawning over Sarah Lund’s knitwear on .

But while ,  and their endless imitators have had their moment in the (weak, intermittent) sun, there is one brooding, Nordic-inflected series that endures. And that is , which tonight returns to BBC One for its eighth series, as fans nervously wait to see whether Ashley Jensen can fill Douglas Henshall’s shoes as the beloved Scottish drama’s star sleuth.

First broadcast a full decade ago in 2013, Shetland has been fairly fondly received by critics, but its uneven tone – how it veers between chilling noir and daytime whodunnit – has held it back from serious acclaim.
But don’t underestimate it. The upside of it being hard to categorise – it is certainly cosier than your average noir – is that there’s nothing else quite like it on TV.

It is a hugely successful export, being shown in the US, Australia, Canada and all across Europe, and an average 5.8 million viewers tuned into each episode of series seven last year – very impressive for the streaming era. What it occasionally lacks in gravitas it makes up for with its endearing, believable characters – there was genuine despair when Henshall’s piercingly blue-eyed DI Jimmy Pérez bowed out at the end of the last series.

Following the success in the 2010s of  and, both European producers, and British execs desperate to make “Celtic noir” happen, churned out a slew of shows in the same ilk – think of  and  on the European side, and and  in the UK.

But part of the reason these dramas fell out of fashion is they felt more like cynical attempts to cash in on a trend than stories genuinely worthy of our attention.  is different, firstly because it predates all those thrillers anyway, being based on Ann Cleeves’s series of novels of the same name (helpfully giving it a readymade, devoted fanbase).
And at its heart it’s more about portraying Shetland’s distinctive community than aping Scandi drama.

Yes, as a former Viking stronghold, Shetland has an unmistakably Nordic soul. Lying 110 miles off the north coast of Scotland, the wind-lashed archipelago is actually further north than Copenhagen, Stockholm and Oslo and shares a latitude with the tip of Greenland.

Its inhabitants have the highest levels of Viking DNA found anywhere in Britain, it has the highest density of Viking-era sites in the UK and a language derived from Old Norse was spoken there until the 19th century.

But while the show plays with all this, with its sweeping shots of Shetland’s spare beauty, muted colour palette (it “looks as if it was filmed through a pair of 15 denier tights” wrote the journalist Filipa Jodelka in 2014) and storylines taking in archaeological digs, its main focus is the close-knit society in which the islanders live.

This is a big part of Jensen’s character’s storyline in the new series, for instance. The  star’s DI Ruth Calder has spent 20 years working for the Met in London, but must now return to her native Shetland to pursue a young woman who witnessed a gangland murder. But once she’s back, she’s reminded of how claustrophobic she found island life. “I couldn’t wait to get away,” she says of leaving two days after her 18th birthday.

Of course, that tight-knit community cuts both ways: the new series also sees fan favourite DS Alison “Tosh” McIntosh (Alison O’Donnell), now “temporary DI” and teaming up with DI Calder, driving around to check in on a victim of a crime after her work day is done – not something you imagine Calder did at the Met.

“The Isles were so much a part of Pérez,” said Henshall before his departure, and the show suggests this is a place that really burrows into people’s psyches. Which might explain why while Pérez may have quit policing in order to finally concentrate on his home life, a fair few of the cast remain unchanged from series one.

Back then, the show began as a two-part adaptation of Ann Cleeves’ novel , about an elderly Shetland resident found murdered at her croft. Series two expanded to six episodes – a trio of two-part stories covering a further three of Cleeves’ novels. Wisely, by the third series in 2016, all six episodes covered a single story.

This had the advantage of both reducing this fictional Shetland’s increasingly improbable body count, and taking it away from the one-mystery-per-episode whodunnit territory of that other perennially popular Ann Cleeves adaptation, .

In its new guise,  had more depth in terms of characterisation and detail about Pérez’s complicated home life (following his wife’s death, he co-parents his stepdaughter Cassie with her chaotic biological dad Duncan, played by ’s Mark Bonnar).

has had its fair share of glamorous guest stars over the years. Succession’s Brian Cox plays an eccentric loner who becomes the scapegoat in the murder of a teenage girl in series two, while Anna Chancellor crops up in the next batch of episodes as a detective desperate to cover up a crime committed byher son.
A young Gemma Chan plays a junior archaeologist early on and ’s Phyllis Logan stars as a formidable matriarch in the new series.

But it’s always been about Henshall’s Pérez, with his trademark black pea coat and impeccable moral compass. The characters around him, particularly some of the more minor figures at the police station, may have a flimsiness reminiscent of daytime drama, but Henshall invested Pérez with enough depth and quiet wit to win a Scottish Bafta in 2016 for the role.

A workaholic with a dead wife, the detective risked falling into the cliché of the troubled cop, but Henshall’s performance as well as a decent script made him understated enough to ring true as a struggling single dad.
His last move as a policeman was to free an innocent man from custody before he could be extradited to America, where he would have ended up on death row.

It was a noble act worthy of Pérez’s final career call, though his goodliness might have been why we lost him in the first place – discussing his departure, Henshall seemed to be itching to branch out from eternally nice guy Pérez and said he “would love to play a baddie again”.
So how will survive without him? At first, the prospect looked as bleak as the Isles’ weather, but Henshall’s fellow Scot Jensen is a promising successor.

A lot of the joy of  lies in its eccentricities, from key suspects owning seal sanctuaries to plotlines about the island’s annual Up Helly Aa festival, which is out-there enough to include the immolation of a full-size Viking longship. As the actor behind the brittle Fran in  and who was nominated for an Emmy for her portrayal of socially inept Maggie in Jensen has plenty of oddball charm of her own and should fit right in.

Besides, she has Tosh to partner up with, whom O’Donnell has made the ultimate Everywoman as we’ve followed her from hungover, brace-wearing DS to a working mum and detective inspector in the making. “You’re ready,” Pérez said of her taking over his job. “Trust me.”

She is such a delightful character that many fans interpreted his comments as a plea to the BBC to make O’Donnell the lead in the show. Instead, she is co-starring with Jensen, giving us a drama that is led by two women at relatively equal stages in their career, which certainly feels a lot more up to date than Pérez and Tosh’s father-daughter-like bond.
On top of that, the thing the critics sniff at about may actually be the key to its longevity. It might veer between chilling and cosy, but its humdrum edge keeps it real – and watchable.
You can admire, for example, Saga Noren’s brilliant characterisation in as much as you want, but none of us could have stomached eight series of that show’s unremitting bleakness.

’s softer moments – such as Duncan and Jimmy sweetly fretting over the best way to parent Cassie – mean we can watch for series after series. Less Scandi noir than Scottish grey, then – but that might just be the perfect level for our times. As the real world becomes increasingly grim, we want our dramas to deliver reassurance as well as thrills.
Henshall’s departure was the one thing that could have killed  off. But with Jensen likely to freshen it up, it looks unlikely to bite the dust anytime soon (unlike many of its fictional residents).

True, the actor hasn’t yet confirmed she’ll be staying beyond the current series, but she seems at home in Scotland after her years in LA. “I’ve loved going back… Scottish people have a wee understanding with each other,” she told The Times last week.

So here’s to the future of . The new series should confirm what its fans have known all along – its quiet confidence, lovable characters and a strong, quirky sense of place has made it TV gold. Maybe Scottish drama trumps Scandi noir after all.

title: Shetland, BBC One, review: This crime drama was on its last legs – Ashley Jensen might have saved it
lead: Douglas Henshall abandoned a sinking ship, but a new lead detective has breathed new life into the Scottish drama
author: Gerard Gilbert

body.text: Ashley Jensen was a bold choice to replace Douglas Henshall as the lead detective in . Given the climate in the UK’s most northerly region, Henshall’s mournful widower DI Jimmy Pérez was suitably buttoned up, while Jensen’s open, sunny disposition has usually been deployed for comic effect in shows like , and .

As if trying to give herself as much distance as possible from these roles, Jensen didn’t smile once in her opening episode as Met detective DI Ruth Calder. A Shetlander who left the island 20 years previously and has never looked back, Calder was forced to return, reluctantly, when ordered to trace a vital witness to a London gangland shooting.

This witness, Ellen Quinn (Maisie Norma Seaton), had been busy robbing the victim in a honeytrap scam when she was interrupted by contract killers. Ellen scarpered back to the island, swiftly followed by the hitmen: Howell and his volatile Eastern European partner Nowak (Don Gilet and Arnas Fedarvicius).

They faced not only capture by Calder and the local cops, but also the wrath of Ellen’s grandmother, Grace Bains (a second formidable matriarch played by ’s Phyllis Logan, following her crime family boss Maggie Lynch in BBC Two’s .)

Long-time fans looking out for familiar faces will have been relieved that DI “Tosh” McIntosh (Alison O’Donnell) was still  – and indeed was temporarily in charge since DI Calder had no jurisdiction in Scotland. There was also the comforting presence of Sgt Billy McCabe (Lewis Howden), who was on hand to offer Tosh a scone with her afternoon cuppa. Not that  does much else in the way of cosy.

But this is primarily Jensen’s gig, and while she had her first headlining role in Sky’s comic crime drama ,  is a very different kettle of fish (or, in this case, red herrings). Calder has bags of back story, including an estranged brother, Alan (Steven Miller), who is now a local vicar, and a dead dad who was – for reasons as yet unbeknownst to viewers – responsible for Calder’s escape from Shetland.

It was a busy but confidently plotted opening episode, one that featured Tosh also investigating a number of dead sheep with seemingly occult symbols marked on their carcasses. There were some whimsical touches as well, such as the hot-headed Nowak (who had no compunction about killing an elderly shopkeeper) being an avid bird-watcher. He wanted to go puffin-spotting once he’d finished with Ellen.

By the end of the episode, the body count had increased by two (not counting the dead sheep). Ellen was one of the dead, although the identity of the killer remained unclear. And with Howell and a badly injured Nowak (after an in-car tussle with Ellen) still at large, and a vengeful Grace on their trail, the mortuary at Lerwick is likely to become even busier over the coming weeks.

has apparently become a global hit, despite (or because of) there being no easily exportable tartan tweeness. This is contemporary Scotland with a strong Scandi-noir vibe underlined by the spectacular, treeless vistas.

But Douglas Henshall’s hugely sympathetic performance was also central to its appeal. So what a relief that has successfully managed that tricky switch of lead detectives previously seen in other long-running crime dramas – from  to , by way of Unforgotten and .
In fact, it feels altogether refreshed, and so far, one of the more enjoyable series yet.

title: The Collins word of the year shortlist shows we’re more self-obsessed than ever
lead: ‘Nepo baby’, ‘deinfluencing’, ‘canon event’: the internet has developed new vocabulary to counteract the image of perfection it once encouraged. Instead, the shortlist reveals, we are pushed towards yet more self-narrative
author: Emily Bootle

body.text: Of all the end-of-year round-ups that inevitably begin come November – from Spotify Wrapped to Sainsbury’s top customers – the most revealing of the annual tenor has got to be the “words of the year” from the Collins, Cambridge, Merriam Webster and Oxford dictionaries. Over the past few years, the chosen words of various dictionaries have included “permacrisis”, “NFT”, “lockdown”, “fake news”, “gaslighting”, “pandemic” and “post-truth”, giving an indication of the political and cultural climate.

Though sometimes the words are highly specific – “lockdown” and “pandemic” being the most obvious – sometimes they are more nebulous, or linked to a niche cultural phenomenon as opposed to a universal experience. In 2004, for example, the OED’s word of the year was “bovvered” – stemming directly from the “am I bovvered” Catherine Tate sketch that was so popular at the time. Last year, it was “goblin mode” – an internet term celebrating slatternly behaviour.

And now, Collins has announced its shortlist and winner for 2023. This year, “AI” has come out on top – not strictly a word, but an acronym standing for “artificial intelligence”, and referring to the alarmingly sharp increase in the prevalence of robots in our lives, through software like ChatGPT. The shortlist also features “ultra-processed”, a word that has grown in traction this year following the release of Chris Van Tulleken’s best-selling book  and “greedflation”, the phenomenon whereby businesses use inflation as an excuse to inflate their prices artificially.

But in the more nebulous cultural sphere are some words and phrases that reveal a lot about the shifting cultural patterns in contemporary life: namely “nepo baby”, “deinfluencing” and “canon event”. What these reveal is that the internet is finally catching up with itself: or, put more simply, that people are no longer seeking the image of the perfect life that has been sold to us online over the past 10 years, and instead are looking to debunk bullshit.

“Nepo baby” refers, of course, to people whose career has been advanced by having celebrity parents (Collins stipulates that it most commonly applies to people in the entertainment industry). Nepo babies have been around since showbiz began – but the term has picked up traction this year because of the kind of collective outing of them – from Iris Law to Kylie Jenner – that serves to demonstrate the realities of success. While we are often sold the idea that anyone can be rich and famous, increased awareness of nepo babies means people are better acquainted with the reality that it’s a lot easier to make it in entertainment if you have someone who can get you in the door.

Similarly, “deinfluencing” is obviously a direct counter to “influencing” (“influencer”, as it happens, was on the Collins shortlist in 2019) – a word that has become fully absorbed into common parlance over the last few years, essentially referring to an individual selling products via social media. “Deinfluencing” refers to a growing phenomenon whereby people with large followings essentially tell us what not to buy – again, something that seeks to cut through the stream of content that shows us that perfect lifestyles are attainable simply by buying more stuff.
Crucially, though, even deinfluencing still looks to further the “personal brand”. It gives you clout among your followers and increases your image as someone with integrity and authenticity.

Although the social media pivot to “authenticity” has been hailed almost unchallenged as a positive thing in recent times, it’s not quite so straightforward. Everything we do online is a performance of some kind, which means even authenticity – the thing that’s supposed to be the antidote to performance – can become staged. What we’ve seen in opposition to the “highlight reels” that were encouraged in the early days of Instagram and Facebook is instead the quest for self-narrative: which means documenting the good, the bad and the ugly for everyone to see.

Which brings us to “canon event” – another phrase identified by Collins as definitive of 2023. Online, this is used to refer to particularly seismic happenings in the lives of individuals that are perceived to have gone on to define their identities (the trend stems from the recent Spider Mananimated film , which centres on a series of events that defined Spider Man – for example, getting bitten by a radioactive magic spider and turning into a superhero). This could, when laced with typical social media irony, encompass anything from childhood trauma to a haircut – the important point is that the “canon event” contributes to the impression of the person given to their followers on social media.

All of this is to say that, although Collins’ word of the year may seem a little obvious, in the shortlist there is much to reveal the current state of culture. Online communities still have huge influence. Celebrities are increasingly under scrutiny. We are no longer putting up with bullshit. And, perhaps somewhat reassuringly, we are still just as self-obsessed as ever.

title: David Hockney, National Portrait Gallery review: Revels in sexuality – and not just Harry Styles’s
lead: The 86-year-old genius’s new show Drawing from Life is not his best work – but it has moments of magnificence
author: Hettie Judah

body.text: The morning ahead of my visit to the David Hockney show at the National Portrait Gallery, I was preparing questions for a talk with a young painter. Hockney references washed over the younger painter’s work. In particular the curving patterns with which Hockney described the surface of sparkling water in his Californian swimming pool paintings of the 1960s, 70s and 80s.

There is no question that Hockney is still relevant, that he is a point of reference for younger generations. I grew up seeing his illustrations and his paintings widely reproduced. He has had a formative impact. So why was I filled with lowering dread?

is a retrospective focusing on the artist’s portraiture, and his drawing practice in particular. The heart of the show is lovely, structured around four important relationships – with his mother Laura Hockney, the designer Celia Birtwell, his lover (later friend) Gregory Evans, and the printmaker Maurice Payne.

It was what came after this that worried me – a series of painted portraits made in the artist’s Normandy studio in 2021-22. I really did not enjoy Hockney’s iPad paintings made in the same period, exhibited at the Royal Academy in 2021 as  In that instance I could at least admire his career-long commitment to experimenting with new (and old) technologies, from Polaroids to the
This show was to be a return to painting, though, and from the advance images circulated by the gallery, it didn’t look glorious.

Back in August, the National Portrait Gallery teased a Hockney portrait of musician/universal lust object Harry Styles – presumably hoping it would attract a young audience to the exhibition. On screen, at least, it recalled the wilfully naive paintings made by comedian Joe Lycett. So much so that Lycett affectionately lampooned the work, releasing his own “portrait” of Styles on Instagram, together with a suitably ludicrous backstory. (Styles subsequently offered to purchase Lycett’s portrait for £6.)

Hockney is now 86 and not in fantastic health. He still apprehends the world through drawing, almost compulsively. A short film at the start of the exhibition shows him leafing through what look like custom sketchbooks showing meals and streetscapes and town squares and ashtrays. The new portrait paintings are positioned as the exhibition finale. He looks like he’s having a lot of fun with them, portraying himself, brush in hand, all smiles, like a jolly uncle.

He surrounds himself with a broad and evidently fond circle of friends and visitors. Is this his best work? No. While the bodies are often rendered with confident fluency, he seems to become tentative when he reaches the face, as though second guessing himself. There is something hesitant about the actual portraits that stops them hanging together.

Mercifully, the portrait of Harry Styles is very much not the highlight of this exhibition. Indeed, the final chamber of recent paintings feels like a peculiar addendum to what is otherwise a show of thoughtful delicacy, exploring shifts and developments in Hockney’s style through his portraits of those closest to him.

The Celia Birtwell room opens with a sparing ink drawing from the late 1960s in which her face is framed by curls and her eyes by heavy rims of kohl. Hockney is fascinated by the shifting subtleties of her face, apparently seeing her afresh at each sitting. Her extravagant costumes invite colour, and the artist turns to crayons to capture the full glory of her romantic ensembles in  (1973) and .

Within the intimacy of these works is also acknowledgement of Birtwell as a sensuous being. Hockney draws her asleep, or reclining on a bed in a black lace slip. Her sexuality becomes an evident and mysterious source of fascination. One of the central “arguments” of this show is that Hockney sees more in faces he knows well – those he has studied over time always yield new material, while new faces tend to produce less interesting work. Revisiting Birtwell over the decades, Hockney has also experimented with bold, large-format printmaking, bringing her into view with a great variety of different marks and materials.

In one of two photo-collages in the show, we find Birtwell with her two sons and two cats (one the famous Percy, immortalised in Hockney’s beloved double portrait .) The composite photographic image suggests a rush of movement, and time passing – in striking contrast to Hockney’s drawings, which are muffled in stillness, all time arrested.
The other photo collage, in an adjacent gallery, is a wonderful portrait of Hockney’s mother Laura, engulfed in a green raincoat, sitting in the funereal ruins of Bolton Abbey in Yorkshire in 1982.

Hockney’s brogues are just visible in the foreground – behold a widowed mother and adult son on a damp day out, surrounded by the architecture of death and commemoration. Beside it is a little ink drawing from three years earlier, of Laura Hockney on the day of her husband’s funeral. Made in sepia ink, a favoured medium of Hockney’s great hero Rembrandt, the gentle portrait again makes a case for the intimacy of drawing in relation to photography. There is no apparatus shoved between the artist and his mother – he is, as he would say, “eyeballing” her.

Not that Hockney has a great aversion to technical apparatus. In the late 1990s he made a series of portrait drawings using a  – a mounted prism that cast a small likeness of the sitter on the artist’s page. Hockney was interested in technologies that may have been used by earlier artists (in this case, the 19th-century French painter Ingres). Rather than tracing a full portrait, the  allowed him to mark out the position of facial features. He made a number of such drawings of Gregory Evans, which are certainly lively and even a little uncanny, but also far less tender and bewitching than his earlier unmediated drawings.

As Hockney’s lover, Evans’ arrival on the page is intoxicating. Hockney draws him with a fine ink line looking moody and romantic in a trench coat among Roman ruins. In a lithograph of 1976, he is naked but for his gym socks – his calves monumental in the foreground. (Socks are suggestive. Patrick Procktor drew Joe Orton reclining nude but for his socks in 1967.)

Again demonstrating Hockney’s ability to constantly see the same sitter in fresh ways, a standing nude of Evans from 1976 shows him boyish and almost androgynous. A more formal seated portrait finds him camp and dandyish is a giant floppy bow, high-waisted flares and high-heeled boots. Forget Harry Styles – Evans is this show’s grand object of desire.

The Evans gallery shows the greatest swoops of change, in both Hockney’s style and in the relationship between the two sitters over five decades. It is magnificent – a tribute to human changeability, its complex variation posing a ripe antidote to the idea that a human might possess a lone, iconic kind of likeness. We are a thing in motion, in constant change.
The next day, in my talk with the young painter, I asked what he thought I should write about Hockney. He shrugged. “That’s easy – he’s a genius, isn’t he?” Well, quite.

title: King Lear, Wyndham’s Theatre review: Kenneth Branagh needs to stop directing himself
lead: The entire thing has the feel of some dubious historical recreation for tourists
author: Fiona Mountford

body.text: Kenneth Branagh may well be one of our finest stage actors – but he certainly isn’t one of the country’s leading theatre directors. Yet every time Branagh returns to the stage, he insists upon directing himself rather than entrusting the task to someone with an outside perspective. This unwise tactic has been playing to diminishing returns for years now and fatally undermines his take on one of the most iconic roles in Shakespeare, a role Branagh fans have been longing to see him assume.

Branagh sets his production in Ancient Britain, which gives us the first of the evening’s myriad problems in the form of a set (designer Jon Bausor) of irredeemable naffness. A lowering cut-out of what appears to be a huge cosmic eye hovers over the stage, with strange planetary projections playing across it. Looming Stonehenge-style rocks circle the playing area; what with these and the cosmic eye the cast looks awkwardly hemmed in. The costumes are from the “big hair, big beards, big boots” school, giving the entire thing the feel of some dubious historical recreation for tourists.

Lear’s troubles start when he peremptorily jettisons his erstwhile favourites – Cordelia (Jessica Revell) and Gloucester (Joseph Kloska) – while he is busy with the worst example of inheritance tax planning in history, dividing his kingdom between his three daughters. Yet it is hard to feel very much at all as the tragic ramifications of this play out.

Branagh hits the key notes of Lear’s character arc as he moves from imperious monarch to a broken man with a fracturing mind (“Let me not be mad”). But it remains a very exterior performance, with little sense of real depth of feeling and emotion. One might say that it’s an old-fashioned performance, with much declaiming and enunciation so over-precise that every letter “t” is spat out like a sharp tack.

Branagh has edited the famously lengthy text down into a two-hour, interval-free running time. This streamlining strips the play of gravitas and nuance; there is much rushing about and it is often unclear which of the warring houses we are in at any given moment. The play’s descent into bloody violence also feels unearned. A little less banging of sticks and carefully choreographed fighting and a little more iambic pentameter would serve the production well.

There are, thankfully, occasional moments of startling pathos, such as the reunion of Lear and his old friend Gloucester on the cliffs at Dover. The cast is predominantly composed of recent RADA graduates and there is notable work from Revell, who doubles as Cordelia and the Fool, and Eleanor de Rohan as a staunchly loyal Kent.
But it is hard not to reflect ruefully upon how an external director would have kept all these excesses in check.
